We wish him every success."}, {'id': 1951, 'article_title': 'CHRISTMAS AND NEW YEAR', 'full_section_title': 'CHRISTMAS AND NEW YEAR', 'last_edit_date': None, 'num_tokens': 0, 'language': 'en', 'block_type': 'text', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/23_12_1870#article-13', 'issue_date': '23_12_1870', 'content': "It has been our custom at this period of the year to send our special greeting to our friends, the subscribers and readers of the African Times. This is the tenth occasion on which we have had to fulfil this pleasing duty; the tenth time at which, while preparing to welcome the return of that festival wherein the Christian world commemorates the human birth in the Bethlehem stable of Him who is the King of Glory, the everlasting Son of the Father, our Redeemer, and our future Judge, we have had to ask ourself how we are performing this work which He has given us to do for the so long degraded and oppressed children of Africa. All we can say is, that we have endeavoured to do it as in his sight; with the earnest desire to be in peace and charity with all men, even when it has seemed most incumbent upon us to oppose, to censure, or to condemn. In this spirit of peace and charity we again give expression to our hearts' wishes that a Happy Christmas and a Happy Year may be the lot of all our friends and readers; and that the blessing of the Prince of Peace may be, and abide with, and upon each and every one of them. We feel that they cannot know true happiness or be made partakers of that blessing unless that Prince of Peace be enthroned in their hearts. Our wish, therefore, includes this, and applies, not only to fleeting earthly time, but also to an unchangeable eternity in Heaven."}, {'id': 2049, 'article_title': 'Death of Mr. Charles Buxton, M.P.', 'full_section_title': 'Death of Mr. Charles Buxton, M.P.', 'last_edit_date': None, 'num_tokens': 0, 'language': 'en', 'block_type': 'text', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/23_08_1871#article-1', 'issue_date': '23_08_1871', 'content': 'In Mr. Charles Buxton the people of Africa have lost a sincere friend, and we greatly regret his loss, being fully able to endorse all that the Under-Secretary of State for the Colonies, Mr. Knatchbull-Hugessen, so feelingly expressed concerning him. Mr. Buxton held a very strong opinion as to the work the _African Times_ was doing for Africa and its people, and a few years since begged us to accept the sum of two guineas annually instead of five shillings for one copy of the _African Times_. In addition we would only express the hope that the mantle of ready African advocacy which the late Mr. Charles Buxton so worthily wore will have fallen on the shoulders of the present Sir T. Fowell Buxton, so that Africa may still have one of that honoured race of her defenders to help in the struggle to obtain for her people those administrative and other reforms which are essential to their taking that place among the peoples of the earth which the lamented Sir T. Fowell Buxton predicted for them, and claimed for them as their just and certain inheritance. One by one, alas! our friends and helpers in the work for Africa disappear from the scene of earthly usefulness. The good Sir Thomas Acland has been speedily followed by Mr. Charles Buxton. May God strengthen us proportionately, that the work yet to be done for Africa may not languish, nor be inefficiently executed!'}, {'id': 2112, 'article_title': 'Want of Common Decency', 'full_section_title': 'Want of Common Decency', 'last_edit_date': '09-01-1871', 'num_tokens': 0, 'language': 'en', 'block_type': 'text', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/23_10_1871#article-13', 'issue_date': '23_10_1871', 'content': 'Sir,—I am a coloured man, and having had ample opportunities of visiting this part of the globe, known as the West Coast of Africa, I beg leave to say, Mr. Editor, that although the African Times is striving daily for the justice of mankind and peace with God, vindicating the cause of Africa and her people, that there are many who call themselves Englishmen, subjects of England's Queen, who are yet giving a deaf ear to the call which monthly strikes loud in every heart, and it seems that they will not in any way amend until their cup of iniquity be filled. Take this as an instance: That well-known captain of the African Steamship Company who is styled "The Hater of Africans" (for every one knows him to be so) was on his way last voyage to the southern ports, and, as is always the case, anchored off Fernando Po. The consignees went on board, their cox and boatswains, sailors of H.M.S. Pert, and passengers, &c. The language of the captain that day was rather sharp, for I took a minute of it verbatim, as follows: "Had I known that so many of these black fellows would have come on board I might have passed off to south before calling here." He then ordered one of his boats to be lowered, and went on shore. What a shame and disgrace to a man occupying so high a position! However, before he went on shore, as his words...

were thrown like dice on the table, so it was retaliated to him as follows: "If you don't wish to see all these black fellows, you ought to have sat at home, and not come cruising all along the towns and islands of Africa." Suppose that steamer was an African's (and I believe they could now afford one), and an increase, say from 20 to 25 per cent. be made to his wages, then he would rather work for an African than a European. He worked for nothing else save his money. To him as well as to all such, I ask, Where were ye when the Rev. S. Crowther, Bishop for the Bights of Benin and Biafra, was ordained? Where were ye when that able doctor, John Africanus Beale Horton, was appointed, who is now doctor on the seacoast of Accra, &c., and whose works found a place amongst the many thousands in England and elsewhere? Call at Sierra Leone, where are the Quakers, Johnsons, Maxwells, and many others. Have they not proved themselves worthy of the posts they filled?

To you, Mr. Editor, I say that the blessed Trinity will ever be pouring his blessings on you; and again to you Africa's sons and daughters are indebted.—Believe me to be,'}, {'id': 2127, 'article_title': 'CONSTITUTION OF THE FANTI CONFEDERATION.', 'full_section_title': 'CONSTITUTION OF THE FANTI CONFEDERATION.', 'last_edit_date': None, 'num_tokens': 0, 'language': 'en', 'block_type': 'text', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/23_01_1872#article-7', 'issue_date': '23_01_1872', 'content': '## The African Times.

**TUESDAY, JANUARY 23, 1872.**

**SUBSCRIPTIONS RECEIVED FOR "AFRICAN TIMES."**  
Mr. R. Eastmon, 5s.; Rev. C. Davies, 5s.; W. M. Gloucester, 10s.; W. D. Broderick, 5s.

---

### A FEW WORDS OF THANKS & EXPLANATION.

We have so many letters expressing wonder and indignation, and asking why it is, that persons on the Coast who either in themselves or in those who might be supposed to be dear to them have been benefited through our instrumentality, should abuse and vilify us, that although we do not insert them, we are at least in duty bound to notice them, and to thank our friends for their honest feeling in our cause. We can only further write a few words in reply. We neither hoped nor expected to work a moral change in those of whom they write. An old Persian aphorism says, "You may feed a snake upon violets, and lull him to sleep upon roseleaves, but he will produce nothing but poison." So it is with some human beings. In what we did for them and theirs in vindication of great principles, we did not look for attachment or reward. If it had come to us, we should have accepted it and been grateful for it; but we were never disappointed in its not coming. If we had the power to give them personal benefits, beyond what they are receiving from our official enemies of whom they make themselves subservient tools, they would become at once loud-tongued and strong-penned adherents. But as this cannot be, they follow their natural instincts. The time may come when they may be victims of some flagrant abuse of power, some disgraceful injustice, some odious wrong. Then they will find us at their side, and using all our influence in their behalf; not for their own sakes personally, but because of the principle involved. We know nothing but this, and the welfare of Africa, and honour of England as connected with it; and wherever and whenever one of those great principles which it has been our duty and glory to defend and vindicate, is or may be in our opinion violated in the person or property of any man on the West Coast, however vile or unworthy he may be, we shall as heretofore do battle in his behalf, as though he were our dearest friend and the most admirable of the human race.

---'}, {'id': 2197, 'article_title': 'NOTE ACCOMPANYING LAGOS LETTERS', 'full_section_title': 'NOTE ACCOMPANYING LAGOS LETTERS', 'last_edit_date': '03-06-1872', 'num_tokens': 0, 'language': 'en', 'block_type': 'text', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/23_04_1872#article-8', 'issue_date': '23_04_1872', 'content': 'Lagos, March 6, 1872.

My dear Sir,—Accept many and unfeigned thanks from the Africans for your kindness towards us. We read all your letters to the Earl Kimberley, and we are satisfied. It is for him to uphold the offices under his jurisdiction. It will go far to enlighten good people, and even the Government themselves. We trust those days of darkness are gone for ever when we could not reveal all oppressions and wrong and unjust dealings. The African Times has raised us from our low estate, and it is our duty to render all the assistance we possibly can. I fear we do not do all we ought in that respect.'}, {'id': 2265, 'article_title': 'Our Twelfth Year', 'full_section_title': 'Our Twelfth Year', 'last_edit_date': None, 'num_tokens': 0, 'language': 'en', 'block_type': 'text', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/23_07_1872#article-15', 'issue_date': '23_07_1872', 'content': "We have usually made a few special remarks with the beginning of each new year of *African Times'* existence. We see no reason why we should not continue to do so. God has this year blessed our efforts by making them visibly instrumental to great good. When we think of the arbitrary errors of a Salmon and a Glover—of what might have been the fate of the Fanti Confederation and its oppressed officials—what might have been the fate of the bulk of those connected with the trade and commerce of Lagos but for our persistent interference in their behalf,—we do indeed rejoice at having continued this work for the good of Africa and her people. We enter, therefore, on this our twelfth year, rich in hope, and not poor in joy. Not that our subscribers pay better than they did. Never have we received so little from them as during the past year; for, to the shame of but too many of them be it said, paying is the very last thing they would seem to think of. There are good and even noble exceptions; but these are, alas! very few. To them we tender our congratulation that they comprehend and appreciate our labours for African advancement, and their own duties and obligations. We want all their aid in every way. Every educated and God-loving African has weighty duties resting upon him. He has been brought out from the mass of heathen superstition and abasement, not through any effort of his own, but under the good providence of God, by the noble and disinterested efforts of others; and this, not only for his own present and eternal good, but that he may be an instrument of good to others, who yet remain entangled by the filth and ignorance of those fiendish idolatries, which have made Africa an object of so much compassionate grief to Christian people. And Christian enlightenment ought also to bring with it a love of country; stimulating to noble and patriotic efforts to do everything possible to free it from all that is evil and degrading. Our efforts in demanding better government for the West African Settlements, and the removal of abuses there, are directed only against such things; and no Christian African ought to allow himself to be seduced by paltry pecuniary or other yet more empty considerations, into becoming an abettor, defender, and supporter of them. God helping and strengthening us, we shall not relax in our efforts; and we hope, year by year, to have to welcome new and ardent fellow-workers among the Africans themselves, and to rejoice in new successes."}, {'id': 2321, 'article_title': 'Another Letter from Livingstone', 'full_section_title': 'Another Letter from Livingstone', 'last_edit_date': '08-28-1872', 'num_tokens': 0, 'language': 'en', 'block_type': 'text', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/23_10_1872#article-8', 'issue_date': '23_10_1872', 'content': 'Sir,—We cannot allow 1871 to pass away without expressing our gratefulness and high appreciation of the philanthropic feelings by which you are impelled to advocate the cause of Africa and her injured myriads from beneath the lash of official tyranny and oppression, and from the taunts, scoffs, and political venom of the negro-haters. When we review the history of our country from the time of the publication of that valuable journal of which you are the honoured editor—a periodical which stands eminent in consequence of the incalculable benefit it has conferred upon us—we say, when we contrast Africa's past with her present; when we look upon the many moral changes the African Times has effected, we could not but classify it amongst the means employed by Divine goodness towards the regeneration of a people who, according to the views of the anthropologist, are deprived of that vital essence which constitutes man the chief of God's creatures; hence with them the negro is calculated to be unfit for any other position than to become "a beast of burden and a beast for prey" to his more favoured brother. But the African Times has declared in the most forcible language that the negroes with the whites "are made of one blood," and are equally fitted to occupy the same position amongst the works of creation.

Not to enumerate its past achievements, the African Times, being animated with the most ardent zeal for our true interest, has contended with the Colonial-office in order to restore to Her Majesty African subjects that most inestimable benefit, which is the life of liberty, in the British Constitution, "trial by jury," which we cannot avoid lamenting. But in consequence of the credit attached in the Colonial-office to the representations of unprincipled officials, no hearing has been given to the reiterated'}, {'id': 2467, 'article_title': 'THE FANTI CONFEDERATION.', 'full_section_title': 'THE FANTI CONFEDERATION.', 'last_edit_date': None, 'num_tokens': 0, 'language': 'en', 'block_type': 'text', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/29_05_1873#article-14', 'issue_date': '29_05_1873', 'content': '

Now, without seeking to attach undue importance to indefinite official utterances, it cannot, we think, be denied that there is in this strong ground of hope that there will be a line of policy adopted, which shall either conform to, and be intended to carry out, the recommendation of the House of Commons Committee, or bring the whole territories under more direct and effective British rule. We say, without hesitation, that with or without an Ashanti invasion, such a result was inevitable, after the attention which we have drawn to the subject for years past, and especially since December, 1871, in our communications to Her Majesty's Government, in the press, and through our friends in Parliament. The situation had become disgracefully absurd, as well as unjust—such, in fact, as no Government having any pretensions to wisdom and equity, could continue to uphold in face of the damaging revelations which Mr. Acting-Administrator Salomon's crass official stupidity gave us an opportunity of making. The papers laid before Parliament are not all that we could have desired, though personally we have reason to be satisfied with them. No one who reads them can doubt for a single moment that it was we who made it impossible for Earl Kimberley to sanction, however he might endeavour on official grounds to extenuate, Mr. Salomon's insane proceedings. Earl Kimberley was able to read Mr. Salomon's officially untruthful and abused despatches in justification of his most indefensible proceedings, as regards the members of the Fanti confederation, and the not less fatuous and unstatesmanlike adoption of them by Sir Arthur Kennedy, in the clear light afforded by our letter to him of the 2nd January, 1871, and its enclosures. We have read very attentively Earl Kimberley's despatch of the 16th January. Earl Kimberley did not forward our letter of the 2nd and its enclosures to the Coast until one day later than the above, to go out by the same steamer on the 18th. The more we consider its contents (see page 133 of the present number of the African Times), the more firmly we are persuaded that Mr. Salomon was only saved from merited reprimand and recall by the stupid adoption of his views and his acts by his patron, Sir Arthur Kennedy. It would have been too much to ask that not only an Acting-Administrator, but a Governor-in-Chief also, should be disgraced for the sake of a people so poor and so dependent as the Fantis. Nevertheless, Mr. Salomon was not let off without serious expressions of disapproval, a full share of which, as the despatch was to Sir Arthur Kennedy, devolved incidentally upon him. Earl Kimberley regrets the arrests should have been made, and ordered what we had urged on his lordship to order—that the parties should be released from their bail, and that no proceedings whatever should be taken against them in the Assessor's Court. His lordship thinks that "the Administrator might have confined himself to issuing a proclamation warning British subjects from taking office under the Confederation until the articles had been approved by Her Majesty's Government, as Her Majesty's Government have no wish to discourage any legitimate efforts on the part of the Fanti kings and chiefs to establish for themselves an improved form of Government," &c., &c., &c. We pity Lord Kimberley in being fettered by official considerations from writing with the indignation he evidently felt, and from the expression of which he with difficulty restrained himself, which makes the excuses he admits for Mr. Salomon's conduct, and by implication for that of Sir Arthur Kennedy, perplexingly lame and inconclusive. We shall return again to these despatches, and the unwarrantable and unfounded assertions contained in those of Mr. Salomon and Sir Arthur Kennedy. Meanwhile, we think it our duty to ourselves to draw attention to the evidence which these papers afford of the inappreciable advantages derived from the African Times and its editor by the West Coast people—in this instance, the Fanti kings, chiefs, and nation, and the educated Africans who took part in and directed the national aspirations for an effective organization which should secure their country from the horrors of Ashanti invasion, and facilitate that development of its enormous natural resources, without which all other efforts to promote the civilization of its people would be futile. If ever there be a great Fanti united nation, educated, civilized, self-governed, rich, and happy—and we feel in our inmost soul that there will be such a nation—the African Times and its officially much-abused editor will, we venture to hope, be acknowledged as having greatly stimulated the national movement, and influenced the adoption by Her Majesty's Government of those measures, whatever they may be, which will have led to results so much to be desired.'}, {'id': 3308, 'article_title': 'THE POLICE OF LAGOS', 'full_section_title': 'THE POLICE OF LAGOS', 'last_edit_date': '01-18-1877', 'num_tokens': 0, 'language': 'en', 'block_type': 'text', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/01_03_1877#article-10', 'issue_date': '01_03_1877', 'content': 'Sir,—Just a few words about the Lagos Police, and the manner in which its operations are guided by the Government. This is a subject of great importance, especially when it is considered that it must be mainly owing to the exertions of a police, under judicious and well-defined regulations, that crimes can be brought to the notice of the authorities and punished. In the absence of such regulations, the name and office of police are mere mockeries. We deeply regret, then, to state that, literally speaking, there is not a single written rule for the guidance of the Lagos police. Some time in 1869 a few directions were put in writing by the then Superintendent, but it is believed these were mere private memoranda for his own guidance, for they were neither signed by him nor sanctioned by the then Administrator; consequently, the succeeding Superintendents have never been able safely to use them as official. Further, not even when peculiar exigencies in the colony need special rules for their treatment, do the police have these supplied to them. This state of things greatly hinders the efficient working of the police scheme in Lagos, and has many a time put matters in great confusion—e.g., when your October issue appeared with a letter condemning the apathy of the Lagos Government on the question of domestic slavery in Lagos, carried on under the Administrator's very nose, general orders were issued from Government House for the police to be on the alert to bring slave-dealers to justice. There being no special rule as to how this was to be done, or on what grounds the police were to apprehend people, or how they were to prosecute them, and nine-tenths of them being illiterate men, great confusion took place. The Administrator himself was at a loss how to manage to get certain arrested parties convicted, without incurring the displeasure of his friend and confidante, Chief (?) Taiwo; and the Acting Stipendiary Magistrate (Mr. C. D. Turton) and the Superintendent of Police were threatened by one Monsieur Callamand with a law-suit if they did not prove against him the charge of slave-dealing, for which he had been summoned to the Police-court. All these things prove the absolute necessity there exists for established rules to guide the police in their action; for, had there been such, his Excellency would have known at once how to have acted in the matter, instead of sending for remanded prisoners from the House of Correction, and assembling them before Chief (?) Taiwo, to tell them they were free. The Superintendent of Police, too, did not know what he was taking a summons against Callamand for; hence he narrowly escaped having a law-suit about his ears. Moreover, this state of things lessens the authority of the police, and renders nearly abortive their exertions to maintain ordinary peace; for when once the people of Lagos think that Taiwo's influence with Mr. Dumaresq is sufficient to free them from the hands of the police, there is no knowing what amount of mischief they will do. But for the African Times, we say,—but for your able leader in the November issue on the subject of Lagos slave-dealers, at this time there would be seen about in the streets of Lagos slave-dealers asking those they meet, "You want buy man?" You see, Mr. Editor, the good the African Times is doing here for us. We thank God for its existence; we hope, also, that you will long live (never despairing) to edit and issue the African Times, bringing to light those monstrous evils perpetrated about our coast.'}, {'id': 3796, 'article_title': 'THE REPRESENTATIVE FUND', 'full_section_title': 'THE REPRESENTATIVE FUND', 'last_edit_date': '03-10-1869', 'num_tokens': 0, 'language': 'en', 'block_type': 'text', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/01_05_1879#article-6', 'issue_date': '01_05_1879', 'content': 'After these nations, the young men cast a glance towards Adda and Awoonah countries, being the richest districts, although short of educated men who can feel and understand what ought to be done. These have means enough to match this speculation, if only the other nations who pretend to know something will begin, as an ensample for them. They lately fell under the British control, and are, by this time, as nursing-children. The Editor has, indeed, accomplished his duty as far as he can, in trying to bring under notice the havoc Captain Ellis, now Deputy-Sheriff at Accra, made with the poor Awoonahs, and which actions he did in virtue of their invulnerability—I mean the white officers'—as expressed by the Editor. Can this not pave the way to the belief of the black men that they are considered fools by the white men? How can a man, after having caused a great disturbance in a country, get, in lieu of degradation, the position of a Deputy-Sheriff? Surely, if this were to be done by a black man, he would be put in prison for his life long, or be hanged. Such is the civilization as brought to us by too many of the white men!

Then we turned to Lagos, being the East Province of the Gold Coast Colony, and richest of all the towns; and about it was asked again, "What is 300l. or 400l. to Lagos—a place where commerce has taken its deepest root, and which, by proper management, bids fair to become the Liverpool of Western Africa. Lagos has been blessed with rivers, and by these navigation is rendered very easy; and also riches can be attained with a few years' labour. Lagos alone can stand this amount, but will not, simply because the inhabitants are spendthrifts. Lagos ought to learn something out of the quarrel between the Ibadans and Egbas, on whom I can say the prosperity of this country depends on an uninterrupted security to be enjoyed for trading operations amongst and with both peoples. Lagos cannot be advantaged in any way by the destruction of either the Egbas or Ibadans. If Lagos will undertake this enterprise of rendering a monetary help to the Editor of the African Times, I hope and believe that he will succeed in arranging a basis of reconciliation and enduring friendship between these two countries, by referring to the Home Government. This is quite natural that the keynote of civilization, peace, and prosperity in those countries must be sounded from Lagos, and ere this be done, she must adopt a distinct policy for the purpose. I do not see any secure basis on which such policy can be founded and built up, but that a pecuniary assistance be, at all events, rendered to the Editor of the African Times, who will employ his energies in bringing these furious disturbances under Her Majesty's notice.'}, {'id': 4572, 'article_title': 'FRENCH CLAIMS ON MADAGASCAR. A COVERT SLAVE-TRADE.', 'full_section_title': 'FRENCH CLAIMS ON MADAGASCAR. A COVERT SLAVE-TRADE.', 'last_edit_date': None, 'num_tokens': 0, 'language': 'en', 'block_type': 'text', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/01_02_1883#article-14', 'issue_date': '01_02_1883', 'content': 'We have reason to believe that this denunciation of ours came under the notice of our anti-slavery friends in France; and to-day, the 30th January, we have the gratification of finding the following as a sub-leader in the Daily News: "There seems to be little doubt that the activity of the French authorities on the East Coast of Africa at the present time is largely due to the determination of the planters of Réunion to obtain a supply of African labour, which would render them independent alike of the creole population of that island and of coolie immigration from India. The testimony on this subject is so strong as to be absolutely conclusive. The facts, indeed, are not denied by the French Government, who will probably contend that what the planters require is simply the organization of free African labour on the indentureship system. Experience in Réunion has shown that it is impossible to secure adequate protection to imported labourers, even when the British Government, acting diplomatically as well as through its resident agents, did its best to induce the local authorities to see that justice was done. But even if the Administration in Réunion could be trusted, it would be impossible so to control the so-called immigration from Africa as to prevent it from becoming a branch of the slave-trade. Africa does not suffer from pressure of population, and there is no natural desire on the part of the people to emigrate to distant countries. At the same time, if the French determine to introduce African engagés into Réunion, the supply of labourers is certain to be equal to the demand, but this will only be by the unscrupulous action of slave-traders eager for a new and profitable market. It is said that large numbers of Sakalavas have been taken to Réunion from the North-west coast of Madagascar, but that, although a good deal has been said as to the voluntary nature of the contracts and the limited period during which the engaged labourers were to be absent from their homes, not one of them has ever been known to return. There is reason to believe that the recent proceedings of the French in Madagascar are attributable not so much to a restless spirit of aggression on the part of the French Government as to the intrigues of colonial planters, who think that under cover of the national flag they may draw a perennial supply of servile labour from the western coast of the great African island. It is satisfactory to learn that the attention of the anti-slavery party in France is being directed to this subject, and that they have resolved strenuously to oppose the revival of a system which, if sanctioned by the Government, cannot fail to bring discredit upon the Republic." We have thought it right to call attention to this matter because some of our friends thought we should be justified, by late severe indisposition, in discontinuing the publication of The African Times. But there is clearly work for it yet to do for God and humanity.'}, {'id': 4807, 'article_title': 'THE LATE MR. F. FITZ-GERALD.', 'full_section_title': 'THE LATE MR. F. FITZ-GERALD.', 'last_edit_date': '03-01-1884', 'num_tokens': 0, 'language': 'en', 'block_type': 'text', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/01_03_1884#article-7', 'issue_date': '01_03_1884', 'content': '"On the 22nd February, at Avenue Trocadero, Paris, Ferdinand FitzGerald, of St. Mary Cray, aged 77."

This announcement, which appeared in the *Times* of Monday, February 26th, will have conveyed to his many friends the intelligence of their loss in the death of Mr. FitzGerald, the founder and conductor for so many years of the *African Times*. He had been in failing health for some months, and his physicians had advised entire change of air and scene as the only chance of restoring a constitution naturally strong, but which increasing age and constant effort in the service of others had rendered feeble. He had resided in Paris for some months, but without any permanent restoration to health, and on Friday morning, the 22nd ult., he passed peacefully away. He had devoted his whole life to the service of Africa, having, in addition to his connexion with the *African Times*—in which he always espoused the cause of the weak against the strong—been for many years the Secretary of the African Aid Society—a society to which the deepest gratitude of Africa is due.

He has now gone to his reward.'}, {'id': 4829, 'article_title': 'Representation in Council on the Gold Coast and Lagos, West Africa', 'full_section_title': 'Representation in Council on the Gold Coast and Lagos, West Africa', 'last_edit_date': '02-14-1884', 'num_tokens': 0, 'language': 'en', 'block_type': 'text', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/01_04_1884#article-14', 'issue_date': '01_04_1884', 'content': 'Should Lord Derby acquiesce in the separation of the two Governments, it is necessary that the Governor to be appointed must be a gentleman, free from passion for war. Knowing that Lagos is an island, and possessed superior and civilized materials for destruction, no native army from the interior or in the neighbourhood thereof can ever attempt to invade her, as, from experience, we know that for every trivial matter we are fond of thrashing the natives, and, therefore, because we are strong; for it has been proved beyond doubt that when we were independent, some of our Executive were very fond of making or creating little unnecessary wars, exhibiting powers, &c., which led to Lagos being placed under Sierra Leone in 1866, to check the ambition of the local Executive. The authority to strike the blow should be in the hands of the Secretary of State, after due and faithful reports. The Governor should be above prejudice, as, from experience, we know it was this that favoured and promoted tribal feelings and jealousies from 1865, one tribe claiming to be the mouthpiece, adviser, and in the confidence of the Governor. The Governor should be above favouritism, as, from experience, it was this that led a special native trader, a favourite of the Executive, to go to the Ogun river with armed force, and there against the interests of all merchants and traders, forcibly seize all produce belonging to several innocent persons, in satisfaction of debt due to him by the Egbas; which policy the then Executive encouraged, sanctioned, and favoured, and the Colonial Secretary dissented from, and for which he was tried in Council, and suspended, to please a favourite political intriguer. The Governor should discourage all gossiping and tale-bearing gentlemen (professedly) and others, who, taking advantage of gaining the Executive ears, injure innocent officials, and, without a proper hearing, dismissing them, to please Mr. So-and-so. Consequently the power of dismissal should be in the hands of the Secretary of State. The Governor should permit every Member of Council to express his opinion independently, and not to please him or simply concur, otherwise to mark him out for ruin. And, in appointing Members of Legislative Council, natives should be appointed as well as Europeans; as we gather from the reply of Lord Derby that he seems to have ignored the right of the natives of the soil to have a voice in the administration of the affairs of the Settlement. Is it wrong for us to ask whether the authorities at the Colonial Office do not read the *African Times* of London from time to time? Have we any better advocates than her? She is acquainted with all our wants and desires.'}]

[{'document_title': 'OUR FIFTH VOLUME', 'section_title': '', 'content': 'In changing the form of our Journal, and adopting that in which it now appears, we have deferred to the oft-expressed wishes of many of our earliest and most constant friends. The African Times now occupies an acknowledged position as the registrar and exponent of native wants and progress, and the advocate of native interests, more especially on the West Coast. Our aim in the future will ever be, as it has been in the past, to make it practically useful; and we again solicit the support of all who have at heart the real welfare of native Africa and its people, both for this Journal and for the Society by which it was founded, and to whose efforts with Government and individuals so much of its power for good may be attributed. And more especially do we commend the African Times and the African-Aid Society to the warm and earnest support of the educated Africans of the West Coast. The African Times brings them, as well as their rulers, face to face with British public opinion, by which they have much to gain in the work to which we hope they all feel themselves pledged—viz., that of the Christian civilization of the whole African people, and the industrial development of those great natural resources with which Africa has been so liberally endowed.', 'last_edit_date': '1865-07-22', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/22_07_1865#article-10', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.726, 'probability_score': 0.067, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'Transported and Imprisoned Kings', 'section_title': '', 'content': 'The most sacred portion of the duty of a free press is to strive to remedy injustice and wrong. We have throughout our editorial career earnestly endeavoured to perform this duty—not with so much success as we could have desired. Government servants, from the highest to the lowest, in Crown Colonies form a serried phalanx that it is difficult for any assailant to penetrate. There is an _esprit de corps_, from the lowest grade of European Crown Colony officials up to and including Downing-street, that has made it almost a superhuman task to procure redress for a wrong committed by the Executive of a Crown Colony. We have had but too much experience of this, our rebuffs having been such that nothing but a full conviction of our being right could have prevented our writing ourselves down as assininely incompetent to distinguish between good and evil, between right and wrong, between even-handed justice and flagrant oppression. Such has been the past in our editorial career. We fancy that we now see a gleam of light justifying in us a hope of better things to come. Some changes that have taken place at the Gambia, attributed to our efforts, are encouraging, as evidencing that the ear and judgment of the present Chief of the Colonial Office, the Earl of Kimberley, are not entirely monopolized by officialism; and in ruminating on the letter which we inserted in our last number, headed "The African Kings Transported by the late Governor Ussher," we have ventured to indulge the hope that if the noble Secretary of State for the Colonies will only admit that the decisions and acts of the Governors of Crown Colonies are not infallible, we may yet obtain some atonement for injustice to some deeply injured persons. With this hope, and the ideas that have sprung from it, we give insertion in our present number to two other letters from Accra bearing on the same subject, of the gross injustice done to the Kings Tackie and Assafo Ajaye, and the deep national disgrace involved in it; for an oppression of the weak and helpless is a deep national disgrace. As such, it touches us nearly, and incites us to persistent action, seeing that we have now in office in England a Government bold and courageous in the cause of right, as evidenced in what they have recently done in the matter of the Transvaal, which no one in his senses could doubt the power of Great Britain to subdue and retain had she so determined. And as we have some faith in the equity of the present Home Government, so have we also in that of the new Governor-in-Chief of the Gold Coast Colony, Sir Samuel Rowe. We hope he will feel that he has nothing to do with the acts of his predecessors, and is not at all bound to uphold them where they were wrong, but, on the contrary, as having the honour of Great Britain in his hands, is bound, in duty to himself and to his country, to remove for the latter the stigma that attaches to her in the minds of thoughtful, impartial men, not only as regards the treatment of Kings Tackie and Assafo Ajaye, but also as regards that of King Ennemil Quow, of Wassaw, on whose behalf we in vain sent in our remonstrances to Downing-street during the Colonial Secretaryship of Sir M. We are not about to praise ourselves for anything that we have done in this work which God has committed to us. Do what we may in His cause, we must still be "unprofitable servants." The last it need not absolutely cost us, if all our subscribers in Africa would pay as they all ought to do, and as some do. But as we dare not withdraw our hand from the plough while God gives us in any way strength to hold it, we have decided to wait and see what another year of labour and anxiety will bring forth. hh: The increasing interest in publications and narratives about African exploration reflects a growing European and Sierra Leonean curiosity and engagement with African cultures and politics.
result: The observations from both the General History of Africa textbook and The African Times news articles collectively support the claim of increasing interest in publications and narratives about African exploration, reflecting a growing European and Sierra Leonean curiosity and engagement with African cultures and politics. The General History of Africa highlights the nineteenth-century surge in European interest driven by exploration, abolitionist movements, and missionary activities, with explorers, traders, and missionaries documenting their findings in publications that reveal a curiosity about Africa's geographical features, cultures, and political structures. It also notes an intellectual revolution in West Africa, particularly in Sierra Leone, where a dynamic Creole culture emerged, contributing to missionary and intellectual activities, suggesting a parallel increase in Sierra Leonean engagement with African cultures and politics. However, it does not explicitly link Sierra Leonean curiosity to publications and narratives about African exploration. Similarly, The African Times articles discuss the publication and discussion of works like "Wanderings in Western Africa" and Dr. Schweinfurth's volumes, highlighting European nations' exploration and annexation activities, and the recognition of explorers by institutions like the Royal Geographical Society. These articles also note Sierra Leone's interest in resource development and the spread of civilization, indicating local curiosity and involvement in African affairs, though they do not specifically mention Sierra Leonean publications. Together, these sources illustrate a growing European interest in African exploration and a Sierra Leonean engagement with African development, albeit without direct references to Sierra Leonean publications.

[{'id': 252, 'article_title': 'General Observations', 'full_section_title': 'General Observations', 'last_edit_date': None, 'num_tokens': 0, 'language': 'en', 'block_type': 'text', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/23_11_1863#article-18', 'issue_date': '23_11_1863', 'content': 'THERE is likely to be great suffering from drought on the Gold Coast. The rainfall during the wet season, which is now over, has been smaller than known for many years. The gross neglect of the British Government in not making the effort to obtain water by boring at Cape Coast—neglect which we denounced two years ago—may be the cause of fatal disasters there in this otherwise unusually healthy season.

Captain Burton, who is charged with a mission to Dahomey, not being at Lagos when the mail from England arrived there with the presents sent from England by Her Majesty's Government for the King, a steamer was sent down to the Bight to bring him up, and convey him, with the presents, to Whydah. We wait the intelligence of his arrival there with great interest, as our readers will remember that he has instructions not to go up to the capital, unless he receives a promise that there shall be no human sacrifices during his stay there.

We have accounts of additions to the mass of misery shipped off the Dahoman coast for Cuba. 1,200 slaves have been got off safely from Popo.

Our readers will perceive that there is promise of great progress at Sierra Leone.

---

The merchants trading between London and Lagos seem to be unanimous in their condemnation of the Government, in allowing Mr. Stanhope Freeman to resume the duties of Governor of Lagos.

The privilege of prepaying letters, &c., by postage stamps is loudly called for, and with reason, by the Gold Coast people. And Lagos, although now two years a British colony, remains without colonial postage privileges.

Porto Novo, under French direction, is working great damage to the trade of Lagos, now burdened with duties, from which that of Porto Novo is exempt.

It is believed that the Ashantees will soon resume the offensive and recross the Praah.

African coffee realised lately the highest price of the day in Mincing-lane—78s. per cwt. for 150 bags.

"Wanderings in Western Africa," by an F.R.G.S., is much spoken of. We hope to review it in our next.

The daily press, in August last, was prolific in letters and papers on Dahomey and Ashantee, among which the letters of "An African" in the Times were conspicuous. We thought our real African friends would demolish such fables. We think it will be admitted that the letter of "Tom Coffee" in this number has done so most effectually.

The Government of Lagos is not in future to have a consulate attached to it, as heretofore. The Governor will be Governor of Lagos, and nothing more.

We hear that the West African Company have purchased the small steamboat made some years since for the King of Calabar, and that she is to navigate the Cradu waters and Lagos River as a passenger boat. We think she may be very useful to the colony in that capacity.

The value of export produce, chiefly cotton and palm oil, shut up in Abeokuta, is estimated at from sixty to eighty thousand pounds.'}, {'id': 372, 'article_title': 'Lagos', 'full_section_title': 'Lagos', 'last_edit_date': '05-08-1864', 'num_tokens': 0, 'language': 'en', 'block_type': 'text', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/23_06_1864#article-10', 'issue_date': '23_06_1864', 'content': 'Sir,—I am sorry to have to report to you that the visit of Governor Freeman to Abeokuta has been postponed, the Bashorun, &c., of that place having gone to the camp at Makun, as the Ibadan had been making some demonstrations. His Excellency is still anxious for an interview with the Egba magnates, and has offered to go to the camp or to Abeokuta, whichever they prefer. We hope and believe that this interview, whenever it does come off, will result in peace and the re-opening of the roads; but "hope deferred maketh the heart sick," and none have experienced the truth of the proverb more fully than the Lagos merchants have done of late.

The work of Captain Burton on Abeokuta, and "Wanderings in West Africa," by an F.R.G.S., are creating some sensation, especially amongst the Sierra Leone people and others.

The French are anxious to introduce a man-of-war steamer into the Lagoon, for service at Porto Novo, &c. Knowing how exclusive France is in her colonies, it is to be hoped that the Home Government will never sanction such a proceeding.*

The Commodore has lately been off the port, but held no communication with the authorities. It would not surprise those who know him to learn that his object in coming was to send letters to Abeokuta, as he has rather a fondness for that place and its inhabitants. Several of our Sierra Leone traders are now in Abeokuta, probably exercising their talents as amateur diplomatists.

Mr. R. B. N. Walker, agent to the West African Company, is also at present in Abeokuta, on business connected with the undertaking. This company has recently lost by death a clerk and an engineer at Lagos—which has been very sickly—no less than eight Europeans having died since the commencement of the year, of dysentery, &c. The Governor has lately been to Badagry. During his absence an affair occurred, through the officious and arbitrary conduct of the police magistrate, which might have had serious consequences. This official took upon himself to imprison a number of chiefs because they would not—i.e., could not—force their people to make Calabar mats, now extensively employed here in lieu of the old country thatch. This very just and politic act naturally caused a considerable disturbance, and might have ended in a dangerous émeute, had the police magistrate not released his prisoners in time.

We are expecting Commander Glover out again by next mail. He will be most heartily welcomed by all the European portion of the community at least. May he remain many years among us!

The King of Dahomey is ransoming his people who were made prisoners on the occasion of his defeat at Abeokuta as fast as he can, and declares that he will attack Abeokuta early next year. This is probably an empty threat, but there is no knowing what wounded pride and vanity may urge him to do. Quos Deus vult perdere, prius dementat. He will never succeed in entering the walls of the Egba capital.'}, {'id': 5096, 'article_title': 'AFRICAN NOTES', 'full_section_title': 'AFRICAN NOTES', 'last_edit_date': None, 'num_tokens': 0, 'language': 'en', 'block_type': 'text', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/01_05_1885#article-8', 'issue_date': '01_05_1885', 'content': 'The total amount of the guarantee fund for the forthcoming Colonial and Indian Exhibition is now £152,950, and there is no doubt that a quarter of a million will be easily subscribed by the end of the year. Many of the firms connected with this enterprise have contributed sums of £1,000.

Messrs. Dean & Son intend issuing a reprint of Mr. Du Val's "With a Show through Southern Africa," which has been such a success, the first edition being sold out in a few weeks from the date of issue. Mr. Du Val intends to visit India next winter, where he will give his popular and clever entertainment, entitled "Odds and Ends."

It has been notified to Sir Baker Russell, whose regiment is now in South Africa, that in the event of war on the Afghan frontier, the command of the cavalry in the field will be confided to him, with Colonel Luck as his second in command.

The Royal Geographical Society will present their Royal Medal to Mr. Joseph Thomson at the anniversary meeting next month, in recognition of his services in carrying out the two expeditions into East Central Africa with which he was charged by the society, with such zeal, promptitude, and success. One will also be presented to Mr. Consul H. E. O'Neill for his explorations along the coast, and in the interior of Mozambique.

The report of the Kimberley Waterworks Company, to be submitted at the forthcoming annual meeting, shows that after writing off £4,200 from different accounts, there is an available balance of £16,724, out of which it is proposed to pay a dividend of 6 per cent. This will absorb £14,700, and leave £2,024 to be carried forward. The return of the quantity of water sold in 1884 gives a total of 100,285,218 gallons, as compared with 50,546,150 gallons in 1883.

The communications with regard to the Madagascar Mails, respecting which one or two questions have been asked in the House, have not yet reached the Government. They are, however, expected shortly.

Replying to Sir M. H. Beach, Mr. Ashley, the Under Secretary of State for the Colonies, stated in the House, on the 23rd ult., that the Colonial Office had not received any telegraphic communication from Sir Charles Warren since the 9th of April. He could not help thinking that this long silence indicated that the relations between the High Commissioner and Sir C. Warren continued to be cordial and satisfactory. The Government had had no report yet from Sir C. Warren as to the progress of the Bechuanaland Expedition up to this time. Up to the end of March he seemed to have been busily engaged in defining the frontier.'}]

[{'document_title': 'MR. JOSEPH THOMSON ON EUROPEAN INTERCOURSE WITH AFRICA.', 'section_title': '', 'content': 'Mr. Joseph Thomson, the African explorer, lectured at Edinburgh, on January 11, on "The result to the African of European intercourse." There was a large attendance.

The Lecturer, after observing that one of the most remarkable features of the century had been the phenomenal interest displayed in all things African, and that people's imaginations had been touched by the varied story of the Dark Continent, drew attention to the apparently unselfish form of the public interest manifested in Africa. The very atmosphere was electric with the most wonderful schemes—religious, philanthropic, and commercial—for the exclusive benefit of the negro. From platform and pulpit rose a clamour of voices, in which was heard the popular watchwords of the day—civilisation, progress, the good of the negro, legitimate commerce, conversion of the heathen, and other high-sounding phrases, all having relation to the good things to be done for the African. The company-promoter freely sprinkled his prospectuses or his conversation with glowing accounts of the great benefits which the African was to derive from intercourse with Europe. They were told to picture as the result the negro clothed and in his right mind, alternately sitting at the feet of the missionary and the trader, learning from the one the truths of a higher and better life, and from the other acquiring the arts of civilisation. They never heard now of the trader who went to Africa with the merely selfish object of making his fortune. Each and all became pioneers of civilisation, thinking only of the native first and self afterwards. They spoke as if the good to the native had been enormous, and that their intercourse with him had been a benefit and blessing. They pointed with pride to their sacrifices in the suppression of the slave trade, to their West Coast settlements as centres of secular light and leading; to their missionary stations as stars twinkling in the night of heathendom; to the returns of their trade with every entrance to the heart of Africa, as showing the spread of their beneficial influence. They saw that the work of other nations had been pernicious in the extreme, that they had been brutal in their dealings with native races, and had thought only of their own sordid interests and national aggrandisement—all in marked contrast to their aims and methods.', 'last_edit_date': '1890-01-11', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/01_02_1890#article-3', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.677, 'probability_score': 0.067, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'THE "COMING" CONTINENT.', 'section_title': '', 'content': 'In an article, entitled "Africa for Africans," published in a magazine issued in Washington, U.S.A., the vast possibilities of progress and development possessed by this continent are so eloquently and aptly set forth that we quote the passage *in extenso*:

"Africa is to-day the object of more interest on the part of a larger number of people than any other quarter of the globe. England, France, Portugal, Germany, and Italy are attempting to obtain titles to the country. England has made annexation of the coast lying adjacent to her colony of Sierra Leone; France is forcing her way on the Senegal and toward the head-waters of the Niger; she threatens to annex the coast from the Gaboon to the Congo, some 250 miles, and is running her lines on the Upper Congo. Her Chamber of Deputies has granted the De Brazza mission, by a vote of 449 to 3, a credit of a million and a quarter of francs. The Portuguese Government has appointed explorers and examined the Congo country, and assumes to exercise control over all the territory at the mouth of the Congo. The German Reichstag has increased its annual appropriation for the exploration of Africa. Italy has despatched a party to Abyssinia for geographical and mercantile purposes. She has also concluded treaties which promise to make Assab a centre of commerce. The Sultan of Morocco has authorized Spain to take possession of Santa Cruz del Mar, and the Sultan of Zanzibar has purchased six superior steamers to constitute a regular coast service, in the interest of commerce and for the suppression of the slave-trade. The International African Association, which owes its origin to the philanthropic initiative of Leopold II., King of the Belgians, has received large subscriptions and pushed forward exploring expeditions to start and equip the line of hospitable and scientific stations which are to bound the East and West Coast, and form a civilizing girdle around Central Africa. And the results following the explorations of Livingstone and Stanley and De Brazza are attracting the attention of the civilized world. What was a 'Dark Continent,' by the indomitable energy of these explorers, seems likely to prove the richest quarter of the globe. Not only does the land produce, with slight persuasion of tillage, admirable crops of cotton and coffee, but the soil is rich in diamonds on its southern coast, and in iron on its northern. Captain Burton has asserted that he knows nothing to equal the prodigious wealth of the land, even in California, or in the Brazils. 'Gold dust is panned by native women from the sands of the sea shore. Gold spangles glitter after showers in the streets of Axím. Gold is yielded by the lumps of yellow swish that rivet the wattle walls of hut and hovel.'"', 'last_edit_date': '1884-08-01', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/01_08_1884#article-11', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.702, 'probability_score': 0.069, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'Review', 'section_title': '', 'content': 'realize living among them; we become, as it were, bosom companions with the worthy Doctor; we gaze with him upon the skulls of the victims of cannibalism whose coveted flesh cost them their lives; we share all his trials and disappointments, which he never parades unnecessarily, and rejoice with him in all his discoveries and successes. He is an admirable draughtsman; nor are his word pictures inferior to those traced by his pencil. It would be little less than absurd for us at present to make extracts (with the small available space which our journal offers) from two volumes, each of between five and six hundred pages, although we purpose doing so from time to time. Our friends know that we do not praise books lightly. We praise these. Our earnest recommendation to all our readers—for they are all, of course, interested in that vast Africa which so much occupies our thoughts—our earnest recommendation is, buy these books, and read them. An African library cannot be complete without them. Dr. Schweinfurth must henceforth occupy the very highest rank among scientific African explorers. Nor is it only to our readers that we feel bound to give advice consequent on the perusal of these volumes. Dr. Schweinfurth is an almost unique African traveller, both as regards his natural and his acquired gifts. He seems to be impervious to African fever. He knows how to obtain the sympathy, respect, and friendship of the people among whom he is thrown; he possesses many qualifications which insure him a welcome everywhere; he is an acute and diligent observer, and knows thoroughly how to place before others what he himself sees, hears, reasons, and feels. Every man who has been in the African vortex seems to long to plunge himself again within it. It has a fascination for him, which he cannot resist. We presume Dr. Schweinfurth is not an exception to this; and believing this, we think it a duty incumbent on the European learned societies—English, French, German, and Italian—by a munificent combined effort (in which we should scarcely think the Governments of their respective countries would hesitate to assist) to dispatch Dr. Schweinfurth once again to the Monbuttoo country, so well furnished that he may be able to continue his course until he arrives at some one of the European settlements on the West Coast of Africa, where we should expect him by the Niger or the Congo. If willing and fit for fresh exertions, it is a disgrace to the scientific and Christian world of the nineteenth century, that Dr. Schweinfurth should remain any longer time unemployed in the great work of African discovery.', 'last_edit_date': '1874-11-30', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/30_11_1874#article-18', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.659, 'probability_score': 0.066, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'SIERRA LEONE', 'section_title': '', 'content': 'SIERRA LEONE seems naturally destined to exercise so much influence in the spread of civilization through the countries of the West Coast of Africa, that the questions connected with the

hh: Western media and historical narratives have often misrepresented African political systems and leaders due to biased, inaccurate, or fabricated accounts by outsiders.
result: The "General History of Africa" textbook and The African Times news articles both provide compelling evidence supporting the claim that Western media and historical narratives have often misrepresented African political systems and leaders due to biased, inaccurate, or fabricated accounts by outsiders. The textbook highlights the prejudices and cultural chauvinism of European historians and colonialists, who frequently dismissed African cultures and political systems as stagnant or non-existent. Notably, figures like Professor A. P. Newton and Sir Reginald Coupland are cited for claiming that Africa had no history before European intervention, reflecting a dismissive attitude towards African political systems. Additionally, colonial apologists often portrayed African resistance as irrational and driven by superstition, further misrepresenting African leaders and their political motivations. The textbook also discusses how colonialism simplified and distorted Africa's political map, ignoring pre-existing political and economic zones in favor of arbitrary colonial boundaries. Similarly, The African Times articles highlight instances where information about African societies, such as the role of the "Ocrah" in Ashanti society, is described as "absolutely and essentially false," attributed to ignorance or deliberate fabrication by outsiders. The articles criticize those who write about African societies without personal experience or reliable sources, suggesting their accounts are based on hearsay or low-quality information. They also mention the misrepresentation of events, such as alleged human sacrifices in Ashantee and Dahomey, and the exaggeration of military encounters, like the supposed defeat of the Fantis by the Ashantis. However, The African Times also highlights efforts to correct these misrepresentations by providing counter-narratives and testimonies from individuals with firsthand experience, indicating a pushback against such biased portrayals. Together, these sources illustrate how Western narratives have historically misrepresented African political systems and leaders, while also acknowledging the presence of voices attempting to rectify these inaccuracies.

[{'id': 259, 'article_title': 'The Friend to the King of Dahomey', 'full_section_title': 'The Friend to the King of Dahomey', 'last_edit_date': '10-14-1863', 'num_tokens': 0, 'language': 'en', 'block_type': 'text', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/23_11_1863#article-25', 'issue_date': '23_11_1863', 'content': 'Again, he says: "By the side of every African king sits a counsellor, who is called the Ocrah. This officer is the soul, then, or most confidential adviser, friend, and companion of the king. He receives all the thoughts and wishes of the king. What is scrupulously concealed from others is revealed to him." Every word of this is absolutely and essentially false. Never was a writer more profoundly ignorant of his subject. It is almost beyond belief how any individual out of the precincts of a lunatic asylum could take up his pen and deliberately scribble off for publication in a respectable journal—in THE most respectable journal in the world—as genuine facts, what he is perfectly conscious are merely counterfeit facts, manufactured on his own premises. The *Times* ought to resent this insult by exposing him. It is no excuse for this person that he received his information from his cook or his butler. An individual who holds a high and responsible office under the Government of one of Her Majesty's foreign possessions, should be more than usually careful to ascertain that the assertions which he is about to put forth to the world in black and white, so that they cannot be recalled, are of that truthful nature that nothing could upset them. If this letter can be satisfactorily traced to the one suspected of being its author, then it will behove his Grace the Secretary of State for the Colonies to be very careful with regard to the official reports he receives from Cape Coast.

The truth respecting the "Ocrah" is this: An Ocrah is a domestic slave, generally a purchased slave, who, by good conduct, has acquired the confidence of his master or of her mistress. There are male Ocrahs, and there are also female Ocrahs, the latter more properly called Crabahs. They are to be found, not only in the palaces of kings, but in the household of anybody and everybody who is wealthy enough or foolish enough to purchase a slave for the purpose. The Ocrah may sometimes be the friend of his master, and the Crabah of her mistress, but is not by any means necessarily so. The probability is, that he does possess the confidence of his master, and she of her mistress, for neither would have been selected had they not evinced, whilst young, unusual capabilities for the performance of the ordinary domestic duties attached to their office. The number of Ocrahs and Crabahs in one household vary according to the wealth or the folly of the master or mistress. The King of Ashantee has in his establishment a staff of upwards of forty Ocrahs, the chief of whom is a fat eunuch, "Ocrah Cherry" by name.

Perhaps "An African" will be good enough to inform us to which of them he refers when he talks of the Ocrah, the soul, counsellor, officer, adviser, friend, and companion of his "old correspondent," Quaku Duah; or does he wish his audience to infer that these forty "souls" form a kind of privy council, without whose advice and consent the king dare not act?'}, {'id': 259, 'article_title': 'The Friend to the King of Dahomey', 'full_section_title': 'The Friend to the King of Dahomey', 'last_edit_date': '10-14-1863', 'num_tokens': 0, 'language': 'en', 'block_type': 'text', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/23_11_1863#article-25', 'issue_date': '23_11_1863', 'content': 'I cannot close this letter without mentioning at least one circumstance regarding the late King of Dahomey, which was related to me on two different occasions by two trustworthy individuals who had visited Dahomey half-a-dozen times, and were great allies with the King. One was a celebrated slavetrader, now dead; the other an equally well-known native merchant. The King of Dahomey, on a certain occasion, expressed a curiosity to ascertain the exact appearance presented by an infant whilst in the womb, and in order to gratify that diabolical curiosity, this religious monarch ordered one of his female subjects who was in an advanced state of pregnancy to be brought before him. I cannot write what followed, as it would be too disgusting; but suffice it to say, that the King, having satisfied his curiosity, exclaimed, "Is that all?" There are those still living that can corroborate this. Now, I should say that one whose religion would not deter him from committing a crime which I believe to be unparalleled would not hesitate to order the slaughter of any number of his helpless dependents. Everybody knows that he often does so, and every honest man who knows it will also candidly admit it.

I have now a very few words more to add. I would respectfully caution the British public from attaching too much importance or faith to the tales of writers who, like "An African," have had no personal experience of the men or things they enlarge upon, and whose knowledge thereof is derived from fifth-rate sources. Government officials who come out to the Gold Coast for a couple of years or less, who seldom move outside the Castle at Cape Coast, and who glean their information on all they intend to write about from their boys or from ignorant people of the lowest class (who just "look in" to get a glass of the white newsmonger's gin), cannot be expected to furnish the public with literary food of a healthy quality. So far as actual experience of matters goes, King Badahung is just as competent to put forth an opinion respecting the existing disputes between the Poles and Russians, or between the Northern and Southern States of America, as his "friend," "An African," is to undertake the task he has attempted.

This individual (always supposing his identity to be established beyond dispute, which, in point of fact, it is) very recently wrote to a friend of his at Cape Coast to announce his impending return to his post in almost these words: "I am returning, not because I am obliged, or because I have any affection for the place, but I have a game to play, and, by Jove, I'll come and play it out too, in spite of all obstacles." No doubt this letter is his first card. The second, I strongly suspect, will be to endeavour to oust from office, through intrigue, one who is the only bar to the well-known object of his ambition; but unless the remaining cards are higher, and much better played, the probability is he will find himself loo'd to a heavy amount.'}, {'id': 259, 'article_title': 'The Friend to the King of Dahomey', 'full_section_title': 'The Friend to the King of Dahomey', 'last_edit_date': '10-14-1863', 'num_tokens': 0, 'language': 'en', 'block_type': 'text', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/23_11_1863#article-25', 'issue_date': '23_11_1863', 'content': 'I have finished, Mr. Editor, and have to request you will be good enough to give this letter the utmost publicity, and every possible chance of being perused by those who may have been taken in by the false African.—I am, &c.,'}, {'id': 310, 'article_title': "THE KING OF DAHOMEY'S FRIEND", 'full_section_title': "THE KING OF DAHOMEY'S FRIEND", 'last_edit_date': '11-14-1863', 'num_tokens': 0, 'language': 'en', 'block_type': 'text', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/23_01_1864#article-25', 'issue_date': '23_01_1864', 'content': 'Sir,—On the 14th of last month I wrote you relative to a letter in the _Times_ of 21st August, which furnished the public with a mass of manufactured information regarding human sacrifices in Ashantee and Dahomey.

There was no English newspaper then here of a later date than the 23rd August. I have since seen the _Times_ of September 1, which contained the letter of the Rev. Charles Hilliard, Wesleyan minister, formerly on this Coast, and well known to most of us, on the subject that "An African" had half drowned himself in some ten days before.

When speaking in my letter of two Wesleyan missionaries being present during the several interviews between Quaku Duah and the late Sir William Winniett, I was not ignorant of the fact that the Rev. Mr. Hilliard also was an eyewitness, as well as the Revs. T. B. Freeman and T. Laing; but not being certain as to his being still alive, I did not cite him as one of my evidences to dispose of the wild and romantic tales which "An African" had cooked up for ignorant lovers of the marvellous.

Permit me to call your attention to Mr. Charles Hilliard's important testimony in that number of the leading journal to which I have referred above. You will there perceive in how many points he supports my most important charges against "An African." Mr. Hilliard's calling as a minister of the Gospel, doubtless, prevented him giving denial in more emphatic and unmistakable language to the inventions of "An African," and induced him to observe, in allusion to the "epaulet" affair, that such a conversation had "escaped his memory." This, though kindhearted on the part of Mr. Hilliard, was a courtesy which "An African," by his bungling and inane attempt to ridicule the reverend gentleman's counterstatements, proved he was utterly undeserving of.

There is only one part of Mr. Hilliard's epistle which I cannot coincide with—that is, where he states that there cannot be a moment's doubt that "An African" writes from "experience" and "ocular testimony," because we who know who the so self-styled "African" is know better.—Yours,'}, {'id': 2666, 'article_title': 'Cape Coast', 'full_section_title': 'Cape Coast', 'last_edit_date': '12-16-1873', 'num_tokens': 0, 'language': 'en', 'block_type': 'text', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/29_01_1874#article-19', 'issue_date': '29_01_1874', 'content': '

It appears that a certain class of people make it their hobby to ridicule us, and to exhibit us in any but our true colours. I see that one gentleman has been writing to one of your contemporaries, that Anfoo Otoo, the King of Abrah, was the first to bring down the news of his own defeat at Doonquah (when and where this occurred we do not know, excepting that it happened in some locality where the fertile and imaginative intellect of this person alone was present), in which he (Anfoo Otoo) was materially aided by his “length of limb.” Now, there is as much of truth in this assertion as if I were to tell you that the King of Ashanti was made of gold, instead of being flesh and blood, as all other ordinary mortals. It is becoming too much the fashion to run down us poor Fantees; and if those gentlemen who are so prone to indulge their fancies would but turn to the history of their own country, they would perceive that it is nothing more nor less than “history repeating itself.” Somewhere about the year 447, when the Britons were being harassed by the Picts and Scots, they applied to Otius, then Prefect of Gaul, as near as my memory will serve me, in the following words: “The groans of the wretched Britons, to the thrice-appointed Consul Otius,—The barbarians” (and you were as barbarous in those days as we poor Fantees are now) “drive us into the sea, and the sea forces us back on the swords of the barbarians; so that we have nothing left us but the wretched choice of being either drowned or murdered.” Failing in obtaining the succour you were so much in need of, you had to go on your knees to the Saxons, give way before the Danes, and so on you continued till you finally succumbed to the domination of William the Conqueror and his sixty thousand followers. It was your numerous principalities, such as now exist here, without cohesion, without leadership, that caused you then to fall before “the barbarians;” and I have not the least doubt that you were looked upon by those barbarians as arrant cowards as you consider us; and it has taken you more than nine-teen hundred years since you were brought into contact with the Romans, who were then the acme of civilization, to reach your present summit. What may not fifteen hundred years hence find us; and where may you not be then? If we are such notorious cowards, if the meed of praise due us is to be withheld, why then, in the name of all that is good, why then, I ask, do you not go and fight your own battles (for this war is none of ours), without calling upon us to bear the brunt? In all ages and in all times, never have two nations engaged in a war without one or the other getting the worst of it; witness the Franco-German war, where the French, in no way the inferior of the Germans as regards courage, had to give way in almost every engagement before the superior skill, organization, and discipline of the German. Were the French cowards? Does it not bespeak a cowardly spirit to write what one knows to be false when he knows that that person has not the means of replying to him, since he can neither read nor write? And it is to be deplored that the writer of that article should so far forget himself, in his eagerness to write what may amuse the public, as to state what has no foundation in fact, and thus cast a slur on one of the best and bravest kings in the Protectorate. “Fiat justitia, ruat cælum.” Enclosing my card, I remain, Mr. Editor, yours truly,  
“TRUTH.”
'}]

[{'document_title': "DR. HORTON'S BOOK.", 'section_title': '', 'content': "Both Africa and Europe are indebted to Dr. Horton for this work. The author is not a man who has taken a run down the West Coast and back again in a mail steamer, and then written a book chiefly valuable as an evidence of the extent to which the boasted European intellect, when it has a wrong bias, can be gulled as to facts, and be made worthless as regards conclusions. One of the two only of native Africans who have been educated for Government Medical Service, Dr. Horton, as a Staff Assistant Surgeon, has passed eight years at the different British settlements on the West Coast. We feel, then, when we take up his book that he ought to know what he is writing about; and, on perusing it, find that he not only ought to know, but does know. It is not to be inferred from this that we agree with all his reasonings, admit all his conclusions, and coincide with all his views. In our position as regards West Africa we think it necessary to state this at once, that we may not be misunderstood. But we say unhesitatingly that the book is a valuable one—is a book that is very much wanted—that it is calculated to remove many misconceptions as regards the people and countries of which it treats—that it ought to do much toward clearing away the thick haze of prejudice in which the West Coast countries have been shrouded—and that it must, we think, convince every unprejudiced reader that those people and countries have a future of great importance to the civilised world, and of deep soul-stirring interest to the Christian, who is praying, hoping, teaching, and striving for the extension of the great Redeemer's kingdom.

The earlier portion of the volume is devoted to an *exposé* of the gross errors and misstatements and absurd reasonings that have been in vogue relative to the West African races and the countries they inhabit. We are glad to have these scientific and vulgar", 'last_edit_date': '1868-09-23', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/23_09_1868#article-33', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.622, 'probability_score': 0.067, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'BRITISH MISRULE IN WEST AFRICA.', 'section_title': '', 'content': 'Probably it will be said that this picture is grossly exaggerated—a mere caricature.* But the fact remains that it is an Englishman who speaks, and thereby condemns his own country for the century of misrule under which Sierra Leone groans.
