hh: The dissemination of information about African expeditions in the late 1800s was plagued by skepticism and misinformation due to unreliable communication networks, biased media sources, and the questionable authenticity of reports from European explorers and missionaries.
result: The dissemination of information about African expeditions in the late 1800s was indeed fraught with skepticism and misinformation, as highlighted by both the General History of Africa textbook and The African Times news articles. While the textbook does not directly address these issues, it provides a contextual backdrop of European influence and bias, noting the activities of explorers, missionaries, and traders, as well as the evolving use of newspapers and radio for nationalist and anti-colonial activities. This context suggests a potential for biased media sources and questionable authenticity in reports, though it does not explicitly highlight unreliable communication networks or misinformation as significant problems. In contrast, The African Times articles explicitly support the claim by detailing instances of skepticism and misinformation. They caution against trusting French reports about Madagascar without English confirmation, indicating unreliable communication networks and biased media sources. Doubts about the authenticity of reports from European explorers, such as M. Jules Gerard's claims about Dahomey, and the premature obituary notices of H. M. Stanley further illustrate these issues. The articles also discuss false reports about diamond discoveries and the challenges journalists faced in verifying information, as seen in the libel case involving Captain Rattray. These examples collectively demonstrate the difficulties in ensuring accurate and reliable dissemination of information about African expeditions during this period, aligning with the claim.

From this point to the south end of the Lake Albert Nyanza was about 480 miles. The caravan under Mr. Stanley left Yambuya on the 28th June 1887, to accomplish this journey, and since then no news had been received, except certain rumours, the first of which was dated November of last year. Some deserters were heard of by the late Major Barttelot as having arrived at an Arab camp about thirteen days' march from Yambuya. These men stated that the expedition had entered into a forest region, with mountains and marshy valleys, sparsely peopled by a hostile population, and that one of the white men had been wounded by an arrow. They also said the expedition had taken nearly three months to traverse the distance which had occupied a month in returning, and from this he (Sir Francis) was inclined to believe that Mr. Stanley had accomplished about 250 or 300 miles of his journey when the deserters left him. The next rumour was that of a white Pasha appearing in the Bahr-el-Gazel. This came via Khartoum and Suakim. He supposed that Mr. Stanley, finding the forest and mountainous region difficult to traverse, had turned to the north, and arrived in the neighbourhood of Tangayi. The news would be conveyed from market to market, and no doubt, would undergo all sorts of exaggeration. The next rumour dated from last July, and had its origin in letters from the missionaries resident at Uganda, dated last April. They stated that up to then no news had been received of either of Mr. Stanley or Emin Pasha. The last rumour came through some Arab traders who had arrived at Zanzibar. They said that at Sanga, last November, they had met a portion of the rear-guard of Stanley's caravan, who stated that Stanley was two marches ahead, that he was turning to the north, that the expedition had suffered great hardships, losing 200 men, and that one white man was dead. On hearing this, telegrams were sent to Zanzibar, but the reply was that the men who had brought the rumour could not be traced, and the intelligence was generally discredited.'}]

[{'document_title': 'False Report of Diamonds in River Congo', 'section_title': '', 'content': 'Sir,—In one of your last numbers the following passage occurs: "Diamonds have been discovered near a place called Sooka (on the Congo River). The stones have been examined by Dr. Bastian, who is travelling in the interior, and he has pronounced them to be of fine water." The whole of this is a dishonest lie of the individual on whose authority your correspondent has made the statement; and I use intentionally this strong expression to...
**35**

cut off at once the false reports. When I arrived at Bomma, to disentangle the idle tales fabricated there about Livingstone approaching the West Coast, the same parties who were interested in them showed me on several occasions, and rather mysteriously, some stones, said to be diamonds; and indicated the neighbourhood of Sooka, or Mossuko, as the place they had been found at. I told them at once that whatever the different samples in particulars would turn out to be, they might be satisfied that there were no diamonds amongst them; that the most of them were garnets or other silicates. As the geologist of the German expedition had not yet arrived on the Coast, I proposed to them to take some specimens with me to Berlin, to have them accurately examined there, as every collection from an unknown country, like that of the Upper Congo, would be of scientific interest. But as often as the question about diamonds was broached again, my answer was invariably the same, that I could recognize nothing to warrant such a supposition. Since my return, the specimens have been examined by highest authority in Berlin, and they have been proved to be, besides garnets (as mentioned before), crystals of magnetic iron metamorphosed into hematite. That the mountain ranges of Central Africa will show themselves rich in unknown treasures, scientific as well as commercial, is probable enough; but till now, there do not exist any indications in which direction to look for them; and I feel, it therefore, my duty to protest against deluding the public by vague surmises, and inveigling fortune-seekers into a country where their purse will be lightened when or even before they get there, and their health destroyed if they stay there, without a fixed purpose. When, on my homeward voyage, the steamer touched at the Gaboon, I was told there that, a few weeks ago, a Portuguese (with a name unknown to me) had been passing through there, and had spoken of diamonds having been discovered at Bomma, and as having been examined by me. I declared this at once to be a perversion of truth in its direct contrary, and I asked the trading gentlemen on the Coast to contradict the false reports whenever they heard them repeated; and as I now see that they have found their way into your columns, I beg permission to contradict them there likewise.—Your obedient servant,', 'last_edit_date': '1874-02-28', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/28_03_1874#article-19', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.616, 'probability_score': 0.066, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'Local Press Mis-statements', 'section_title': '', 'content': 'Sir,—I consider it due to the public to draw attention to the incorrect statements that appear in the three first issues of the _West African Herald_, under the present editor.

In his first issue (I shall take one instance only out of the numbers that appear in each paper) it is stated that the Fantis, although numbering 70,000 against 12,000 Ashantis, had been defeated by the enemy. The Fantis never had 70,000 men in the field, and the enemy had nearly four times the number given him.

In the second issue, it is stated in a letter addressed by the editor to our present Administrator-in-Chief, that the King of Denkira complained of the conduct of the Government Interpreter, Mr. James Davis, and that the king had no confidence in Mr. Davis. I am in a position to assert that Acquessi Kaye, the King of Denkira, told the Administrator-in-Chief that he had never authorized any such statement, and that he had the greatest confidence in Mr. Davis.

In the third issue, it is stated that the king and chiefs, at their meeting with his Excellency on the 7th June last, said that, owing to their cowardice, they were unable to fight the Ashantis. I have made inquiries from parties who were present at the meeting—kings, chiefs, and others—and they assure me that they made no use of any such expression.

It is always an unpleasant task to be compelled to draw attention to mis-statements; but history cannot be truly written unless this duty, however unpleasant, is performed.—I am, Sir,', 'last_edit_date': '1873-06-30', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/29_08_1873#article-25', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.624, 'probability_score': 0.067, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'The Lagos Mission of the Church Missionary Society', 'section_title': '', 'content': 'Dear Sir,—I beg you will allow me space in your columns to give one more instance in support of your frequent endeavours to point out the disadvantages to which the educated Africans on the West Coast are subject by their more favoured European brethren, be they missionaries, merchants, or Government officials. The African is to make no suggestion, or say anything beneficial to his country, when that suggestion or saying appears in any way likely to affect the interest, directly or indirectly, of his European brethren. This is what makes it always difficult to get people in England to believe your assertions in the African Times; because the majority of all European classes on the Coast do all they can to contradict those assertions, and very often some African is employed to assist them in the contradiction. In this case, however, I feel that, the facts being so true and plain, none but very unscrupulous persons in the body concerned will attempt to contradict what I shall here relate.', 'last_edit_date': '1872-11-19', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/30_12_1872#article-10', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.626, 'probability_score': 0.067, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'The Congo and Central Africa Company', 'section_title': '', 'content': 'Before our leader of last month on this important subject went to press, we had received further communications from the West Coast of a nature to give especial point to our observations therein made. In order that our readers may have some idea of the difficulties in the way of journalism where evils and errors are to be exposed with a view to effect a salutary change, we may state briefly what then occurred. We expurgated the chief communication we had received, which was a long report of a criminal case brought before one of the Courts, and incidents in the trial. We did not name the Court, nor the presiding Judge, nor the parties concerned. But it was held by our publishers that there was sufficient to lead to identification; and that, therefore, as “the greater the truth the greater the libel,” they could not take the risk of allowing it to appear in our columns. We had no resource but to bow to the decision, and refrain from publishing it. As it was strongly confirmative of what we had stated in our leader above alluded to, we can scarcely say that we submitted with a good grace. And yet, considering the small amount of support received by us from the West Coast, where comparatively so few of our nominal subscribers think it necessary to pay for the African Times, we can have no doubt they were right in preventing us as well as themselves from incurring any risk of the expense of defending an action for libel. At the same time, we feel it to be quite impossible to submit to entire silence, and, without therefore stating any of the particulars that were considered objectionable, we will merely give a short description of the *modus operandi* observed in obtaining a verdict. “When this

witness for the defence stated a fact that was important for the prosecution, the solicitor for the defence winked to the interpreter (the gentleman setting as Judge knowing nothing of the language), who did not interpret it at all. The solicitor then winked to the Judge, who thereupon said, 'Court adjourned for half an hour!' The jurors then marched respectively in pairs to partake of refreshments, with sparkling moselle, &c., prepared for them by the said solicitor. On the reappearance of all parties in Court, after a few words of badinage by the solicitor, there were also a few from the Judge, concluding with, 'But I do not mean that you should find these parties guilty!' and the jury obediently acquitted them." It may be said, perhaps, the jury were right. But if we could publish the whole case, it would be seen in a moment that they were wrong, and that this was well known to those who induced the jury to return such a verdict. After our last month's leader we do not think it necessary to make any further observations on the above, merely adding that we could wish the report of the case as we have it were in the hands of the Secretary of State for the Colonies, to whom, however, it does not belong to us to forward it.', 'last_edit_date': '1882-05-01', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/01_05_1882#article-10', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.628, 'probability_score': 0.067, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'THE FALSE STATEMENT OF THE DROWNING OF KROOMEN FROM THE AFRICAN S.S. BIAFRA.', 'section_title': '', 'content': "TO THE EDITOR OF THE AFRICAN TIMES.

Sir,—Captain Rattray, late of the steamship Biafra, has drawn our attention to the articles appearing in your paper of the 1st September last, one of which purports to give an extract from the Monrovia Observer, practically charging our client with the death of certain Krooboys at Settra Kroo. The article attributes to our client conduct so inhuman and abominable that he is most anxious that the public should be freely informed what the facts really were. We have, therefore, to request that you will give this letter as great prominence in your paper as the editorial article in your issue to which we have referred. In the month of June last, the Biafra put into Grand Cess, to land some Kroo passengers, and, as usual, canoes came off from the shore to land the passengers and their effects. Kroo passengers learned from those coming from ashore that there was some dispute between the town from which the canoes had come and the town to which they wished to go, and where they resided. Not knowing how far this dispute had gone, or whether actual fighting had taken place, the Kroo passengers were afraid to land, and asked Captain Rattray to wait until canoes should arrive from their own town. The ship had already been delayed, waiting for canoes, and was behind time; so that it was uncertain when canoes would, if at all, come from their town. Captain Rattray informed them it was impossible for him to wait, but he offered to take them to Bassa or Monrovia.

to land them there, and give them a note to the Captain of the next returning steamer to take them back. This arrangement was entirely satisfactory to the passengers, and they were landed by the steamer's boats at Monrovia, where the Captain gave them the promised note for their passages home by the Company's next steamer, giving them, in addition, a week's rations of bread and meat. From this you will see that Captain Rattray, instead of treating the men in the cruel manner attributed to him, treated them in the best possible way, and, for their accommodation, went much farther than there was any legal call upon him. We may add, that we have in our possession a duly signed and attested certificate to the effect that there is no truth whatever in the article you have quoted. We would only add, that the Biafra never was at Settra Kroo at all on the voyage referred to.—

We are, Sir, your obedient servants,  
**Hill, Dickinson, & Co.**

In inserting the above letter of Captain Rattray, we beg to express our deep and sincere regret that we should have been misled into copying from the Monrovia Observer, and publishing in our columns, with editorial remarks on the same, the false and calumnious statement of which Captain Rattray so justly complains. We can imagine the pain it must have caused him, and tender our apologies for having been thus instrumental in inflicting it.", 'last_edit_date': '1882-11-01', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/01_11_1882#article-15', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.629, 'probability_score': 0.067, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'THE "AFRICAN TIMES" AND THE AUTHORITIES AT LAGOS.', 'section_title': '', 'content': 'We find that complaint is made at Lagos of the article in our February number, relative to the non-delivery in Lagos of our journal of the 23rd November. We are accused of undue and intemperate haste in charging any of the colonial authorities with the suppression of our paper on that occasion, and condemned for writing as if there was a certainty about it, when there not only was no certainty at all, but, moreover, when the thing really had not taken place. We are told we ought to have waited, and made proper inquiry, and then we should have found there was no truth whatever in the statement. We do not think we were unduly hasty. We did not act upon a single testimony. We received letters from several of our subscribers complaining of the alleged fact; and it was, we believe, the first time such a thing had occurred; and there did happen to be in the November number, also for the first time, certain matter which might not be quite agreeable to the authorities. The papers had been duly
**125**

posted in England, and the papers were not duly delivered in Lagos. We were therefore justified in writing on the supposition that they had been purposely withheld from our subscribers. And what is now the explanation we have indirectly received? "The greater portion of the November number of the 'African Times' arrived in December, and the two numbers for November and December were delivered together to the various subscribers," i.e., we presume, if words mean anything, that the November papers which arrived in Lagos in December, were detained at the Post-office there until the December papers arrived in January, and then the papers of the two months were delivered to the subscribers at the same time. We can only say in reply that under such circumstances our subscribers who did not receive the November papers in December were fully justified in believing that they had been suppressed, and in writing to us to that effect. In order to avoid the recurrence of similar unfounded charges against any of the Lagos authorities, we therefore beg respectfully to suggest that they will do well at all times to deliver the papers immediately on their arrival.', 'last_edit_date': '1866-05-23', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/23_05_1866#article-13', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.626, 'probability_score': 0.067, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'TO THE EDITOR OF THE AFRICAN TIMES.', 'section_title': '', 'content': 'Sir,—The *African Times* of November 1st contains a letter having reference to our work here. While the said letter appears to be written by one who appreciates my efforts to benefit the Gambia, I must, in justice to the Rev. Mr. Adcock, and in the interest of truth, openly deny the veracity of several of the statements it contains, and request you to publish my entire disapproval of its appearance in your paper. I do not know "Wesleyan," but if he knew more of the internal work of our Mission, he would not give me the honour due to another.—Yours, &c.,', 'last_edit_date': '1878-02-01', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/01_02_1878#article-6', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.628, 'probability_score': 0.067, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'The Alleged Drowning of Kroomen', 'section_title': '', 'content': 'Our readers will find in another column evidence of the perils which beset journalism even when conducted with the greatest caution and the most earnest desire to do good unmixed with evil. When we copied from the Monrovia Observer, and published in our September number, with some editorial comments, the statement of the alleged throwing overboard of Kroomen from the mail steamer Biafra, we prefaced the one with the question, "Can this be true?" and stated in the other our willingness to publish any contradiction by the officers of the steamer or the Company to which the steamer belongs. We should not have copied the statement into our paper, but that it stated, "the men were landed at Monrovia, many of them entirely naked." Now, Monrovia is not a very large place, and as it had long seemed to us that the Monrovia Observer was most respectably and carefully conducted, we naturally supposed that the Editor had satisfied himself of the truth of the very serious allegations. In this it appears that we were altogether in error, and were thus innocently led into inflicting pain upon the Captain of the steamer. Those who know us personally would understand how deeply this would grieve us. Instead, however, of availing himself of the offer contained in our leader, Captain Rattray placed the matter in the hands of his Attorney in Liverpool, and we received a letter from them, threatening us with proceedings for libel, and our Printer also, unless we published in our next number a refutation of the charge, with our apologies for its insertion and for our comments. We replied immediately, that nothing could have given us greater pleasure than the assurance that the alleged circumstance never occurred, and that we were ready to publish any letter of Captain Rattray to this effect, supplementing it with expression of our most sincere and heartfelt regret that we should have given publicity to so false a statement. We received a reply that this was unsatisfactory, and that unless we agreed fully to their demands to publish whatever they might send to us in contradiction, with the most ample apology, and agreed to pay all costs, proceedings would be commenced immediately. We were not in London on the Saturday to receive this, and our Printer wrote them to this effect, but when we found it on the Monday we reiterated by post our willingness to do all that could be reasonably required to atone for our unintentional offence. But a writ had been already issued on that Monday, and we were served with it on Tuesday, just after we had written what we intended to insert, with the purpose of sending it by that day's post. But on receiving the writ, we placed the matter in the hands of our Solicitors, Messrs. Hollams, Son, and Coward, to effect a settlement, when what appears in another column was agreed upon and accepted as satisfactory, on our payment of costs. In making this statement of facts to show our African readers the perils to which we are exposed in our labours for Africa, we again repeat our deep and sincere regret for any pain we may have caused Captain Rattray by the reproduction of the falsehood in our columns, while, at the same time, stating that we should have done this without any legal proceedings on his part, which have thus inflicted on us a heavy and unnecessary expense. We cannot, however, acquit the Editor of the Monrovia Observer of blame in this matter, and we think he owes us an apology as full and sincere as that which we have given to Captain Rattray, and which, we repeat, we should have given upon a simple statement and demand had such been made direct to us by him.', 'last_edit_date': '1882-11-01', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/01_11_1882#article-14', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.625, 'probability_score': 0.067, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'REVIEW.', 'section_title': '', 'content': 'Books are like men. Their contents are the reflex of men's minds. The facts, real or pretended, which are chronicled in them are coloured and modified by the author's idiosyncrasy. Human imperfection is universally admitted. What wonder, then, if we rarely or never find a work that we can unreservedly praise? At the same time, and for the same reason, we never desire or expect that our opinion of a work should be the standard of our readers' judgment regarding it. In spite of many and grave faults and errors in "Wanderings in Western Africa," by a F.R.G.S., we therefore say to one and all who take an interest in Africa, *get the book and read it.* It is dashingly written. It does not weary the reader. It gives much of the information that lies scattered in a hundred different works published during the last two or three centuries, which are inaccessible to many, and, when procured, fatigue rather than instruct. And to these gleanings the author adds his own first impressions of scenes—his own opinions of systems (if anything in British government on the West Coast can be justly designated by such a term)—his own appreciation of facts brought before him—his own personal experience among a people on whom the light of civilization and Christianity has scarcely anywhere dawned.

It may be said of these volumes as but of too many that have preceded them, "what is true in them is [for the most part] not new, and what is new is [for the most part] not true." They have in them, however, the stamp of genius. Alas, that it should be of genius without the control of high or Christian principle! We allude to this with deep regret. But it would have been unjustifiable in us not to have alluded to it, especially as we have been dragged forward most unnecessarily and unprovokedly for censure. Apropos of roads, which he says "are hardly so important to Africa as people at home suppose," he adds: "These remarks will apply to the Special Fund of 200l., of which an advertisement, 'Aquapem Mountain Road,' appears once per month in the *African Times,* a Methodistical publication, whose tone and spirit, venerable cant, and worn-out declamation, take us back to the days of A.D. 1800."—Vol. II., p. 236.', 'last_edit_date': '1863-12-23', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/23_12_1863#article-21', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.63, 'probability_score': 0.067, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'The Administration of Justice on the West Coast', 'section_title': '', 'content': 'Before our leader of last month on this important subject went to press, we had received further communications from the West Coast of a nature to give especial point to our observations therein made. At the same time, we feel it to be quite impossible to submit to entire silence, and, without therefore stating any of the particulars that were considered objectionable, we will merely give a short description of the *modus operandi* observed in obtaining a verdict. “When this', 'last_edit_date': '1882-05-01', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/01_05_1882#article-9', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.63, 'probability_score': 0.067, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'AFRICAN EXPLORATION.', 'section_title': '', 'content': 'A correspondent of the *Cape Times*, at Zanzibar, writes: “Mr. Thomson has come back after a most successful journey. In fourteen months, and at the cost of 2,600l., he has examined the country to the north of Lake Nyassa and then to the south of Tanganyika. He has followed the Lukuga from the lake on its way to the Congo; it takes the north-west course, and led him too far off, so that he did not reach the junction. Notwithstanding this, the Lukuga has been seen as a large, swift river flowing off to the Atlantic, but utterly useless for trade, as it is full of rapids. The blocking of the outlet seems to have been caused by an accumulation of vegetation, which probably takes place periodically and at long intervals. It is in each case only a question of time as to when the lake bursts through. This time the lake fell eight feet after the occurrence, and an inundation passed down sweeping villages away in the Congo Valley, near Nyangwe. Mr. Thomson has visited Lake Hikna, a lake about twenty miles long, and which would be a considerable one were not Africa already so filled with greater ones. The best of the expedition is that there has not been a bale of goods lost, a single man deserted, or any one died; not a shot has been fired in defence or attack; and Mr. Thomson agrees with old travellers that African travelling is very interesting, but', 'last_edit_date': '1880-10-01', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/01_10_1880#article-15', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.615, 'probability_score': 0.066, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'Alleged Unfair Dealings of the European Agents of the Church Missionary Society', 'section_title': '', 'content': '.**

LISBON, July 7 (Evening).—The African exploring expedition left Lisbon for Loanda to-day. The Minister of Marine and the members of the Lisbon Geographical Society were at the place of embarkation to take leave of the party and wish them a cordial farewell.

Signor Gessi, the celebrated African explorer, while proceeding to the Lake District, had all his scientific instruments and baggage burnt.

---', 'last_edit_date': '1877-09-01', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/01_09_1877#article-14', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.618, 'probability_score': 0.066, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'The Complaints from Old Calabar', 'section_title': '', 'content': 'The War on the Gold Coast, from the period of the crossing of the Prah by the invading Ashantees twenty months ago, and the Parliamentary and other public and official proceedings connected with it, and with the establishment of the new Gold Coast Colony, with coast extension over the old coast line purchased by Great Britain in time past from Denmark, have so occupied our columns, that we could not find time or space for a number of complaints of wrongs endured, and evil deeds committed in Native and British territories on the West Coast. If any of our readers have interpreted that comparative absence of complaints, as indicating that the West Coast was becoming an Arcadia, it is time that we dissipate the illusion by giving printed utterance to some of those denunciations and groans, perhaps too long suppressed by us. Of these, some will be found in the letters from Old Calabar inserted in our present number. These are not the first we have had touching the matters of which they complain; and perhaps it is scarcely necessary for us to say that we have greatly modified and softened them in publication. Half-educated West Africans who have wrongs and abuses to expose, seem to be under the impression that we have unlimited power to hold up individuals by name to public obloquy or condemnation, upon the mere statement of one, two, or three of their number—persons of whom we, perhaps, know little or nothing. We wish them to understand, once for all, that this is by no means the case. In the first place, our conscience would not permit us thus to attack or expose any individual, without the most incontrovertible evidence of the exact and unexaggerated truth of the prejudicial statements thus made—evidence which could not be said to be thus furnished. In the second place, we must inform them that there are very stringent laws of libel,
**[SEPT. 30, 1874.]**', 'last_edit_date': '1874-09-30', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/30_09_1874#article-21', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.625, 'probability_score': 0.067, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'Letters to the Editor: The C.M.S. Niger Mission—A Warning to Native Merchants', 'section_title': '', 'content': '## A WARNING TO NATIVE MERCHANTS.

### TO THE EDITOR OF "THE AFRICAN TIMES."

Sir,—Will you permit me space in your pages to show some of my brethren on the West Coast how I have been swindled by a firm of professing merchants in London, in the hope that a relation of my experience may be of service to others, and cause them to make all needful inquiries as to the good faith and solvency of those to whom they are thinking of consigning goods for realisation in the London markets, or money for purchase of goods for Africa.

In May last year I received letters from a firm dating from the City, offering to do business with me, whether in the way of realisation or purchase, and professing to have exceptional facilities for the disposal of African produce, and the purchase of European goods in exchange. They made such a plausible tale that I was quite taken with them, and forwarded a box of gold dust, together with samples of goods I wanted in return. This came duly into their hands, and I received an acknowledgment from them with a statement showing that the gold dust had realised £56 10s. 10d., but that the goods I required would cost a good deal more than that. I accordingly obtained and forwarded to them a draft, making in all £97 10s. 2d.; at the same time sending them my gold watch (value £7) for cleaning and repairs in London. This second remittance was also acknowledged in due course—and there the matter ended! Finding weeks go by, and nothing come to hand, I wrote to a firm in London, upon whose integrity I can rely, for them to inquire into the matter, and do the best they could—either in the way of getting back my money or by urging these people to hurry on with the goods, so that I might not entirely lose the market. They accordingly wrote to the firm in question several times, but only to receive vague promises of immediate attention, or still more evasive answers. So I determined myself to come to London to see what could be done. And the upshot of my inquiries is that the firm to whom I had consigned my money and goods have proved utter swindlers: they traded under a fancy name, and when they found things were getting too hot for them they left the country, so as to be beyond the reach of the law.

For myself I must make up my mind to cut my loss; as I understand that even if I could get hold of the swindlers there is no chance of my regaining any portion of what they have had from me. hh: Historical accounts of African conflicts are often contested and potentially biased, necessitating the inclusion of native perspectives to achieve a more accurate and comprehensive understanding.
result: The observations from both the "General History of Africa" textbook and The African Times news articles collectively underscore the claim that historical accounts of African conflicts are often contested and potentially biased, necessitating the inclusion of native perspectives for a more accurate and comprehensive understanding. The textbook highlights how colonial historians have distorted facts by oversimplifying African societies and resistance movements, often portraying them as disorganized or irrational, and critiques the Eurocentric view that Africans welcomed colonial rule, ignoring the complexity and regularity of African resistance. It emphasizes the importance of preserving and evaluating local accounts and oral histories to counter these biases and argues for a dynamic theory of underdevelopment that includes African perspectives on resistance and liberation. Similarly, The African Times articles provide instances of discrepancies between official reports and native accounts, such as differing views on the wars up the river and the Ashantee war, where native correspondents offer alternative narratives that challenge official sources. Letters from individuals like Africanus and King Wea highlight the importance of native voices in recounting events, often contradicting or providing additional context to official narratives, suggesting biases in the latter. The articles also discuss complexities in treaties and territorial claims, as seen in the Liberian Special Commissioner's report, which omits certain native claims, indicating potential bias. Together, these sources emphasize the necessity of incorporating native perspectives to challenge biased historical narratives and achieve a nuanced and comprehensive understanding of African conflicts.

[{'document_title': 'African initiatives and resistance in North Africa and the Sahara', 'section_title': '', 'content': "Colonial historians knowingly distort the facts when they ignore the level of the organized state, reduce brotherhoods to some kind of superethnic group and see nothing in Maghribi society but ethnic groups. These, moreover, they interpret according to anthropological models of kinship which are more theoretical than real. By this skewed approach, they break the resistance up into a sporadic set of disorganized reactions to a policy of conquest that seems eminently rational by contrast.
When speaking of the state or the brotherhoods, we shall use the word 'initiatives'; at the local level the word 'reactions'. Although both ideas coexist in the history of the Maghrib, each can nevertheless be used separately to define the characteristics of a given period (before and after 1912 in Morocco, before and after 1922 in Libya).
Our source material for Maghribian initiatives to resist colonial ambitions is political and diplomatic. It is familiar material, and the problem for historians today is to assemble and preserve it. The evidence for local reactions is mainly written statements and oral accounts. B. Davidson, called upon scholars to refute 'the traditional European historiographical view' in which 'the African people apprehended the coming of the colonialists as good fortune; as deliverance from fratricidal internecine wars, from the tyranny of neigh› bouring tribes, from epidemics, and periodic starvations'; in which peoples who did not resist were described as 'peace-loving' and those who did resist were described as 'blood-thirsty'. Davidson remarked that 'protectors of colonial rule refused to consider rebellion a regular phenomenon'. They explained it in terms of 'primitive and irrational' responses, or in terms of the agitation of the 'blood-thirsty' minority. 'They rejected the only correct explanation which regards rebellions as just wars for liberation, which is why they were supported by the overwhelming majority of Africans.' l In 1965 Davidson emphasized that 'many rebellions are not yet known... Often we do not have concrete information about those rebellions that are considered an established fact'. Since then, the job of 'discovering' resistances has gone on apace. Historians have begun to classify revolts more rigorously, distinguishing 'social banditry' from 'peasant rebellion', and guerrilla warfare from the clash of armies. In some cases episodes trumpeted by the colonialists as rebellions have been shown to have been forced upon the people by ignorance and fear on the part of the whites. 2 In many more cases considerable and significant resistances have been rescued from obscurity. We now possess detailed studies for most of the 'major' uprisings and in some cases a vigorous argument about how best to explain and interpret them has been taking place. From all this it is quite clear that Davidson was right to think that resistance was a 'regular phenomenon'.", 'last_edit_date': None, 'url': None, 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.674, 'probability_score': 0.05, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'Africa and the colonial challenge', 'section_title': 'The structure of Volume VII', 'content': "The second section deals with a theme that had until the 1960s either been grossly misrepresented or entirely ignored by the colonial school of African historiography, namely, African initiatives and reactions in the face of the conquest and occupation of Africa. To the members of this school such as H. H. Johnston, Sir Alan Burns and, more recently, Margery Perham, Lewis H. Gann and Peter Duignan,$^{10}$ Africans in fact welcomed the establishment of colonial rule since not only did it save them from anarchy and internecine warfare but it also brought them some concrete benefits. Thus Margery Perham: most of the tribes quickly accepted European rule as part of an irresist› ible order, one which brought many benefits, above all peace, and exciting novelties, railways and roads, lamps, bicycles, ploughs, new foods and crops, and all that could be acquired and experienced in town and city. For the ruling classes, traditional or created, it brought a new strength and security of status and new forms of wealth and power. For many years after annexation, though there was much bewilderment, revolts were very few, and there does not appear to have been much sense of indignity at being ruled. ' ' Such ideas are also reflected in the use of such Eurocentric terms as 'pacification', Pax Britannica and Pax Gallica used to describe what amounted to the conquest and occupation of Africa between 1890 and 1914. Those historians who did pay some attention to this subject mentioned it almost accidentally or casually. In their A Short History of Africa which first appeared in 1962, one of the very first modern professional surveys of the history of Africa, the English historians, Roland Oliver and J. D. Fage, devoted only a single paragraph to what they termed 'bitter resistance' by Africans in a chapter of fourteen pages dealing with what has become known as the European Scramble for African colonies. It is to correct this wrong interpretation of the colonial school and to redress the balance and highlight the African perspective that we have devoted as many as seven chapters to this theme of African initiatives and reactions.", 'last_edit_date': None, 'url': None, 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.671, 'probability_score': 0.05, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'Africa and the colonial challenge', 'section_title': 'The structure of Volume VII', 'content': 'Finally, only those historians who are really ignorant of or hold very simplistic views about the political and ethno-cultural situation in Africa on the eve of the European partition and conquest would use that term. They assume that all African countries, like many European countries, are inhabited by the same ethno-cultural group or nation, and therefore that any section of that group that allied with an invader could be termed a collaborator. But no African country or colony or empire was made up of any such single ethnic group. Each country or empire was populated by numerous ethno-cultural groups or nations who were as different from each other as, say, the Italians are from the Germans or the French. More› over, prior to the arrival of the European invaders, relations between these different groups were often hostile while some might even have been sub› jugated by others. To label such subjugated or hostile groups who chose to join the invading European group against their former foreign enemies or rulers as collaborators is to miss the point. Indeed, as will be demon› strated in some of the chapters of this volume, the nature of African reactions and responses to colonialism was determined not only by the ethno-cultural and political situation with which the Africans were con› fronted but also by the very nature of the socio-economic forces at work in the particular society at the time of the confrontation, and the nature of its political organization.', 'last_edit_date': None, 'url': None, 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.662, 'probability_score': 0.05, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'African initiatives and resistance in the face of partition and conquest', 'section_title': 'Conclusion', 'content': "It can be seen, then, that the historiography of resistance is a lively and argumentative one. Yet the modifications and new perspectives enlarge rather than controvert the three basic propositions I have been discussing. The 'regularity' and 'generality' of resistance emerges yet more clearly when we add to our catalogue of armed opposition and revolt during the Scramble the earlier indirect resistances to European economic aggression. Exploration of the ideological basis of resistance gains a new richness when we add the first manifestations of 'consciousness' on the part of workers or peasants to the idea of sovereignty and to the search for a new moral order. And the exploration of the links between resistance and the present situation of Africa gains a new resonance from the idea of economic resist› ance. The last word may rest not with a historian but with a political scientist, Colin Leys, who has called for a more dynamic and historically founded theory of 'underdevelopment': in one critical respect underdevelopment theory tends to resemble 'development theory' - it concentrates on what happens to the under› developed countries at the hands of imperialism and colonialism rather than on the total historical process involved, including the various forms of struggle against imperialism and colonialism which grow out of the conditions of underdevelopment ... what is needed is not a theory of underdevelopment but a theory of underdevelopment and its liquidation ... a theory of this kind implies nothing less than a theory of world history from the standpoint of the underdeveloped countries, a theory of the oppression and liberation of these countries; something ... in a fairly rudimentary stage of development, however keenly the need for it may be felt. 47 The study of the resistances is not a romantic dwelling upon the futile glories of the past but can make its own contribution to a theory of oppression and liberation.", 'last_edit_date': None, 'url': None, 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.653, 'probability_score': 0.049, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'African initiatives and resistance in East Africa, i880-1914', 'section_title': '', 'content': 'Much has been written about the African response to foreign penetration and eventual rule towards the end of the last century and the beginning of the present. Most of the discussion, if not all of it, has been centred on the dichotomy between resisters, who by implication are to be praised as heroes, and so-called collaborators, who also by implication are to be condemned as traitors. This classification came about as a result of the nationalist struggle for independence in Africa, as elsewhere in the world. Those involved in the movement tended to see themselves as heirs to a long tradition of struggle whose roots go back to the beginning of this century, if not earlier. It was assumed that independence was a good thing and to strive for it was natural. Consequently, all those who had resisted European penetration of Africa, in order to preserve its inde› pendence, were heroes to be emulated and given an honourable place in the histories of the countries that had gained their independence through resistance to colonial rule. Put in these terms, this view is an attempt to use the standards of the present, with the aid of hindsight, to interpret the events of the past. In the colonial situation, those who resisted were described by colonial officials as short-sighted while those who collaborated were seen as far-sighted. Today, nationalist historians in East Africa con› demn so-called collaborators, especially chiefs, and praise resisters. 1
Among the resisters, there were also divisions. There were those who took to armed confrontation with the intruders - active resistance. Then there were those who, though they did not take to arms, refused to co› operate with the intruders. This form of resistance is referred to as passive resistance. There has not been a similar treatment of the so-called collaborators. They are often put together as simply one undifferentiated group.', 'last_edit_date': None, 'url': None, 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.665, 'probability_score': 0.05, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'European partition and conquest of Africa: an overview', 'section_title': 'The partition of Africa and the new imperialism: a review > The African dimension theory', 'content': 'In these cases an explanation of partition will need to emphasise external pressures, such as mercantile demands and Anglo-French rivalries. In these cases an explanation of imperialism will need to place more weight on disintegrative forces on the African side of the frontier, though without neglecting external factors. 32 The present writer agrees with most of the views of members of this school.$^{33}$ Like them, he explains the partition in both African and European terms, and therefore sees the African dimension theory as supplementing the Eurocentric theories already discussed. He sees the partition and con› quest as the logical consequence of European nibbling at Africa which started well before the nineteenth century; he accepts that the essentially economic impulse that necessitated that nibbling changed drastically during the last quarter of the nineteenth century; that the change was caused by the transition from slave to legitimate trade and the subsequent decline in both the export and import trade during that period, and that it was this economic change in Africa and the consequent African resistance to increasing European influence that precipitated the actual military con› quest. It would appear, indeed, that the African dimension theory provides a better rounded, more historically focused theory of the partition than any of the purely Eurocentric theories.', 'last_edit_date': None, 'url': None, 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.671, 'probability_score': 0.05, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'Africa and the colonial challenge', 'section_title': 'The structure of Volume VII', 'content': "Many European historians have condemned the opposers as being romantic and short-sighted and have praised the so-called collaborators as being far-sighted and progressive. As Oliver and Fage put it in 1962: If these [African rulers] were far-sighted and well-informed, and more particularly if they had had access to foreign advisers such as mission› aries or traders they might well understand that nothing was to be gained by resistance, and much by negotiation. If they were less farsighted, less fortunate or less well-advised, they would see their traditional enemies siding with the invader and would themselves assume an attitude of resistance, which could all too easily end in military defeat, the deposition of chiefs, the loss of land to the native allies of the occupying power, possibly even to the political fragmen› tation of the society or state ... As with the slave trade in earlier times, there were gainers as well as losers, and both were to be found within the confines of every colonial territory. ls Ronald E. Robinson and John Gallagher have also described opposition or resistance as consisting of 'romantic reactionary struggles against the facts, the passionate protests of societies which were shocked by the new age of change and would not be comforted'.$^{16}$ But these views are highly questionable and the dichotomy between resisters and so-called collabor› ators is not only mechanistic but simply unconvincing. There were certainly losers and gainers in the slave trade, but there were no gainers this time. Both resisters and so-called collaborators lost in the end, and what is interesting is that it is the so-called romantic leaders and diehards who are still remembered, and have become a source of inspiration to the nationalist leaders of today.$^{17}$ I entirely agree with the conclusion of Robert I. Rotberg and Ali A. Mazrui that 'there is no gainsaying that the introduction of western norms and power, and accompanying controls and constraints, was everywhere in Africa questioned by the peoples affected'. 18 However, whatever strategy the Africans adopted, all of them - with the sole exception of the Liberians and Ethiopians - failed, for reasons that will be discussed below, to maintain their sovereignty, and by the beginning of the First World War, the cut-off date for the first section of this volume, Africa had been subjected to colonial rule. How and why the Liberians and Ethiopians managed to survive in the face of this", 'last_edit_date': None, 'url': None, 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.655, 'probability_score': 0.049, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'The arts in Africa during the period of colonial rule', 'section_title': 'African music', 'content': "OPPONENT: Nobody goes both ways at the same time. You have told this and that. One of the two must be wrong. That is why I am attack› ing you. (sings) 'A thief speaks with another thief. The griot has been amply celebrated in the epic of a slave's descendant who returned from the United States in the last decade to trace his Gambian ancestry.$^{9}$ To move from the griot's home in the Western Sudan southwards to Central and Southern Africa is to encounter his counterpart and the epic of his survival in a phase of even greater violence and instability. [{'id': 313, 'article_title': 'RIVER GAMBIA', 'full_section_title': 'RIVER GAMBIA', 'last_edit_date': None, 'num_tokens': 0, 'language': 'en', 'block_type': 'text', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/23_02_1864#article-1', 'issue_date': '23_02_1864', 'content': 'One of our native correspondents, who certainly shows too much ability to be allied to the "great ape species," whatever Dr. Hunt may discover, or fancy he discovers, in the physical formation of the African, gives a very different account of the wars up the river to those which we as well as Her Majesty's Government have received from official and semi-official sources. It is our duty, in the interest of African advancement, to hear both sides, and if our space this month will admit, we will give in another column a native account of those disturbances which he says, "the Administration might have found something better to do than to interfere with, to give themselves so much trouble, and oblige them to waste so much of their time in writing so many voluminous official documents about nothing at all." We are inclined to attach the more importance to this new view of native affairs in the river because (and which has been often a matter of surprise with us) we have experienced that British merchants having transactions in the river seemed to pooh pooh some of the voluminous reports alluded to.

Our native friends make a sweeping accusation against successive governors of having done nothing for the colony. They speak with great respect of Governor George Rendall, who died in 1837, as "one who really did set about improving the colony; and again of Sir Charles Fitzgerald, sent out in 1843," who did his best for the improvement and civilization of the colony, but whose efforts have been systematically discontinued by his successors up to this present time."'}, {'id': 340, 'article_title': 'CAPE COAST.', 'full_section_title': 'CAPE COAST.', 'last_edit_date': '04-11-1864', 'num_tokens': 0, 'language': 'en', 'block_type': 'text', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/23_05_1864#article-5', 'issue_date': '23_05_1864', 'content': 'No one can lament more than we do the loss of life and treasure caused by this deplorable Ashantee war. But our readers are too well acquainted with its rise and progress to be misled by a clap-trap letter, in which the invasion of the Gold Coast Territories last year by three divisions of the Ashantee army, the loss of some thousands of native lives, and the destruction of many towns and villages, is so completely ignored, that it is stated to be doubtful whether one of the enemy has been at some time or other seen by a sentry. We can only further refer our readers to letters and articles in this present number of our journal on this interesting and painful subject.—_Ed. A.T._'}, {'id': 952, 'article_title': 'ABYSSINIA', 'full_section_title': 'ABYSSINIA', 'last_edit_date': None, 'num_tokens': 0, 'language': 'en', 'block_type': 'text', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/23_10_1866#article-19', 'issue_date': '23_10_1866', 'content': 'Some French papers have published a long account of a great battle said to have been fought between the armies of King Theodore and the insurgents of Tigné and Chos, two of the principal and most civilised provinces of that country. The two armies are stated at about 100,000 men each. No decided victory was gained, but the King's army remained masters of the field of battle. The killed and wounded in the two armies were estimated at some 70,000! The report adds that the King, "in a rage, had sent an order on the 1st August for the immediate execution of the English captives, Cameron, Rassam, Stern, &c., &c." We venture yet to hope that this is all an invention. Should it, however, prove to be true, we may possibly give the published details of the battle, which are curious, if correct.'}, {'id': 1274, 'article_title': 'THE AWOONLAH WARS', 'full_section_title': 'THE AWOONLAH WARS', 'last_edit_date': '02-06-1868', 'num_tokens': 0, 'language': 'en', 'block_type': 'text', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/23_03_1868#article-5', 'issue_date': '23_03_1868', 'content': 'Sir,—As I am well aware that news might reach you from Accra from some of your correspondents, about a new fight on the Volta on the 1st and 6th of January between the Doffoes, Volloes, and Akwamus on one hand, and the Assucharye, and as I am sure that things might be represented to you in a different light than they ought to be, I beg you, Mr. Editor, to insert this in your next number.

I beg to inform you that I am a native of the interior, and in consequence know more about Akuapim, Akim, Kroboe, and Akwamu than many of your other correspondents, and what I now say is the truth.

The Government has done what it could in restoring peace and order amongst the natives. There are many persons who are of opinion that the Government ought to help the Adahs and Accras to fight the Anwoonahs to finish the war; but there are others who know the state of the country who think differently, and that the first who brought on the war were Adahs, and not the Anwoonahs. You will perhaps have heard that the
**[MARCH 23, 1868.]**

messengers whom the Government sent to Akwamu were killed; but I am glad to inform you that the report is not true; they came back safe and sound to Accra last Saturday, the 1st instant. Their report shows that the Akwamus would have kept the treaty if this last outrage between the Dofoes, &c., had not taken place, and also that the King and many peacefully-disposed chiefs and head men under him are greatly sorry at what has happened.—I am, Sir, your obedient servant,

AFRICANUS.

*Note.—It seems to us that this "true statement of facts" affords strong corroborative evidence of the absolute necessity of a supreme power insisting upon, and, if requisite, enforcing peace in the Eastern Districts.—Ed. A. T.*

ROBERTS.', 'last_edit_date': '04-01-1876', 'num_tokens': 0, 'language': 'en', 'block_type': 'text', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/01_04_1876#article-16', 'issue_date': '01_04_1876', 'content': 'The Consul-General of Liberia in London, Mr. Jackson, with that zeal for his Government which characterizes him on all occasions, has kindly furnished us with the printed Report of the Liberian Special Commissioner sent from Monrovia to Cape Palmas, last summer, to inquire into the difficulties which had arisen between the Gedeboes and the Cape Palmas Liberians. We have read it attentively, but we cannot find in it that dependable rectification of errors in King Weah’s statement, published by us last month, which we had looked for. Having received constant and minute intelligence from Cape Palmas, from the period of the advent of the Liberian Commissioner there, we discover that there are important omissions in the Report; nor are we at all satisfied that King Weah’s statements are incorrect as regards either of the two great points—viz., the commencement of warlike operations and the territorial claims. We are surprised at the failure of the Report on these points, because, if there be one thing more than another in which the public men in Liberia have excelled, it has been in the drawing up of their Reports, Presidential Messages, and other State documents; and still more surprised, because many portions of the Report are written with a most charming air of sincerity and good feeling, becoming the character and position of the Commissioner. The Commissioner states that there was a warlike demonstration of the natives on the 10th of August, and that on the following day some of them began deliberately to fire on the Hoffman Mission Station. He then adds: “Thus war began, as far as I know the facts.” As the Commissioner was at Cape Palmas at that time, he must have had a personal knowledge of the facts had they been such as he relates; and the impression produced on our mind is that, not himself believing the statement to be altogether true, he was too conscientious to vouch for it. Then as regards the Land question. The Special Commissioner states that the object of the combination among the natives is “the re-possession of the territory,” which involves rights and powers that would be incompatible with the fiscal arrangements of the Liberian Government; that the natives “deny that the Liberian Government has acquired the domain; that they declare themselves the masters; that they ignore the deed of purchase by the Maryland Colonization Society, and assert that the articles therein mentioned were paid to them for landing the immigrants and building their huts.” Looking to probabilities, we cannot believe that the natives sold the entire lands of their country, and their own right of free action, but only the lands on which they permitted the immigrants of the Colonization Society to settle, assisting them in landing, building their huts, &c. We must frankly state, however, that we do not attach much importance to this. Liberia has become an organized and recognized State, with institutions framed and established on the model of the United States of America. The presence of any European or other civilized Power on the coast lands of the Gedeboes and others would be fatal.
[APRIL 1, 1876.]'}, {'id': 3467, 'article_title': 'The Truth as to the Dispute between the Egbas and Ibadans', 'full_section_title': 'The Truth as to the Dispute between the Egbas and Ibadans', 'last_edit_date': '10-08-1877', 'num_tokens': 0, 'language': 'en', 'block_type': 'text', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/01_12_1877#article-15', 'issue_date': '01_12_1877', 'content': 'Sir,—I have read your able article in the African Times of the 1st ultimo, signed "A Native," and beg you to allow me to answer Mr. "Native," in a few words, as to what he stated about the Ibadans and Egba war affairs. Mr. Native ought to be impartial, as a Christian, and not take the part of one, but pray for both, in order that this war may not break out as others are doing. Both have great faults, each in its own way. The so-called refugees (or "refuse" as Mr. "Native" calls them) have been more just to the Egbas than the peaceable Egbas are to them. I doubt not about the Egbas being a peaceful nation, but I should like to know what they went to do in Porto Novo's farm (Wenu) in 1874, or in Oluke in 1876; as for what they went to do at Imeko, Mr. "Native" no doubt will answer all this. As an eye-witness, I ought to let Mr. Editor know something about this war, in order that Mr. "Native" may contradict me in it.'}]
