Dr. Schön has since been actively employed in compiling books, and making translations in the languages of West Africa, a knowledge of which he acquired on the spot. He has spurned the name and the position of a "disabled" missionary, for all his powers have been unceasingly devoted to the service of the Lord, and he could with difficulty be kept back by the order of his doctor, at the age of eighty-five, from his daily work with eye and pen. The great language of the Hausa, spoken by tens of millions, and destined to be a most important element in the civilisation of the negro, has been revealed to the world by Dr. Schön, in dictionaries, grammars, reading-books, and translation of the Bible. Not content with publishing a book, he has, immediately after publication, commenced a studious revision and enlargement, and has lived to carry through revised editions. When he was stationed in Sierra Leone, he studied and published works in the Mende language; and, when on the Niger, he mastered the Ibo language; and by keeping himself in con...

stant touch with negro scholars in the field, he has kept his knowledge up. Large portions of the Bible and the Prayer Book in Ibo will survive as proofs of his industry and power. Yet one day he met Livingstone at dinner at Lambeth Palace, and the great traveller made the following remark to Archbishop Sumner: "This man's name will live generations after mine has been forgotten." In a special assembly at the University of Oxford the degree of D.D. was conferred upon Dr. Benson, the Primate, "causâ honoris," on account of his high station, and on Dr. Schön, "honoris causâ," as a small acknowledgment of all his labour, his knowledge, and his devotion. Horace Waller', 'last_edit_date': None, 'num_tokens': 0, 'language': 'en', 'block_type': 'text', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/02_03_1896#article-3', 'issue_date': '02_03_1896', 'content': 'The Rev. Horace Waller, F.R.G.S., who died on Feb. 22, at East Liss, Hants, at the age of 63, was widely known as a strong opponent of slavery. His sympathies were chiefly directed to Africa, whither he went in 1861 in connexion with the founding of the first branch of the Universities' Missions to Central Africa in the regions that had just been explored by the efforts of Dr. Livingstone and Sir John Kirk. Mr. Waller was not then in orders, but he travelled out and afterwards worked with Bishop Mackenzie, being associated for some time also with Dr. Livingstone in the Zambesi and Shiré districts. Mr. Waller began life in a business house in London, and thus acquired a knowledge of the world and businesslike habits which often stood him in good stead. He was a close observer of nature and a keen sportsman, and his services to the mission were of the highest value. Returning to England on the death of Bishop Mackenzie, Mr. Waller took orders, and soon began to devote his energies to opposing the slave trade, an opposition which became one of the chief objects of his life. In 1867 he attended the British & Foreign Anti-Slavery Society's conference held in Paris in conjunction with the French and Spanish societies, and in 1870 he became a member of the Committee of the Society, an office which he retained to the time of his death. When, in 1871, the House of Commons decided to appoint a Select Committee to investigate the East African slave trade, it was owing mainly to the influence of Mr. Edmund Sturge, with Mr. Waller's assistance, that the Committee decided to recommend that the acting Political Agent at Zanzibar, Sir John Kirk, should receive the appointment of permanent Political Agent. This was followed in the course of 1873 by Sir Bartle Frere's anti-slavery mission to the East Coast of Africa, which eventually resulted in the treaty between the Sultan of Zanzibar and Great Britain which declared the slave trade by sea to be illegal. In the long-continued efforts made by Mr. Waller to put down the trade entirely, by means of letters in the columns of the newspapers, by pamphlets written for general circulation, and by speeches, he always emphasised the fact that by the treaty with Zanzibar in 1873 all slaves who had been imported into the islands since that date were illegally held in bondage, and when Zanzibar became a British protectorate his protests against what he called "slavery under the British flag" were redoubled. When Mr. H. M. Stanley succeeded in discovering Livingstone, the latter's voluminous journals were intrusted to the hands of Mr. Waller for publication, and were given to the public in two large volumes in 1875. The intimacy between Mr. Waller and the late General Gordon was of a very close and confidential kind, and it was in the rectory at Twywell that Gordon often sought a retreat from the pertinacious attention of correspondents anxious to obtain interviews with him. Mr. Waller had been rector of Twywell, Northants, since 1874. Before that he had held a curacy at Chatham and he had for four years been Vicar of Leytonstone. Last year Mr. Waller resigned his living at Twywell and removed to the more temperate climate of South Hants.'}]

Are we not at this moment most anxious to determine by positive observation whether there exists a great series of lakes and rivers proceeding, as Cooley has suggested, from Tanganyika on the north, to Lake Nyassa on the south? and has not Livingstone's very last effort been directed to this point? If central Africa is ever to advance in civilization, and its inhabitants are to be brought into commercial relations with Europe, one of the best chances of our accomplishing it will, in my opinion, consist in rendering the great White Nile a highway of intercourse and traffic. And if the present ruler of Egypt shall bring about this most desirable end, by putting a stop to the lawless slave-trade, carried on beyond his frontiers under the guise of dealing in ivory, and by establishing marts of commerce on the banks of the great river, Africa will owe more to him than to any ruler since the days of the Roman emperors, who, though they tried, never succeeded in opening out the regions around the head waters of the Nile. In touching upon this subject, I have to congratulate you on the news which has arrived, that that chivalrous explorer, Mr. Samuel Baker, is successfully examining the central equatorial regions, from which, I trust, he will bring us the solution of some of the problems already adverted to, and will determine the real source of the waters which supply the Luta N'zigé of Speke and Grant. I have also to announce that Baron Von der Decken has proceeded on his bold adventure to explore the interior of Africa from the east coast, by ascending the Juba, or one of the adjacent rivers, with two river steamers constructed at his own cost. In making these allusions to African discovery, most heartily do I congratulate geographers on the safe return of my excellent and disinterested friend Livingstone. Already, after his first two great traverses from east to west and from west to east across South Africa, this undaunted missionary has won for himself imperishable renown. But now, after a second expatriation which has lasted upwards of six years (his previous journeys occupying sixteen years), during which he has been labouring conjointly to improve the condition of the natives and to extend geographical knowledge, he comes home with a firm resolution to adhere to his noble calling for the benefit of the natives, and to return to that country in which every black man must bless his name. The return also of Captain Burton ensures for us some fresh and pregnant communications respecting Western Africa; and when we know that Francis Galton, though much occupied with the duties of a general secretary, will always take part in our discussions, and that Barth is likely to be present, it is probable that we shall have a concourse of travellers, capable of illustrating the geography and ethnology of Africa, such as was never assembled at any former meeting.", 'last_edit_date': '1864-09-23', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/23_09_1864#article-20', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.714, 'probability_score': 0.068, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'THE "COMING" CONTINENT.', 'section_title': '', 'content': 'In an article, entitled "Africa for Africans," published in a magazine issued in Washington, U.S.A., the vast possibilities of progress and development possessed by this continent are so eloquently and aptly set forth that we quote the passage *in extenso*:

"Africa is to-day the object of more interest on the part of a larger number of people than any other quarter of the globe. England, France, Portugal, Germany, and Italy are attempting to obtain titles to the country. England has made annexation of the coast lying adjacent to her colony of Sierra Leone; France is forcing her way on the Senegal and toward the head-waters of the Niger; she threatens to annex the coast from the Gaboon to the Congo, some 250 miles, and is running her lines on the Upper Congo. Her Chamber of Deputies has granted the De Brazza mission, by a vote of 449 to 3, a credit of a million and a quarter of francs. The Portuguese Government has appointed explorers and examined the Congo country, and assumes to exercise control over all the territory at the mouth of the Congo. The German Reichstag has increased its annual appropriation for the exploration of Africa. Italy has despatched a party to Abyssinia for geographical and mercantile purposes. She has also concluded treaties which promise to make Assab a centre of commerce. The Sultan of Morocco has authorized Spain to take possession of Santa Cruz del Mar, and the Sultan of Zanzibar has purchased six superior steamers to constitute a regular coast service, in the interest of commerce and for the suppression of the slave-trade. The International African Association, which owes its origin to the philanthropic initiative of Leopold II., King of the Belgians, has received large subscriptions and pushed forward exploring expeditions to start and equip the line of hospitable and scientific stations which are to bound the East and West Coast, and form a civilizing girdle around Central Africa. And the results following the explorations of Livingstone and Stanley and De Brazza are attracting the attention of the civilized world. What was a 'Dark Continent,' by the indomitable energy of these explorers, seems likely to prove the richest quarter of the globe. Not only does the land produce, with slight persuasion of tillage, admirable crops of cotton and coffee, but the soil is rich in diamonds on its southern coast, and in iron on its northern. Captain Burton has asserted that he knows nothing to equal the prodigious wealth of the land, even in California, or in the Brazils. 'Gold dust is panned by native women from the sands of the sea shore. Gold spangles glitter after showers in the streets of Axím. Gold is yielded by the lumps of yellow swish that rivet the wattle walls of hut and hovel.'"', 'last_edit_date': '1884-08-01', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/01_08_1884#article-11', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.696, 'probability_score': 0.067, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'The Late Dr. Livingstone', 'section_title': '', 'content': "wearing influence of exposure and privations. For three days preceding his death he had been wading through deep, marshy water, suffering at the same time from that great African enemy of life—dysentery; and he persevered until death put an end to his labours in the difficult field of African exploration. How far he has solved the geographical problems which motived his late persistent efforts, we, as yet, know not; but whether he has solved them or not, we cannot refrain from expressing our sorrow that the accomplished or attempted solution should have cost so valuable a life. For our own part, we had rather those problems should have remained unsolved for another century or two, than that he, who had already done so much for East Africa, should have thus miserably perished there, and been robbed by death of those honours and distinctions and that public esteem which would have surrounded the residue of his life with an aureole of glory. Livingstone, alas! is dead; but the great work that he inaugurated—war to the death against the atrocious East African foreign slave trade—will not perish. All that has of late been done by the British Government for its total suppression, owes its origin to the good Doctor's fearless and untiring exposure of the enormous sin and crime being daily perpetrated in those countries. If the heart of the British people has been at all stirred within them against the monster iniquity perpetrated by Arabs and Portuguese in those vast regions which they were depopulating by its practice, it was the voice and pen of Livingstone that stirred it. The influence he thus wielded for good will not have died with him. The emancipation of Eastern Africa, and its debased people, from the horrors that have held sway over and among them for many long centuries, will, sooner or later, be fully accomplished by the development of those agencies now at work with that object, and other agencies that will necessarily follow them; and when Eastern Africa attains to civilization and Christianity, one of the most honoured names—the central name on its monuments to those who have inaugurated and aided in the mighty work, will be—Livingstone.", 'last_edit_date': '1874-02-26', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/26_02_1874#article-15', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.742, 'probability_score': 0.07, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'GERMAN EXPEDITION TO AFRICA', 'section_title': '', 'content': 'BERLIN, March 13.—A committee has been formed among the members of the Berlin Geographical Society, and a plan has been drawn up in conjunction with the other Geographical Societies of Germany for the completion from the West Coast of Africa of the discoveries commenced by Dr. Livingstone from the East. The committee propose that the expedition should start from the West Coast south of the Equator. The funds for the proper equipment and maintenance of the expedition are already partly provided for.', 'last_edit_date': '1873-03-13', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/29_03_1873#article-15', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.706, 'probability_score': 0.068, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'The News of Dr. Livingstone', 'section_title': '', 'content': 'The hope which Sir Roderick Murchison has expressed that in the course of a few weeks news may reach England of Dr. Livingstone's arrival at Zanzibar, and that Dr. Livingstone himself may be among us to receive a Christmas greeting, will be shared by all to whom Dr. Livingstone's name is known. The latest dates of direct information with respect to the great traveller's movements and whereabouts will seem to the reader unversed in African distances and delays discouragingly remote. But there is no reason, Sir Roderick Murchison urges, for alarm. Notes written by Livingstone in October and November, 1867, from Marunga and Cazembe, places which lie S. and S.S.W. of Lake Tanganyika, have been received by Dr. Kirk at Zanzibar. Livingstone, it appears, when he last wrote, had been living for three months with a friendly Arab tribe, waiting for the close of a native war, before proceeding to Ujiji, with the intention of exploring Lake Tanganyika, and thence pushing on to Zanzibar. At Ujiji Livingstone would find provisions, medicine, letters, &c., and would learn the discoveries of Sir Samuel Baker. This information, Sir Roderick thinks, would induce him to attempt the solution of "the great problem of the Nilotic watershed of Africa, by determining whether the great lakes (Albert Nyanza and Tanganyika) are united or separated by highlands, and if separated, by ascertaining into what river-system Tanganyika discharges its surplus waters." Ten months would suffice, probably, to complete this work and to bring Livingstone to the seacoast. The report received by telegram from Bombay early in this month to the effect that Livingstone was within a week's journey of Zanzibar, confirms, and is itself confirmed by these probabilities, and increases the confidence with which we may look to see our great African explorer amongst us before the year is out.', 'last_edit_date': '1868-10-23', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/23_10_1868#article-26', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.677, 'probability_score': 0.066, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'REVIEW', 'section_title': '', 'content': 'Mr. Stanford's book fully justifies the title he has given to it. It is indeed a compendium. It places before us in brief but luminous sketches, and with the aid of sixteen admirable maps and some seventy illustrations, all that is publicly known about Africa and its peoples—their specific peculiarities, character, manners, customs, and condition, physical and moral; with enumeration of its varied products, its trade and commerce. It is an admirable volume for all who desire general information respecting that great continent, into the dense darkness of which the light of civilization and Christianity has begun to penetrate, through the devoted exertions of missionaries and scientific explorers. Africa does not present us with any very pleasing pictures. They are all of barbarism, and for the most part barbarism of the lowest and most disgusting type, and yet such as awakes and impels to active exertion the warmest sympathies and desires of the Christian and philanthropist. Such books as this of Mr. Stanford's are particularly valuable in view of the extremely limited degree of information respecting Africa possessed even by the majority of well-educated people in England. So many active agencies are now at work in and for Africa that some more intimate knowledge of it must be desired; while yet the labour of wading through long and dreary books of African travel, with their sadly monotonous succession of pictures of sparsely-inhabited countries, and of ignorance, suffering, cruelty, and moral degradation everywhere, deters most people from seeking it in their pages. This "Compendium" meets such desires, and gets rid of such difficulties, offering as a prize to be gained by a few leisure hours' reading all that it is essential well-educated people should know of this great continent. The degree of knowledge thus to be obtained may lead some whose attention has not hitherto been called in that direction to desires and sympathies with regard to that long-neglected quarter of the world, and its wretched populations. We therefore hail its appearance with great pleasure, and strongly recommend "Stanford's Compendium—Africa" to our readers. The educated Africans of the West Coast ought all to possess it, as in it they will see what Africa really is throughout, and the opinions current respecting it and themselves. Some of these opinions are not at all flattering, and wherever our friends can show them to be unjust we shall be glad to help in correcting them through our columns.', 'last_edit_date': '1878-04-01', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/01_04_1878#article-24', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.681, 'probability_score': 0.066, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'EASTERN AFRICA', 'section_title': '', 'content': "Dr. Livingstone's proposed expedition to the district between the north of Lake Nyassa and the south of Lake Tanganyika assumes a substantial form. CONSUL O'NEILL ON HIS DISCOVERIES IN EASTERN AFRICA.", 'section_title': '', 'content': 'Mr. Consul O'Neill delivered an address on July 8th, in Edinburgh, before the Geographical Society of Scotland, on his discoveries in Eastern Africa. After alluding to the services which Scotland has rendered to geographical science, especially in the person of Livingstone, Mr. O'Neill described the circumstances which induced him to resolve to fill up, as far as possible, the great blank in the map of Eastern Africa. The results of his journeys Mr. O'Neill summarised as follows:—

"Briefly, the chief results have been to open up three new routes between the Nyassa district and the coast: 1, between Mozambique and Lake Shirwa and Blantyre; 2, from Blantyre to the Portuguese settlements of Angoche and Parapato; 3, from Quillimane to Blantyre. You know the length of time it took to get overland to Lake Nyassa from the east coast. Many of you remember the hardships encountered by Bishop Steere when getting over the same ground. The Nyassa may now be reached by the longest route in thirty days, and by that from Quillimane to Blantyre in fourteen. His servant, Chumas, went on ahead to procure provisions, as the party was destitute, and gave intelligence to Cameron, who expected the body in a few days. Cameron and his party had suffered greatly from fever and ophthalmia, but hoped to push on to Ujiji. Livingstone's body may be expected at Zanzibar in February. Please telegraph orders as to disposal. No leaden shells procurable here."

hh: Media outlets like the African Times played a crucial role in shaping global perceptions and influencing colonial policies regarding African affairs during the 19th century.
result: The General History of Africa textbook and The African Times articles provide complementary insights into the role of media outlets in shaping global perceptions and influencing colonial policies regarding African affairs during the 19th century. The General History of Africa highlights the significant impact of newspapers, pamphlets, and journals in mobilizing anti-colonial sentiment and disseminating nationalist ideas across Africa, particularly during the inter-war period. These publications served as vital organs for anti-colonial propaganda and posed challenges for colonial administrators in controlling their influence. However, the textbook does not specifically mention the African Times in this context, listing it only among other publications without detailing its specific influence. In contrast, The African Times articles provide evidence supporting the claim that media outlets like the African Times played a crucial role in shaping perceptions and influencing colonial policies. The articles emphasize the African Times' efforts to advocate for African interests, expose abuses, and promote good governance in British African colonies, thereby influencing British public opinion. The publication is noted for its role in advocating for the Christian civilization and industrial development of Africa, indicating its impact on shaping perceptions. Despite the lack of explicit mention of direct influence on specific colonial policies, the African Times is portrayed as an important medium for raising awareness and advocating for African interests during the 19th century. Together, these sources suggest that while media outlets were indeed crucial in shaping perceptions and influencing policies, the specific role of the African Times in this process is more clearly articulated in its own articles than in the General History of Africa textbook.

THE DAHOMAN DEFEAT BEFORE ABEOKUTA.

The third expedition of the Dahomans against Abeokuta, and the second attack, has been made. The result of a great defeat such as the Dahomans have now sustained may be so important, that it behoves us to chronicle briefly the leading incidents of a struggle so honourable to the Egbas, so humiliating to the King of Dahomey and his notoriously vainglorious army.

the bearer of Mr. Stanley's letter, we find evidences of the beneficent influence of the change, so that scepticism is deprived of the power of saying, "It may be a gross exaggeration—it rests on Stanley's report alone." [{'document_title': 'OUR FIFTH VOLUME', 'section_title': '', 'content': 'In changing the form of our Journal, and adopting that in which it now appears, we have deferred to the oft-expressed wishes of many of our earliest and most constant friends. The African Times now occupies an acknowledged position as the registrar and exponent of native wants and progress, and the advocate of native interests, more especially on the West Coast. Our aim in the future will ever be, as it has been in the past, to make it practically useful; and we again solicit the support of all who have at heart the real welfare of native Africa and its people, both for this Journal and for the Society by which it was founded, and to whose efforts with Government and individuals so much of its power for good may be attributed. And more especially do we commend the African Times and the African-Aid Society to the warm and earnest support of the educated Africans of the West Coast. The African Times brings them, as well as their rulers, face to face with British public opinion, by which they have much to gain in the work to which we hope they all feel themselves pledged—viz., that of the Christian civilization of the whole African people, and the industrial development of those great natural resources with which Africa has been so liberally endowed.', 'last_edit_date': '1865-07-22', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/22_07_1865#article-10', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.717, 'probability_score': 0.068, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'Another Letter from Livingstone', 'section_title': '', 'content': 'Sir,—We cannot allow 1871 to pass away without expressing our gratefulness and high appreciation of the philanthropic feelings by which you are impelled to advocate the cause of Africa and her injured myriads from beneath the lash of official tyranny and oppression, and from the taunts, scoffs, and political venom of the negro-haters. When we review the history of our country from the time of the publication of that valuable journal of which you are the honoured editor—a periodical which stands eminent in consequence of the incalculable benefit it has conferred upon us—we say, when we contrast Africa's past with her present; when we look upon the many moral changes the African Times has effected, we could not but classify it amongst the means employed by Divine goodness towards the regeneration of a people who, according to the views of the anthropologist, are deprived of that vital essence which constitutes man the chief of God's creatures; hence with them the negro is calculated to be unfit for any other position than to become "a beast of burden and a beast for prey" to his more favoured brother. But the African Times has declared in the most forcible language that the negroes with the whites "are made of one blood," and are equally fitted to occupy the same position amongst the works of creation.

Not to enumerate its past achievements, the African Times, being animated with the most ardent zeal for our true interest, has contended with the Colonial-office in order to restore to Her Majesty African subjects that most inestimable benefit, which is the life of liberty, in the British Constitution, "trial by jury," which we cannot avoid lamenting. But in consequence of the credit attached in the Colonial-office to the representations of unprincipled officials, no hearing has been given to the reiterated', 'last_edit_date': '1872-08-28', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/23_10_1872#article-8', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.709, 'probability_score': 0.067, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'Close of Another Year of the "African Times"', 'section_title': '', 'content': "The curtain now falls over another year of the life of this journal. During eight years we have endeavoured to advocate in its columns, honestly, temperately, and fearlessly, the true interests of the West African countries, their people, and the merchants engaged in commerce with them. Great changes have taken place since the issue of the African Times commenced. The slave trade, which was then carrying off victims from the coasts of Dahomey and from the Congo, seems now to be entirely at an end, we hope and believe never to be again revived. At that period there was steam communication once a month between Liverpool and the West Coast ports; now, thanks to the establishment of the new line, there are four steam vessels to be despatched per month. This last important change ought to operate as a powerful stimulus to production and commerce, giving, as it will, so much greater facilities to the native traders to utilise their comparatively small capital in direct operation with Great Britain. With regard to the British settlements, trade and commerce cannot be expected to take their due development, until those administrative and judicial abuses which have been and will continue to be exposed and denounced by us shall have ceased. It cannot be said that life and property are safe in them while the authorities, executive and judicial, are guilty of the most illegal and arbitrary acts, and are allowed by the Colonial-office to perpetrate such acts with impunity instead of being immediately cashiered for them. But since this inclination on the part of the Home Government to throw the shield of its protection over culpable officials, rather than over the people among whom they exercise authority in its name, does unhappily exist, as recent facts most incontestably prove, it only becomes the more indispensable to create and organise a public opinion in the British settlements on the Coast that shall be powerful enough to secure for the governed a due attention to their grievances by Her Majesty's Secretary of State for the Colonies, and prompt redress at his hands. To this creation and organisation of an African public opinion our most strenuous efforts will be directed in the future, as they have been incessantly in the past; and looking at what we have done in this direction during the past eight years, we think we are justified in demanding a much more liberal support from all classes on the West Coast of Africa than we have hitherto received. We have endeavoured conscientiously and zealously, without fear or favour, to carry on the work which God has put it into our hearts and hands to do, and has therefore charged us with; and those for whose present protection and permanent interests we labour have a duty also to perform towards us. "Cape Coast, October 14.

"I am obliged still to make complaints of the non-arrival of subscribers' papers. We know that it is not your fault; but we hope your having noticed it, which, no doubt, you will have done, may lead to a better state of things. Many of your subscribers did not get their August number. Those who did get it were literally besieged by their friends, that they might see the fearless exposure made in your blessed columns of the villainous conduct of the military officers, and of other iniquities in these parts. Since the papers of the 22nd of August reached us, and its contents became public, many of the natives have expressed their determination to subscribe. This very day a resident of the town, a man of consequence, but who can neither read nor write, informed me that he was going to order the African Times, as he heard that it gave news about his country, and that he would get his son, a boy in the Mission School, to read it to him. The Editor will at all times be pleased to receive communications from subscribers and others in Africa, containing items of local or general news likely to be interesting to his readers. But he would point out that, to insure insertion, such communications must be authenticated with the name and address of the sender (not necessarily for publication, but as evidence of good faith); and that all letters must be prepaid, or they will have to be refused.

**The African Times.**

**SATURDAY, SEPTEMBER 1, 1888.**

**"OUR POLICY IN AFRICA."**

The following is extracted from a long article under the above heading which appeared in the *Times* of August 22:—

We have lost all interest in the Congo since the geographical ignorance and foolish sentimentality of the House of Commons burked the Treaty with Portugal and brought about the Congress of Berlin. In Western Africa our sphere of influence is confined to the Guinea Coast and the Niger Basin. Here, however, we have quite sufficient to occupy our attention and our enterprise. Our actual possessions in West Africa are limited to the Gambia River, the Sierra Leone Colony, the Gold Coast, Lagos, the Oil Rivers, and the Niger and Binué.

What we want is concentration and the filling up of the gaps in the coast line. We must abandon the now useless Gambia, annex or protect the Ivory Coast, eastwards of Liberia, acquire by friendly arrangement the French possessions on the Gold Coast and on the slave coast, get the Germans to exchange Togoland for Walfisch Bay, replace the Portuguese in the protectorate of the Dahomey coast which they have abandoned, and we shall then possess the entire seaboard of West Africa, with the exception of Liberia, from Sierra Leone to the German boundary in Cameroons. Any one will see that this is not a very large operation, and it may be effected by coming to terms with the French. Indeed, it would be well to make some arrangement with the French on the west such as the agreement we made with Germany on the east, by which the sphere of each Power is defined and both nations can continue their work quietly and without dread of each other's encroachments. France might take the left bank of the River Niger as far as Timbuctoo, and we the right bank as our boundary, and from a point on the Upper Niger near Falaba the frontier could be carried to the Little Scarcies River and to the sea, thus cutting off a small portion of the present Sierra Leone colony. We should then be enabled to offer the French the Gambia River, the Isles...', 'last_edit_date': '1888-09-01', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/01_09_1888#article-9', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.688, 'probability_score': 0.066, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'ADDRESS BY THE EDITOR TO SUBSCRIBERS AND FRIENDS OF THE "AFRICAN TIMES."', 'section_title': '', 'content': 'A combined and powerful attack has been lately made upon the African Times, to destroy its existence, if possible, and deprive the educated African people and their less advanced countrymen of that power of appeal to the public opinion of Great Britain which they now possess through its columns. The upholders of African abuses, mercantile and administrative, brought so strong a pressure to bear upon the African-Aid Society itself, that the Editor of the African Times could only preserve its existence for Africa by assuming the proprietorship of it. This he could not do without pecuniary sacrifices, and, in order to mitigate these, he calls upon every subscriber who is in arrear with his subscriptions to remit the amount due, and one year's further subscription in advance. Beyond this, any donations to the "African Times" to assist the Editor in his responsible task, will be thankfully acknowledged in the columns of this journal.

The change in the heading of our paper, and in other portions of it, will show our subscribers that this journal now stands unfettered by any nominal, and, as circumstances have proved, precarious support of a society. The African-Aid Society has, in point of fact, absolutely ceased to exist, though it was not in any way in pecuniary difficulties, but possessed a considerable surplus. We shall give a full account of all the proceedings connected therewith in the first number of our sixth volume, which, D.V., will be published on the 23rd of July, for the West African mail, as usual; and we hope our services to Africa have been so felt among our subscribers and readers on the West Coast and elsewhere in Africa, and also in England, that our friends will come forward to our help without delay.

During that period the whole of the anxiety, labour, and responsibility, both public and pecuniary, which it has involved, have been borne by one individual, the Editor. When first started, he undertook, subject to the condition of a certain number of copies being subscribed for individually by some members of the Council of the African-Aid Society, that it should never involve that society in any pecuniary loss or responsibility. Contrary to his opinion as to the conditions under which a public journal could be successfully conducted, and submitted to by him solely with the object of facilitating its establishment, a committee of a few members of the council of that society was appointed to meet monthly, prior to its publication, for considering the articles, &c., which the Editor had decided to insert. But to this the Editor attached a stipulation that he would not consent to any alterations of which he did not himself fully approve, and which he did not consider advisable or innocuous. Such a committee of course could not work, and the Editor freed himself almost immediately from the nominal restriction, which only served to increase the difficulty of bringing out the paper on the proper day, without effecting any useful purpose whatever. A perfect and entire independence of thought and opinion in the editor is essential to the success of any and every public journal. During five years, therefore, the whole labour and responsibility have, as before stated, rested with one individual, the present Editor. Such an anniversary as this is therefore a solemn one with us. The objects the Editor has endeavoured ever to keep in view have been the promotion of good government in the British African colonies and settlements, to force a removal of official abuses, to promote material development and increased facilities of transit and trade, as auxiliaries to missionary effort, and as indispensable, not to the reception of Christianity, but to the existence and spread of Christian civilization in Africa. Having entered upon this work with a deep sense of responsibility to God, we feel bound to ask ourselves how that work has been performed. With the measure and extent of its success we have nothing to do, that we leave in the hands of Him who worketh through individual agencies on the earth, according to His own infinite wisdom. But have we done our duty by the African people, and have they, on their side, done their duty towards us? As regards the former, we can only look to our motives and our desires. We have endeavoured to keep a watchful guard over ourselves as "one who must give an account before God," and we have, with no small sacrifice of time and rest, conscientiously striven to give to Africa in our labours whatever talent or wisdom God may have bestowed upon us for that purpose. As regards the latter, we think we have cause of rejoicing rather than of complaint. The number of our African subscribers has continuously increased, filling up, in a way most satisfactory to us, the gaps in our subscription list caused by the withdrawals of those of our early friends who considered, we suppose, that no further effort on their part was necessary to our support. And we have given a voice—a public voice to Africa. Few people in England, unfortunately, care much about her or her concerns. The English Anti-Slavery party, fully occupied in their high and noble object of the eradication of negro slavery everywhere, have not yet had time generally to recognise the importance of paving the way, and preparing for, and aiding in the work of Christian civilization in Africa itself. It has been the endeavour of the Conductors of this paper, ever since its establishment in 1860, to promote the improvement and advancement—social, commercial, and religious—of the people of Africa, and in their efforts they have been loyally assisted by many well-wishers to the African race. FERNANDO PO.

**AUGUST!**  
TO THE EDITOR OF THE AFRICAN TIMES.

Sir,—Mr. Beecher Stowe has said that there is something in the character of the African race which will in no distant future develop a higher phase of civilisation than any as yet known in the history of the world. I rejoice in the columns of your valuable journal to print the sacred prophecy of this gifted woman, and I know that the *African Times* will not be wanting in every exertion towards the fulfilment of this prophecy. If it ever perish for want of it, while, as now, faithful in its mission, disgrace to those who shall have allowed it to perish. And here we must say one word to the educated Africans of the West Coast. They have recognised, and are recognising, by their subscriptions to this paper, the importance to them of the African Times. But they have not as yet done anything for the support of The Society whose influence makes that journal a power. In future every subscription will be published in this paper. hh: Colonial journalism in British Western Africa struggled to report injustices and corruption due to accusations of bias, local opposition, and the risk of libel.
result: The observations from the General History of Africa textbook and The African Times news articles provide a nuanced view of the challenges faced by colonial journalism in British Western Africa. The General History of Africa highlights the role of newspapers in promoting nationalist and anti-colonial activities, which concerned colonial administrators and led to the implementation of sedition laws in the mid-1930s. This suggests that colonial journalism was active in reporting injustices and corruption, focusing on political and economic reforms and the formation of organizations like the National Congress of British West Africa. However, the textbook does not specifically mention accusations of bias, local opposition, or the risk of libel as obstacles, indicating a divergence from the claim. In contrast, The African Times articles provide detailed accounts supporting the claim, emphasizing the challenges of accusations of bias, local opposition, and the risk of libel. The African Times faced criticism for both concealing wrongs and daring to interfere, highlighting the delicate balance in reporting sensitive issues. The risk of libel was evident in their cautious approach to publishing details of criminal cases and the costly libel proceedings initiated by Captain Rattray. Despite these challenges, the African Times demonstrated a commitment to exposing corruption and injustices, underscoring their role as public guardians of humanity and progress. Together, these sources illustrate the complex landscape of colonial journalism, where determination to report injustices coexisted with significant obstacles.

However, the text does not specifically mention accusations of bias, local opposition, or the risk of libel as obstacles faced by journalists. Instead, it emphasizes the role of newspapers in advocating for political and economic reforms and the formation of organizations like the National Congress of British West Africa. The absence of specific references to accusations of bias or libel in the textbook indicates a difference from the claim, suggesting that while colonial journalism faced challenges, these were not necessarily centered around bias or libel as the claim suggests.

For instance, the publication was criticized for both concealing wrongs and daring to interfere, indicating a delicate balance in reporting sensitive issues. Additionally, the articles mention the risk of libel, as seen in the decision to refrain from publishing certain details of a criminal case due to potential identification and legal repercussions. The African Times also faced legal threats, such as the libel proceedings initiated by Captain Rattray, which resulted in a costly settlement. These examples illustrate the challenges colonial journalists encountered in exposing corruption and injustices, aligning with the claim. However, the articles also show the African Times' commitment to reporting these issues despite the risks, suggesting a determination to fulfill their role as public guardians of humanity and progress. This determination, despite the challenges, adds a nuanced perspective to the claim.

[{'id': 340, 'article_title': 'CAPE COAST.', 'full_section_title': 'CAPE COAST.', 'last_edit_date': '04-11-1864', 'num_tokens': 0, 'language': 'en', 'block_type': 'text', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/23_05_1864#article-5', 'issue_date': '23_05_1864', 'content': 'We never felt so deeply as now the weight of the work that we have undertaken, and the heavy load of responsibility that rests on us as the public guardians of the cause of humanity and progress in British Western Africa. We do not publish a tithe of the revelations that are constantly reaching us. We exclude, as far as possible, everything that is personal. We are reproached, on the one hand, for the concealment of wrongs done; we are abused, on the other, for daring to interfere at all; and even where we have been giving praise, our praises are rejected with contumely, because (as in the unwarrantable attack on us by Mr. Commissary Blanc) some associates have justly been complained of.

We have on the present occasion given more than usual prominence to complaints. Among these there are some charges of a very heavy nature. The revelations as regards Cape Coast, the gaol, and the administration of justice!! are horrible. If true, speedy redress is imperative; and we know of no way of eliciting the truth save that recommended and urged by the man who denounces the iniquities—viz., that a commissioner be sent down expressly to make due inquiry on oath as to the truth or falsehood of the incriminations.'}, {'id': 2900, 'article_title': 'SLAVE-HOLDING AND SLAVE-MURDER AT FERNANDO PO', 'full_section_title': 'SLAVE-HOLDING AND SLAVE-MURDER AT FERNANDO PO', 'last_edit_date': None, 'num_tokens': 0, 'language': 'en', 'block_type': 'text', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/01_07_1875#article-14', 'issue_date': '01_07_1875', 'content': 'Dogberry insisted that his fellow-official should "write him down an ass." There are many people who choose rather to perform this operation for themselves. In another part of this number will be found a letter from Fernando Po, complaining of our insertion of a communication from that place in our March number, and our leading article thereon, which was headed "Murder—the Humane Character of Domestic Slavery." If we had needed in our mind any further confirmation of the propriety of what we did in inserting that letter, or of the justice and necessity of what we wrote in the article in question, we should have found them abundantly in this letter. We have but too often reason to complain of being furnished by West African correspondents with information of actions and events that must necessarily have a sequence or result, which ought to be equally made known to us, but of which we never hear a word. Our correspondents write on the spur of the moment, and forget that they thereby contract with us an obligation on their part to complete in due time their information. Happily, however, this has not been the course pursued by our informant of Fernando Po, whose letter we published in our March number. This was followed in due time by another from him, which we inserted in our last (June) number, and which gave us the sequel of the slave-murder charge. We commented also on this letter in our last, and earnestly request of our readers that they will read our said comments again, in the light now thrown upon the matter by our new correspondent, Mr. W. W. Jackson. Mr. Jackson, after expressing some of that "virtuous indignation" to which we last month alluded, both at our correspondent's letter (which we beg leave to inform him was not an anonymous one, or it would not have found a place in our columns) and at our comments, proceeds to say, "Now that the trial is over, you will perhaps be good enough to allow me to state the plain unvarnished facts, which are these: Mrs. Gardiner—who, by the way, is a native—had a black servant-girl, aged about twelve years, and, as any one knows who has had experience upon the Coast, the blacks require firm treatment and occasional chastisement to keep them in their places. Mrs. Gardiner corrected (!) her servant one day, and the girl afterwards expired. The medical examination, such as it was, went to prove that the girl—who, though young, bore a very bad character—was suffering from several diseases, and these were the cause of death, although the proper punishment (!) administered by Mrs. Gardiner hastened the girl's decease." The comments that we should make on this very precious statement are so obvious that we deem it unnecessary to record them, further than that, knowing what we do of the West Coast, they completely establish the truth of the statement we published in March. "Mrs. Gardiner corrected her servant one day, and the girl afterwards expired." "Diseases were the cause of death, but they were hastened by the proper punishment administered by Mrs. Gardiner." Here we have the old slaveholder's vindication of atrocities committed on the bodies of slaves, with which, in days happily gone by, we were, alas! but too painfully familiar. We were never advocates of the lex talionis, but if we could be tempted to approve of it, it would be in such a case as this of Mrs. Gardiner and her "servant-girl." Our impugned correspondent showed us what that "proper punishment" inflicted by Mrs. Gardiner really was; and if it shocked any one, which we hope and believe it did, by its horrid brutality, the fault was not that of our correspondent, but that of Mrs. Gardiner, whose sensitive feelings we can happily, have no fear of wounding, supported as she is by the love and admiration of her Fernando Po compeers, European and native, including Mr. Jackson; for this, it appears, is Mrs. Gardiner's present status there. We will give Mr. Jackson's own words: "These are the facts, and they are vastly similar to many cases of the kind at home." We did not know this, and regret that Mr. Jackson has not given us a few instances, especially as combined with the sequence stated in the following words: "Mrs. Gardiner is still living here, and, instead of being execrated, as one would imagine from your correspondent's letter she would be, is respected and sympathized with as before;" and to this he adds: "The attempt to mislead yourselves, and to create a fearful impression at home regarding our social life here, cannot be too strongly reprobated." Does not the view of Fernando Po society which this opens to us fully justify our last month's leader, in which we referred to the outcry against us there? Mr. Jackson has confirmed, in his peculiar way, all that our correspondent had written to us; and we have not one word to unsay as to the state of demoralization that prevails among the small knots of European traders that carry on their mercantile operations in obscure parts of the West Coast, such as Fernando Po for example. And now we would remind Mr. Jackson that there is something else that "cannot be too strongly reprobated," and that is the studied endeavour to mislead us by an ex parte statement, that conceals the most important facts of the case. It was most likely thought at Fernando Po that the "virtuous indignation" expressed there at our correspondent for having written to us, and at our comments, would have sufficed to prevent any further communication being made to us about the trial. Mr. Jackson, therefore, has so written that, had we not been better informed, we might have inferred from his letter that Mrs. Gardiner had been absolved in the judicial inquiry, and was, therefore, an object of respect and sympathy. He does not, therefore, say one word of the condemnation, the exile, the new Governor, the new King, the amnesty which embraced her as well as other criminals, and the return to Fernando Po. Our first correspondent, whom he censures, must therefore be regarded as far more trustworthy than himself, as he certainly is far more deserving of honour in sympathizing with the poor dead victim than with the living aggressor. We are inclined to believe that Mr. Jackson must be a very young man, or we should not have heard of him in this matter. Warm as the indignation against us has been in Fernando Po, we fancy there must have been something more than this to induce him to thrust his paw, or allow his paw to be thrust into this fire, that he might pull out the Gardiners' chestnuts. He is certainly entitled to Mr. Gardiner's generosity and to Mrs. Gardiner's smiles, since it is not his fault if he has failed in the hazardous attempt. If we possessed the power attributed to some of the wonderful magicians whose feats are recorded in the veracious stories of "The Thousand and One Nights," we should certainly exercise it by metamorphosing him into a little servant or slave girl to Mrs. Gardiner, when we should have but little fear of his meeting his just reward, and arriving at a full appreciation of the characters of those who respect her and sympathize with her for having, by carrying her "proper punishment" too far, deprived herself of all future pleasure in torturing her helpless victim. Our sympathy—wretch, no doubt, that we are!—is with the dead slave, and not with the living mistress. In one thing, however, we do rejoice, and we have to thank Mr. Jackson for our joy. Mrs. Gardiner is not an European, but a native. We are sorry the same thing cannot be said of Mr. Gardiner, who, if he has any legitimate power over Mrs. Gardiner, ought to have prevented her from thus atrociously chastising her defenceless slave-girl. Mr. Jackson winds up by saying that "any suggestion to make this slave-holding and slave-slaughter a matter for the Foreign Office cannot be commended on the grounds either of reason or common sense, and that Lord Derby will do well to leave the matter to fade into the obscurity from which it ought never to have been brought." In order that our readers may have some idea of the difficulties in the way of journalism where evils and errors are to be exposed with a view to effect a salutary change, we may state briefly what then occurred. We expurgated the chief communication we had received, which was a long report of a criminal case brought before one of the Courts, and incidents in the trial. We did not name the Court, nor the presiding Judge, nor the parties concerned. But it was held by our publishers that there was sufficient to lead to identification; and that, therefore, as “the greater the truth the greater the libel,” they could not take the risk of allowing it to appear in our columns. We had no resource but to bow to the decision, and refrain from publishing it. As it was strongly confirmative of what we had stated in our leader above alluded to, we can scarcely say that we submitted with a good grace. And yet, considering the small amount of support received by us from the West Coast, where comparatively so few of our nominal subscribers think it necessary to pay for the African Times, we can have no doubt they were right in preventing us as well as themselves from incurring any risk of the expense of defending an action for libel. At the same time, we feel it to be quite impossible to submit to entire silence, and, without therefore stating any of the particulars that were considered objectionable, we will merely give a short description of the *modus operandi* observed in obtaining a verdict. “When this

witness for the defence stated a fact that was important for the prosecution, the solicitor for the defence winked to the interpreter (the gentleman setting as Judge knowing nothing of the language), who did not interpret it at all. The solicitor then winked to the Judge, who thereupon said, 'Court adjourned for half an hour!' The jurors then marched respectively in pairs to partake of refreshments, with sparkling moselle, &c., prepared for them by the said solicitor. On the reappearance of all parties in Court, after a few words of badinage by the solicitor, there were also a few from the Judge, concluding with, 'But I do not mean that you should find these parties guilty!' and the jury obediently acquitted them." It may be said, perhaps, the jury were right. But if we could publish the whole case, it would be seen in a moment that they were wrong, and that this was well known to those who induced the jury to return such a verdict. After our last month's leader we do not think it necessary to make any further observations on the above, merely adding that we could wish the report of the case as we have it were in the hands of the Secretary of State for the Colonies, to whom, however, it does not belong to us to forward it.'}, {'id': 4517, 'article_title': 'The Alleged Drowning of Kroomen', 'full_section_title': 'The Alleged Drowning of Kroomen', 'last_edit_date': None, 'num_tokens': 0, 'language': 'en', 'block_type': 'text', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/01_11_1882#article-14', 'issue_date': '01_11_1882', 'content': 'Our readers will find in another column evidence of the perils which beset journalism even when conducted with the greatest caution and the most earnest desire to do good unmixed with evil. When we copied from the Monrovia Observer, and published in our September number, with some editorial comments, the statement of the alleged throwing overboard of Kroomen from the mail steamer Biafra, we prefaced the one with the question, "Can this be true?" and stated in the other our willingness to publish any contradiction by the officers of the steamer or the Company to which the steamer belongs. We should not have copied the statement into our paper, but that it stated, "the men were landed at Monrovia, many of them entirely naked." Now, Monrovia is not a very large place, and as it had long seemed to us that the Monrovia Observer was most respectably and carefully conducted, we naturally supposed that the Editor had satisfied himself of the truth of the very serious allegations. In this it appears that we were altogether in error, and were thus innocently led into inflicting pain upon the Captain of the steamer. Those who know us personally would understand how deeply this would grieve us. Instead, however, of availing himself of the offer contained in our leader, Captain Rattray placed the matter in the hands of his Attorney in Liverpool, and we received a letter from them, threatening us with proceedings for libel, and our Printer also, unless we published in our next number a refutation of the charge, with our apologies for its insertion and for our comments. We replied immediately, that nothing could have given us greater pleasure than the assurance that the alleged circumstance never occurred, and that we were ready to publish any letter of Captain Rattray to this effect, supplementing it with expression of our most sincere and heartfelt regret that we should have given publicity to so false a statement. We received a reply that this was unsatisfactory, and that unless we agreed fully to their demands to publish whatever they might send to us in contradiction, with the most ample apology, and agreed to pay all costs, proceedings would be commenced immediately. We were not in London on the Saturday to receive this, and our Printer wrote them to this effect, but when we found it on the Monday we reiterated by post our willingness to do all that could be reasonably required to atone for our unintentional offence. But a writ had been already issued on that Monday, and we were served with it on Tuesday, just after we had written what we intended to insert, with the purpose of sending it by that day's post. But on receiving the writ, we placed the matter in the hands of our Solicitors, Messrs. Hollams, Son, and Coward, to effect a settlement, when what appears in another column was agreed upon and accepted as satisfactory, on our payment of costs. In making this statement of facts to show our African readers the perils to which we are exposed in our labours for Africa, we again repeat our deep and sincere regret for any pain we may have caused Captain Rattray by the reproduction of the falsehood in our columns, while, at the same time, stating that we should have done this without any legal proceedings on his part, which have thus inflicted on us a heavy and unnecessary expense. We cannot, however, acquit the Editor of the Monrovia Observer of blame in this matter, and we think he owes us an apology as full and sincere as that which we have given to Captain Rattray, and which, we repeat, we should have given upon a simple statement and demand had such been made direct to us by him.'}]
