[{'document_title': 'The Congo and Central Africa Company', 'section_title': '', 'content': 'Before our leader of last month on this important subject went to press, we had received further communications from the West Coast of a nature to give especial point to our observations therein made. In order that our readers may have some idea of the difficulties in the way of journalism where evils and errors are to be exposed with a view to effect a salutary change, we may state briefly what then occurred. We expurgated the chief communication we had received, which was a long report of a criminal case brought before one of the Courts, and incidents in the trial. We did not name the Court, nor the presiding Judge, nor the parties concerned. But it was held by our publishers that there was sufficient to lead to identification; and that, therefore, as “the greater the truth the greater the libel,” they could not take the risk of allowing it to appear in our columns. We had no resource but to bow to the decision, and refrain from publishing it. As it was strongly confirmative of what we had stated in our leader above alluded to, we can scarcely say that we submitted with a good grace. And yet, considering the small amount of support received by us from the West Coast, where comparatively so few of our nominal subscribers think it necessary to pay for the African Times, we can have no doubt they were right in preventing us as well as themselves from incurring any risk of the expense of defending an action for libel. At the same time, we feel it to be quite impossible to submit to entire silence, and, without therefore stating any of the particulars that were considered objectionable, we will merely give a short description of the *modus operandi* observed in obtaining a verdict. “When this

witness for the defence stated a fact that was important for the prosecution, the solicitor for the defence winked to the interpreter (the gentleman setting as Judge knowing nothing of the language), who did not interpret it at all. The solicitor then winked to the Judge, who thereupon said, 'Court adjourned for half an hour!' The jurors then marched respectively in pairs to partake of refreshments, with sparkling moselle, &c., prepared for them by the said solicitor. On the reappearance of all parties in Court, after a few words of badinage by the solicitor, there were also a few from the Judge, concluding with, 'But I do not mean that you should find these parties guilty!' and the jury obediently acquitted them." It may be said, perhaps, the jury were right. But if we could publish the whole case, it would be seen in a moment that they were wrong, and that this was well known to those who induced the jury to return such a verdict. After our last month's leader we do not think it necessary to make any further observations on the above, merely adding that we could wish the report of the case as we have it were in the hands of the Secretary of State for the Colonies, to whom, however, it does not belong to us to forward it.', 'last_edit_date': '1882-05-01', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/01_05_1882#article-10', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.698, 'probability_score': 0.067, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'The African Times', 'section_title': '', 'content': "The Queen's Speech at the opening of Parliament on February 9 contained nothing very striking or original. Ireland and her troubles is still the great rock ahead of all political progress, but one need not be very sanguine to hope that the proceedings of the present Session will be more satisfactory and to the point than was that of 1887. One sentence in the Speech is of special interest to all our readers—we allude to that referring to the improving prospects of commerce. For years now all branches of trade—both home and foreign—have been in an abnormally depressed condition; but at last there seems to be a general consensus of opinion that on all sides things are beginning to show signs of improvement. There is one subject that we should have liked to see mentioned in the Queen's Speech, but which was conspicuous by its absence—the state of things on the West Coast of Africa, with special reference to the deposition and exile of King Ja Ja, and our lately-assumed Protectorate of the Oil Rivers. However necessary the political effacement of King Ja Ja may have been, and readily granting, for the sake of argument, that the new order of things is as greatly to the advantage of the native trader as to that of the European merchant, there are many persons, even outside the limits of those directly concerned in African commerce, who not unreasonably consider that Ja Ja has been harshly treated by the British authorities. In all probability, his own condition is rather improved.

Yet still the whole subject ought to be fairly and frankly discussed, if we would have the native continue to look to the British with confidence for protection and fair play.", 'last_edit_date': '1888-03-01', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/01_03_1888#article-12', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.679, 'probability_score': 0.066, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'THE "AFRICAN TIMES" AND THE AUTHORITIES AT LAGOS.', 'section_title': '', 'content': 'We find that complaint is made at Lagos of the article in our February number, relative to the non-delivery in Lagos of our journal of the 23rd November. We are accused of undue and intemperate haste in charging any of the colonial authorities with the suppression of our paper on that occasion, and condemned for writing as if there was a certainty about it, when there not only was no certainty at all, but, moreover, when the thing really had not taken place. We are told we ought to have waited, and made proper inquiry, and then we should have found there was no truth whatever in the statement. We do not think we were unduly hasty. We did not act upon a single testimony. We received letters from several of our subscribers complaining of the alleged fact; and it was, we believe, the first time such a thing had occurred; and there did happen to be in the November number, also for the first time, certain matter which might not be quite agreeable to the authorities. The papers had been duly
**125**

posted in England, and the papers were not duly delivered in Lagos. We were therefore justified in writing on the supposition that they had been purposely withheld from our subscribers. And what is now the explanation we have indirectly received? "The greater portion of the November number of the 'African Times' arrived in December, and the two numbers for November and December were delivered together to the various subscribers," i.e., we presume, if words mean anything, that the November papers which arrived in Lagos in December, were detained at the Post-office there until the December papers arrived in January, and then the papers of the two months were delivered to the subscribers at the same time. We can only say in reply that under such circumstances our subscribers who did not receive the November papers in December were fully justified in believing that they had been suppressed, and in writing to us to that effect. Niger Mission—A Warning to Native Merchants', 'section_title': '', 'content': '## A WARNING TO NATIVE MERCHANTS.

### TO THE EDITOR OF "THE AFRICAN TIMES."

Sir,—Will you permit me space in your pages to show some of my brethren on the West Coast how I have been swindled by a firm of professing merchants in London, in the hope that a relation of my experience may be of service to others, and cause them to make all needful inquiries as to the good faith and solvency of those to whom they are thinking of consigning goods for realisation in the London markets, or money for purchase of goods for Africa.

In May last year I received letters from a firm dating from the City, offering to do business with me, whether in the way of realisation or purchase, and professing to have exceptional facilities for the disposal of African produce, and the purchase of European goods in exchange. They made such a plausible tale that I was quite taken with them, and forwarded a box of gold dust, together with samples of goods I wanted in return. This came duly into their hands, and I received an acknowledgment from them with a statement showing that the gold dust had realised £56 10s. 10d., but that the goods I required would cost a good deal more than that. I accordingly obtained and forwarded to them a draft, making in all £97 10s. 2d.; at the same time sending them my gold watch (value £7) for cleaning and repairs in London. This second remittance was also acknowledged in due course—and there the matter ended! Finding weeks go by, and nothing come to hand, I wrote to a firm in London, upon whose integrity I can rely, for them to inquire into the matter, and do the best they could—either in the way of getting back my money or by urging these people to hurry on with the goods, so that I might not entirely lose the market. They accordingly wrote to the firm in question several times, but only to receive vague promises of immediate attention, or still more evasive answers. So I determined myself to come to London to see what could be done. And the upshot of my inquiries is that the firm to whom I had consigned my money and goods have proved utter swindlers: they traded under a fancy name, and when they found things were getting too hot for them they left the country, so as to be beyond the reach of the law.

For myself I must make up my mind to cut my loss; as I understand that even if I could get hold of the swindlers there is no chance of my regaining any portion of what they have had from me. But I hope my experience will be of some use to others who, trading on the West Coast of Africa, are under the necessity of trusting so much to persons or firms in London or the other European capitals.—Yours faithfully,', 'last_edit_date': '1891-06-01', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/01_06_1891#article-10', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.673, 'probability_score': 0.066, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'TRIBUTE TO THE "AFRICAN TIMES."', 'section_title': '', 'content': '[We cannot refrain from making the following brief extracts from the letter of a valued correspondent. Our aim is "the good of Africa," and we are glad to see that our efforts are appreciated in Africa, as it is only by the co-operation of enlightened Africans that "the good" can be effected.—Ed. A. T.]

"Cape Coast, October 14.

"I am obliged still to make complaints of the non-arrival of subscribers' papers. We know that it is not your fault; but we hope your having noticed it, which, no doubt, you will have done, may lead to a better state of things. Many of your subscribers did not get their August number. Those who did get it were literally besieged by their friends, that they might see the fearless exposure made in your blessed columns of the villainous conduct of the military officers, and of other iniquities in these parts. Since the papers of the 22nd of August reached us, and its contents became public, many of the natives have expressed their determination to subscribe. This very day a resident of the town, a man of consequence, but who can neither read nor write, informed me that he was going to order the African Times, as he heard that it gave news about his country, and that he would get his son, a boy in the Mission School, to read it to him. The interest in it is increasing every month. There is now a perfect rush for it when the mail arrives. Most of the numbers that were permitted to reach their owners by last mail are now so much pulled about as to be perfectly illegible," &c., &c., &c.', 'last_edit_date': '1863-11-23', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/23_11_1863#article-6', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.7, 'probability_score': 0.067, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'THE AFRICAN TIMES.', 'section_title': '', 'content': "A subscriber at the West Coast thus writes to us:—

TO THE EDITOR OF THE AFRICAN TIMES.

Sir,—Enclosed please receive 10s., being amount for the subscription for the African Times for the next two years. I have read in your invaluable number that, owing to the irregularity or non-payment of subscribers, and fraud of the gentlemen agents, you had deemed it expedient to discontinue the publishing of the African Times, and you only volunteer this last year; and should there not be any advancement shown, its termed suspension will be totally absolute. I regret, Sir, to see and hear how you have been treated; and now I implore you not to discontinue the publishing of such an invaluable African paper, because through it the griefs of Africa are made known in Europe and brought before Her Majesty's Government, and our wants are greatly repaired. The thanks which you should have received from my African brethren ought to have been boundless, and it is their duty to assist you to help the progress of the paper, as well as the enlargement of it. result: The late 19th century is often characterized as a transformative period in urban development and cultural practices, marked by the adoption of electric lighting, which enhanced safety, visibility, and entertainment, reflecting a societal shift towards embracing technological advancements. However, the "General History of Africa" textbook does not provide direct evidence or details supporting this claim within the African context. While it discusses various technological advancements and modernization efforts, such as the introduction of telephones, railways, and printing presses, it does not specifically mention electric lighting or its impact on safety, visibility, and entertainment. This absence suggests that electric lighting may not have been a significant or documented factor in Africa during this period, at least within the scope of the textbook. In contrast, The African Times news articles provide several details supporting the claim, describing the use of electric lighting in various contexts, such as the first use of Edison and Maxim lights in a London church, which enhanced visibility and ambiance during services. The articles also highlight the illumination of the Montreal Ice Carnival and an exhibition in Cape Town with electric lights, indicating their role in enhancing public events and entertainment. Additionally, the articles discuss the potential of electric railways and the application of electricity in various domains, underscoring the broader technological advancements of the era. However, they do not specifically address the impact of electric lighting on urban safety, which is a notable difference from the claim. Overall, while the African context in the textbook does not align with the claim, the articles illustrate the widespread adoption of electric lighting and its influence on cultural practices and urban development in other regions.

For example north of the Senegal basin increased exports of gum arabic allowed a zawiya lineage, whose members specialized in Islamic scholarship and the mediation of disputes and organized trading caravans to escales on the Senegal river to gain in power and influence.19 In the area north of the Sokoto caliphate the rise ofexports ofostrich feathers and tanned goat skins in the last thirty years of the century forced nomadic ruling classes to adjust to the new¬ found ability of peasants and servile agriculturalists to earn income from collecting and selling these products.20 European economic penetration also affected the tastes of consumers, so that the custom of drinking heavily sugared tea spread during the century.', 'last_edit_date': None, 'url': None, 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.508, 'probability_score': 0.05, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'The social repercussions of colonial rule: the new social structures', 'section_title': 'Change and continuity', 'content': 'Nor is the \'traditional-modern\' polar model, with all its attendant implications of conflict and incompatibility, applicable to the entire spectrum of African experience of change under colonialism. There were manifold variations in the reaction of African cultures to western innova› tions. Not only were certain customs and beliefs discarded or modified, but some were retained at one level of society at the same time as new alternatives were being accepted at another level. Thus while human sacrifice, the slave trade and the killing of twins were discarded in societies where such practices had existed, and old and new ideas were amalgamated in the sphere of religion, the European ideal of monogamous marriage, accepted as part of an expected public image by sections of the westernized elite, exists side by side under the law with the institution of polygamy among the urban and rural masses. Today we have existing side by side in Africa indigenous and European architectural traditions; local ethnicity and nationalism; local and regional-locked economies and a notional money economy; rural and urban life; western bureaucratic institutions and traditional local authorities; Ku\'ranic and Western schools.\nThus with ease many indigenous African institutions and ideas survived the impact of, or even blended with, alien European values. There is, for instance, the case of the Igbo who are often regarded as having massively embraced western ways. According to Sylvia Leith-Ross, an Igbo in the 1930s would - with disengaging facility - patronize holy communion and traditional magic and medicine, and plant \'side by side in the garden round his new cement and pan-roofed house the hibiscus of "civilization" and the ogirisi tree of pagan family rites\'. $^{1}$ Margaret Read has shown how the Nguni integrated the Christian Church and western education into their society, using both as instruments for further ensuring the survival of their culture in the modern world. They see no contradiction, and have no difficulty, in combining Christian and traditional Nguni rites in marriage and funeral ceremonies.$^{2}$ Professor Fallers has also described some Ugandan groups as \'enthusiastically and successfully\' accepting many elements of modernization - confining their influence, and adapting them to traditional culture and social structure. The point is that colonial Africans were probably not unaware of the elementary fact that accepting \'new forms [would] increase the range of alternatives\'$^{3}$ available to them.', 'last_edit_date': None, 'url': None, 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.51, 'probability_score': 0.05, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'The social repercussions of colonial rule: the new social structures', 'section_title': 'The main forces of change', 'content': 'So did the introduction of Christianity which sought to abolish tradi› tional gods and beliefs. Wherever Christianity took root, for instance, many traditional priests and other manipulators of the supernatural had to take to other professions. Slaves obtained their freedom, thus forcing those who formerly depended on slave labour to do their own work for themselves or shift to dependence on wage labour. Lands hitherto reserved for gods and goblins were released either for arable use or for the siting of social institutions like the school, hospital and so on. The younger generations went to school where they learned new techniques which equipped them for employment in government, commercial firms or missions. And since these jobs were available for the most part in urban areas, it means that conversion to Christianity could also imply a predisposi› tion to live in urban areas. Or to take another example, a man could go to the urban area in search of economic advancement while being still staunchly loyal to the traditional religion. In time, however, his physical separation from the shrines and religious rites of his home gods, as well as the economic, social and psychological pressures of the new environment could turn him into a Christian of sorts. These examples of how one social force usually produced a variegated impact could be multiplied many times.', 'last_edit_date': None, 'url': None, 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.508, 'probability_score': 0.05, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'New trends and processes in Africa in the nineteenth century', 'section_title': 'Emergence of the Western-educated elite', 'content': 'The greatest social impact of the missionary revolution, however, was the emergence of an educated elite in Africa. The regions that saw the greatest development of this phenomenon were undoubtedly South Africa and West Africa.', 'last_edit_date': None, 'url': None, 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.54, 'probability_score': 0.051, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'New trends and processes in Africa in the nineteenth century', 'section_title': 'New political trends', 'content': "the country' and, finally, to develop and facilitate the working of the mineral and other resources of the country. Particular emphasis was placed on the promotion of education of both sexes and on industrial training. As Clause 22 put it, That normal schools be attached to each national school for the express purpose of educating and instructing the scholars as carpenters, masons, sawyers, joiners, agriculturists, smiths, architects, builders, etc.", 'last_edit_date': None, 'url': None, 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.519, 'probability_score': 0.05, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'The Congo* Basin and Angola', 'section_title': 'Demography, society and politics in high-density areas', 'content': "Hence growth in the nineteenth century was still slow; but it was doubtless more pronounced than before, for it started from the relatively high base level achieved by the population of the area. As in the past, excess population was absorbed by movement elsewhere or by settlement in the savanna or the open forest, following a method of expansion that has left profound traces in the folk memory in the shape of traditions about 'migrations'. Excess population was also absorbed by areas practising a more diversified form of agriculture, and hence able, as P. Gourou puts it, to 'capitalize their surplus population'. Here a more sedentary type of settlement finally succeeded in overcoming the hostility of environments that had been gradually broken in down the ages, and from now on became favourable to human occupation. 9\nThis material history and the political and social history of the area both throw light on each other, with no one-way determining influence. In some cases a high-density area would develop as a base for hierarchical political organizations. This is what happened in the case of two high-density areas, Mangbetu and Zande, in north-eastern Zaire. In the Mbomu valley and as far south as the Vela, the Zande area was a relatively high-density area in the nineteenth century despite murderous wars (in the 1870s Georg Schweinfurth put its population density at 40 per sq km). The agrarian system of the Zande was older than the military power of the Avungara, who only began to unify the area at the end of the eighteenth century. Under their rule, however, the term Zande became synonymous with subject-farmers; and they developed a high-yield agriculture capable of feeding a population which grew all the more rapidly because of the accumulation of captives and dependents resulting from the raiding and slave-trading of the warrior-aristocracy.", 'last_edit_date': None, 'url': None, 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.511, 'probability_score': 0.05, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': '1 New trends in the Maghrib: Algeria, Tunisia and Libya', 'section_title': 'Rural society', 'content': "A clear distinction was made by contemporary observers between the citydweller (h'adharî) and the country-dweller {badam). What were the criteria for such a distinction? On the one hand, there was a complex city culture based upon the written word, whereas in the rural areas there persisted an oral, repetitive tradition; in religious matters, the instruction in law dis› pensed by the flirrt ('scholar') in the city contrasted with the teachings of the marabout and the triumph of'audio-visual' worship in the countryside. 9 In material matters, a monetary system and its concomitant activities were the life-blood of the cities, whereas a subsistence economy and the poorly developed means of production, as regards both human and technological resources were characteristic of the rural areas. From the social point of view, city-dwellers were becoming more rank-conscious and at the same time more individualistic, but country people abided by the undisputed rules of lineal or, to be more specific, patrilineal structures: this meant that human groups identified themselves in terms of their kinship ties sometimes more mythical than real - with an eponymous ancestor ('son of ...'). Beduin society formed a pattern of juxtaposed 'segments', either allied or opposed to each other in accordance with certain rules dictated not so much by blood ties as by the natural environment or the necessity to maintain an overall equilibrium.$^{10}$ The lineal principle implied egalitarianism, in theory, between 'brothers' and 'cousins' who, in some instances, might be enemies; the collective ownership of land; and mutual dependence and assistance in work. [{'id': 510, 'article_title': 'A Peep through Bathurst and other parts of the River Gambia', 'full_section_title': 'A Peep through Bathurst and other parts of the River Gambia', 'last_edit_date': None, 'num_tokens': 0, 'language': 'en', 'block_type': 'text', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/23_01_1865#article-1', 'issue_date': '23_01_1865', 'content': "On entering the River Gambia our attention was first attracted by a building on the left bank of the river, to which was attached a small light. We wondered what that was, and were told that it was a substitute for a lighthouse, and a miserable one it was. Our vessel suddenly came to anchor, to our great surprise, as we had intended to have a jolly good turn out on shore, and on inquiry we were told that the pilots would not conduct vessels to their safe anchorage in this intricate river at night. We grumbled and stamped our feet, but were obliged to succumb to the will of the pilate, and remained. Before break of day, however, steam was again up, and we were introduced, through deep channel by uncertain turnings amongst the sandbanks on the mouth of the river, to the anchorage opposite Bathurst.

It was in the rainy season of August, 1856, that I thus first visited St. Mary's. The night before there had been heavy rain. The appearance of the front buildings was indeed picturesque, white houses beautifully laid out, peeping through a row of bushy trees, unlike Sierra Leone, where the backs of the houses fronting the sea are in a demi-semi state of dilapidation, a standing disgrace to the colony. The frontage houses in the Gambia are in perfect harmony with each other, substantially built, and in very good condition. Through the kindness of our polite captain, I had an easy row in one of the ship's boats to the shore. I was a perfect stranger to the place, and my companions and myself intended to have a regular déjeuner in the hotel. We stood for a long time in the front street, which was in excellent condition, and I was surprised to find lamps hanging by ropes on trees all along the streets. On inquiry we found that there was no hotel, and no place of accommodation; and therefore, after a brief consultation with my companions, we agreed to make a regular inspection of the town. The condition of the back streets produced a rather unfavourable impression, those especially in the soldiers' and the Mohammedan town were in a state of swamp and dirt; there was very little drainage, the streets were covered with water knee-deep, and, as I was told by our guide, visiting from one house to the other was most difficult in some parts; in fact, he repeated the antiquated story that at times some of the people were obliged to visit by canoe; but this statement, in my second visit of 1864, I heard indignantly denied by natives of the Gambia, and from their countenances read that it was the production of an over-heated imagination."}, {'id': 4347, 'article_title': 'ELECTRICAL TOYS', 'full_section_title': 'ELECTRICAL TOYS', 'last_edit_date': None, 'num_tokens': 0, 'language': 'en', 'block_type': 'text', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/01_12_1881#article-16', 'issue_date': '01_12_1881', 'content': 'The attention of the public having been recently attracted to electricity, the inventors of conjuring tricks and toys have not been slow in utilising it for their own business. Some of their devices are most ingenious and amusing, while others enable those who are inclined to set up as amateur spiritualists. One of these devices is a mysterious drum, which in full view of the audience is "beaten" without any visible sign of the drumsticks. Another is a rapping and talking table, which is, perhaps, an old acquaintance amongst the spiritualists; but the most interesting are the electrical insects, which are placed in the most conspicuous parts of a room, and at least afford plenty of innocent amusement. One of the best of these consists of apparently a real plant growing in an ordinary pot, with one or more insects located on its branches or leaves. The pot contains a galvanic battery, and the insects, being made up of electric magnets, &c., they are easily caused to move their wings and exhibit signs of life merely by touching the pot. Handsomely painted butterflies placed on white lace curtains not only attract attention, but act in an extraordinary way when touched.'}, {'id': 4400, 'article_title': 'THE ELECTRIC LIGHT IN CHURCH.', 'full_section_title': 'THE ELECTRIC LIGHT IN CHURCH.', 'last_edit_date': '12-31-1882', 'num_tokens': 0, 'language': 'en', 'block_type': 'text', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/01_03_1882#article-14', 'issue_date': '01_03_1882', 'content': "On the night of December 31, in St. James's, Westmoreland-street, Marylebone, the Edison and Maxim lights were used for the first time in a London church, under the direction of Mr. Lachlan, of the Société de la Force et la Lumière, 446, Strand. Three clear-glass lamps hung under three arches separating the side aisle and vestry, over the altar was a strong Maxim, and two others in a pulpit were enclosed in milk-white globes. The light was brilliant, soft, and steady, more steady than any gas. Faure's secondary battery, consisting of forty boxes, was used. These were deposited at five in the afternoon, ready charged, and no engine or any additional machinery was required. The wires were quickly connected, before seven o'clock service, with the suspended lamps, the lights being lowered or turned up to different degrees of brilliancy at discretion. A fine loan collection of sacred paintings was thus admirably lighted. There was an immense congregation, and crowds of people kept passing through the vestry till past ten o'clock. A selection from the _Messiah_ took the place of an anthem, and we understand that Mr. Haweis was indebted to the kindness of Miss de Fonblanque and Miss Alitsen for an admirable rendering of the solos in the organ gallery; no names, however, appeared on any programme. The usual choir took the choruses. This is the first application of the electric light to churches, and no one can help feeling that in these steady lamps, burning in vacuo, neither giving out heat nor using up air—easily stored and carried, and perfectly soft, and, let us add, safe—we have the light of the future for all crowded buildings. The light from the Faure accumulator is far steadier than that used at the Savoy Theatre; it is the same as that in the Brighton Pulman car. The supply from the secondary battery being constant and uniform, there is not the least flicker; the Northern railway companies are adopting it, and next week the Paris and Lyons train is to be lighted by the same Society, the revolutions of the train's own wheels being skilfully utilised to produce the electricity, free of all further cost. Well may we say, What next?"}, {'id': 4578, 'article_title': 'The Montreal Ice Palace and Carnival', 'full_section_title': 'The Montreal Ice Palace and Carnival', 'last_edit_date': '01-23-1883', 'num_tokens': 0, 'language': 'en', 'block_type': 'text', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/01_02_1883#article-20', 'issue_date': '01_02_1883', 'content': "As many of our West Coast readers now know what ice really is, we think the following will interest them, as they will be able to form an idea of the beauty of the ice structure:—

MONTREAL, January 23, 1883.—The Montreal (Canada) Ice Carnival has opened under most favourable circumstances. The weather was cold and clear; the thermometer at zero. All the hotels are filled to overflowing with visitors. There were large delegations from New York and other parts of the United States. The carnival began with the contractors' drive and dinner. There were over 200 sleighs in line. Then came the formal opening of the magnificent ice palace in Dominion-square, standing on a commanding eminence in the heart of the city. This structure, the first of the kind ever erected on this continent, is a great object of attraction. It is nearly a hundred feet square in the interior, with towers fifteen feet square and thirty feet in height. At each angle the walls are twenty-five feet high. From the centre rises a massive tower thirty-two feet square and a hundred feet high. The walls and towers are constructed of blocks of ice taken from the St. Lawrence. They are forty inches in length, from fourteen to twenty in breadth, and as transparent as crystal. They were put in their place with derricks, and were deluged with water, which froze them into a solid mass. The roofs of the building and the towers are made of beams, upon which were spread cedar branches. Over these a spray of water was thrown, which froze them into solid masses of ice with pendant icicles. When the bright sun falls upon this glittering palace with its frosted roof, the effect is said to be indescribably beautiful. At night it was illuminated with thousands of electric lights within and without, making the spectacle one of surpassing brilliancy."}, {'id': 4640, 'article_title': 'A New Light', 'full_section_title': 'A New Light', 'last_edit_date': None, 'num_tokens': 0, 'language': 'en', 'block_type': 'text', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/01_06_1883#article-18', 'issue_date': '01_06_1883', 'content': 'Another Russian invention in the science of illumination is announced in the *Engineer* by Captain A. de Khotineky, of St. Petersburg. It is a form of the Drummond light, and is thus described:—

"The refractory material has the shape of a prism or pencil made of a specially prepared magnesia compound, which is unaffected by air, and is even not spoiled by water; it stands the temperature so well that, although it looks so delicate and thin, it will remain burning for three hundred hours. A stream of oxygen and coal gas under very low pressure—eight inches of water—is directed on to the axis of the prism, which becomes incandescent, and, unlike the Drummond light, it is not a point, but a line of light of about two inches long, and, moreover, this light radiates all round. When coal gas is not to be obtained it can be superseded by paraffin, spirit, or other form of lamp. In St. Petersburg it is in use at the State Paper Manufactory, where colour printing is executed on a very large scale. In the shops where coloured silks and other fabrics are sold the advantage of the new white light is especially appreciated. The size and shape of the burners and prisms are made in great variety, so as to give light from 25 to 300 candles strong.'}, {'id': 4961, 'article_title': 'THE CAPE TOWN INDUSTRIAL EXHIBITION', 'full_section_title': 'THE CAPE TOWN INDUSTRIAL EXHIBITION', 'last_edit_date': None, 'num_tokens': 0, 'language': 'en', 'block_type': 'text', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/01_11_1884#article-21', 'issue_date': '01_11_1884', 'content': 'The Exhibition now open was projected about six months ago, and it was at first intended to hold it as soon after the return of His Excellency the Governor from England as was convenient. The movement, once set on foot, had in its favour the "colonial industrial" movement, but it had against it the terrible depression of the times. The Committee persevered, however, and the result is seen in the really fine collection, meeting with universal approval, that has been opened. The Committee, after several proposals had been discussed as to the erection of a new building, made arrangements for the hire of the building erected by Cagli, in the Goede Hope Lodge Gardens, for the so-called International Exhibition, and known to this day as the Exhibition Building. The building had been fitted up as a theatre, so the stage had to be removed. This was done at the last moment, and an annexe erected on the Government Gardens side of the building to take the overflowing exhibits with which the Committee found themselves flooded at the last moment. The lateness of space applications, and many difficulties tedious to relate now they are overcome, have taxed the efforts of the Committee and Sub-committees severely; but there has never been an undertaking in Cape Town more thoroughly carried out. The building is not very comely, but it has been so completely draped in flags that all its ungainly outlines are hidden, and the scene is as gay as need be. Captain Hewat kindly rendered his assistance in the disposal of these flags, which are of all nations and designs, from Imperial Eagles and Royal Standards to bits of plain bunting. They are suspended to perfection, and the view of them from the gallery is very fine. The annexe is devoted to in-door machinery and heavy exhibits. The main building is used for general exhibits; the gallery for fine arts, models, and a few stands for which no room could be found below; and the yard is for machinery in motion, and the rougher kinds of exhibits generally. The Exhibition is lighted with the electric light, and will be open every evening. Bands of music will play and entertainments will be given at intervals for the three weeks during which the Exhibition is open.'}, {'id': 5825, 'article_title': 'Produce Markets', 'full_section_title': 'Produce Markets', 'last_edit_date': None, 'num_tokens': 0, 'language': 'en', 'block_type': 'text', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/01_04_1889#article-7', 'issue_date': '01_04_1889', 'content': 'Terms of Subscription (in advance), Monthly, 5d.; or 5s. per annum, by Post Office Order or Stamps.

THE ÆOLUS WATERSPRAY GENERAL VENTILATING AND ELECTRICAL ENGINEERING COMPANY'S SYSTEMS OF Heating, Cooling, Ventilating, and Electric Lighting, ARE THE CHEAPEST AND BEST.

**Testimonials.**  
From R. Norman Shaw, Architect to the Royal Academy.  
29 Bloomsbury Square, London, W.C., February 19th, 1884.

The "Æolus" Waterspray Company have fixed two Air Extractors and one Air Warmer in the Life School of the Royal Academy of Arts with, we all think, the happiest results. Our troubles with that School have always been very great, as, owing to the amount of gas consumed and the necessity of keeping the School well heated on account of the nude models, its tendency has been to get unbearably hot; and when windows were attempted to be opened the draughts were most dangerous. It is now kept at a pleasant even temperature, and there are no draughts. The reason for this is not difficult to find. The very hot air from the steam-pipes, and the fumes from the gas, are carried off as fast as they are generated; and a continual stream of warm fresh air being supplied, the School is kept comfortable.  
(Signed) R. Norman Shaw, R.A., Architect.

From Lamb and Armstrong.

Dear Sir,  
We have pleasure in testifying to the efficiency of your "Invisible Roof Ventilators," which we fixed on above church, with admirable results.  
We are, yours faithfully,  
(Signed) Lamb and Armstrong, Architects.

To the Secretary of the Æolus Waterspray Company.

ELECTRIC LIGHTING OF CHURCHES, CHAPELS, SCHOOLS, PUBLIC HALLS, FACTORIES, STREETS, OFFICES, AND PRIVATE RESIDENCES, BY ENGINE AND DYNAMO, FOR ARC OR INCANDESCENT LAMPS, OR BY PRIMARY BATTERIES, AS REQUIRED, Either in connexion with or independent of their well-known systems of Ventilation.

TEMPORARY INSTALLATIONS FOR BALLS, PARTIES, FETES, &c., ON VERY REASONABLE TERMS.

APPLY TO THE MANAGER, 124 HIGH HOLBORN, LONDON, W.C.

DURKEE'S GREEN MOUNTAIN VEGETABLE OINTMENT.'}]

[{'document_title': 'The Future of Electricity', 'section_title': '', 'content': 'At the weekly meeting of the Society of Arts, March 24th, Professor John Perry read a paper, which was illustrated by many experiments, "On the Future Development of Electrical Appliances." He said: "Electrical energy can be transmitted to a distance, and even to many thousands of miles, but can it be transformed at the distant place into mechanical or any other required form of energy nearly equal in amount to what was supplied? Unfortunately, hitherto the practical answer made by existing machines is 'No.' But, fortunately, Joule's experiments and other facts tell us that in electric machines of the future, and in their connecting wires, there will be little heating, and therefore little loss. We shall, at no distant date, have great central stations, possibly situated at the bottom of coal-pits, where enormous steam engines will drive enormous electric machines. We shall have wires laid along every street, lapped into every house, as gas-pipes are at present; we shall have the quantity of electricity used in each house registered, as gas is at present; and it will be passed through little electric machines to drive machinery, to produce ventilation, to replace stoves and fires, to work apple-parers and mangles, and barbers' brushes, among other things, as well as to give everybody an electric light. It had been supposed that to transmit the power of Niagara Falls to New York, a copper cable of enormous thickness would be needed. Professor Ayrton showed that the whole power might be transmitted by a fine copper wire, if it could only be sufficiently well insulated. He also showed that the one thing preventing our receiving the whole of our power was the mechanical friction which occurs in the machines. He showed, in fact, how to get rid of electrical friction. Professor Ayrton and himself had come to the conclusion that very large continuous current machines, with separate exciters, or perhaps even magneto-electric machines, driven very fast by steam engines, will have an important place in the future transmission of energy by electrical methods. With such machines it would be possible to heat, light, and ventilate all the houses in New York, and to give to large and small workshops the power required to drive their machinery by means of an ordinary telegraph wire (but with some exceptionally good method of insulation), transmitting energy from as great a distance as the Falls of Niagara. The experiments of Dr. Siemens showed that there could be no doubt that the introduction of electric railways everywhere was merely a question of capital and the sacrifice of much existing plant. This kind of proof was very much needed by capitalists. But the electrician saw much further; he saw better insulation for the conductor, and application of the above principles to hundreds of miles of rail instead of a thousand yards; he saw, in fact, that the larger the experiment the greater must be its success. He looked forward to the absence of a vitiated atmosphere in our underground railways. He saw that the weight of rails (for there would be no heavy locomotive in the future, each carriage would have its own driving and breaking machinery) and the cost of bridges and wear and tear of permanent way might become less than one quarter of what they are at present; he saw, in fact, all the advantages that would arise when, instead of making a heavy steam engine travel backwards and forwards with carriages, the carriages alone travel, and the steam engine is not near the railway at all. After a number of interesting experiments bearing on the subject of the storage of energy, the lecturer concluded by exhibiting models to illustrate his belief that it will become possible by electricity to enable a man in London to see an occurrence going on in a distant town.', 'last_edit_date': '1881-03-24', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/01_08_1881#article-12', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.537, 'probability_score': 0.068, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'The New Electric Railway at Berlin', 'section_title': '', 'content': 'Our Berlin Correspondent, describing the new electric railway there, already referred to in a telegram, says that the system, which has been in use in Berlin for more than a year, has not proved a financial success. It has also been found that there is some inconvenience attending the transmission of the electric current through the rails. A horse, while crossing this line, striking it with his shoe, received a severe shock. It is impossible, moreover, to repair or remove the rails without causing a suspension of traffic over the entire route, since such removal interrupts the current. Herr Siemens, to meet these and other objections, devised his new system, which is far more practicable than the first. Over the entire line two cables are suspended parallel to and about twelve inches from each other on poles approximately 16 feet above the ground. Along these cables a system of wheels passes, connecting with the tramcar by another cable which can be detached from the car at pleasure. The cables are charged with electricity, which is generated at a station about the middle of the route, and which is taken up by the apparatus as it runs over them. It then passes through the connecting cable, down beneath the tramcar, over a system of drums which unites with the running gear. The apparatus passing along the suspended cables either precedes or follows the car. The speed of the vehicle is regulated by a crank, and a complete stop can be made as readily as if it were drawn by horses. On Saturday, during the trial, two cars were run, first separately and afterwards together. In the first case two distinct connecting cables are necessary, while in the second one answers the same purpose, the electricity passing through the car-couplings, the only difference being a diminution of velocity owing to the additional weight. The length of the route run over on the trial trip is about three miles, a portion of the distance being uphill, an inclination of 1 to 28. A car can be run up this grade at the rate of from 15 to 20 miles an hour, while on a level it will make 30 miles to the hour. After having thoroughly tested the working of the railway, visitors were driven to the country to witness the operation of a road car which Herr Siemens has invented. Colonial-office, Gold Coast, July 4, 1871.', 'last_edit_date': '1871-07-04', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/23_08_1871#article-7', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.516, 'probability_score': 0.066, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'Electric Railroads', 'section_title': '', 'content': 'Our attention is constantly directed to the new discoveries of science and their practical application, with a view to their adaptability or otherwise to the growing wants of the British West-African Settlements, and the work of development of their resources about which our anxiety is unceasing. Among those which have lately come to the front is the applicability of the now proved electric railway, which has been laid down and worked in the immediate vicinity of the capital of the German Empire.

On this railway, some seven English miles in length, trains impelled by electricity as the motive power have been running at a velocity of twenty miles an hour; and even a greater speed is said by Mons. Siemens, the inventor, to be attainable. One of the advantages of this system is the lightness of rail consequent upon the heavy steam locomotive being dispensed with. We are yet only in the infancy of this application of electricity as a motive power on railroads; but the results are, as stated above, already so important that there is strong reason to believe in such an employment of electricity becoming much cheaper than that of the steam locomotive, at the same time that the cost of construction of road will be very much diminished. We had intended to give a detailed account of the working of the Berlin railway, but find that our available space will not allow us to do so in the present number. The West African railways, whenever they may be constructed, will not at first require a greater speed than that which it has been already proved by the Berlin working may be easily obtained; the trains will not be heavy, nor require to be very frequently run; and in many other respects it seems to us that this invention—this new conquest of science by the application of electricity as a motive power—is full of promise for Africa in the future. We are now merely introducing the subject to the notice and attention of our readers, and defer to a future opportunity a detailed exposition of the new principle. It may after all, and we hope it will, turn out that the delay which has inevitably occurred in the introduction of railways in West Africa has not been time altogether lost, by science having prepared for her a better system than the one which has revolutionized the civilized countries of the world.', 'last_edit_date': '1881-06-01', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/01_06_1881#article-19', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.541, 'probability_score': 0.068, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'AFRICAN TRAVELLERS AND EXPLORERS', 'section_title': '', 'content': '## RAILWAYS, THE GREAT MODERN CIVILIZER.

The great civilizer of modern times has been the railway, together with the electric telegraph, which, at its beginning, was constructed exclusively along the railway lines. The Colonies have not been slow to realize the necessity of the iron way, if they would open to agriculture their unoccupied lands, and get a ready conveyance for their produce to home and foreign markets. The mileage of railways in British India in 1878 was 8,215—an increase of nearly 900 upon the previous year, and a greater increase than had taken place before since Lord Lytton assumed the Viceroyalty. In Australia there were 3,977 miles of railway, including the horse railways which South Australia is contenting herself with until she can afford to construct more substantial lines. India has thus about twice as much railway mileage as Australia to accommodate more than ninety times the population. The Cape has made the greatest advance in this respect of all our Colonies, as she has multiplied her railroads tenfold in five years—namely, from sixty-seven miles in 1874 to 663 in 1878. The Mauritius and Jamaica have made no difference since 1870, the former having sixty-six miles, and the latter unprogressive island twenty-five. In the Dominion of Canada the extension has been from 4,002 miles in 1874 to 5,915 in 1871. Telegraph wires can, however, be stretched where the railway engineer must be content to wait. Accordingly, India had, in the year already quoted, 18,210 miles of telegraph line, or considerably more than twice the length of the railways; while in Australia the telegraph mileage was 15,515, or more than six times the railway mileage; and the Cape of Good Hope had 2,713 miles of wire.', 'last_edit_date': '1880-07-01', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/01_07_1880#article-22', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.513, 'probability_score': 0.066, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'The People of Lagos upon European Influence upon the West Coast', 'section_title': '', 'content': '"As a civilizing agent: commerce is the mother of civilization, and has been, both in our days and in the earliest times, the grand engine by which the blessings of civilization and the treasures of knowledge and science are diffused. By bringing us into contact with the inhabitants of other countries, it produces moral and intellectual effects of the greatest importance. It gives us new tastes, at the same time that it affords the means for their gratification; it enables us to compare our own laws, institutions, and manners with those of the Europeans, to profit by their example, or to take warning by their fate. Let us compare Lagos thirty-five years ago with Lagos today, and we have a striking instance of the potency of commerce as a civilizing agent. Lagos thirty-five years ago—ruled over by a despot, at whose nod a soul could be hurried into eternity; Lagos with its idolatry, its slave barracoons, its bush and miserable mud huts. Lagos of today—an emporium of legitimate commerce, a place of refuge for slaves, a centre of civilization; law, order, and justice, the rule and not the exception; the bush substituted for roads; in place of mud huts, with their thatched roofs, that fall so easy a prey to fire, we are having substantial brick buildings, with iron or slate roofs; the churches, the schools; the moral and mental improvement of the natives—are not these proof enough of the good wrought by commercial intercourse with Europe? Well, I will give one more instance. In 1873, domestic slavery was abolished on the Gold Coast. By force of arms? No! During the Ashantee Expedition, the English lost so many men that reparation was demanded and granted—namely, the abolition of domestic slavery. This took place when the Gold Coast was only a British protectorate.', 'last_edit_date': '1885-02-16', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/01_05_1885#article-11', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.491, 'probability_score': 0.065, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'THE ELECTRIC RAILWAY.', 'section_title': '', 'content': 'The electric railway at Berlin is so much of a success that permission has been given for its extension as far as Potsdam, provided an alteration is made in the arrangement of the conductors where they are crossed by roads. At present the rails themselves serve as conductors of the current, and it has been found that frequently horses crossing them are apt to get into such a position that they receive a shock from the current in some cases so severe that they fall, but, as a rule, sufficient to frighten them, and cause them to bolt.', 'last_edit_date': '1881-07-01', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/01_07_1881#article-18', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.556, 'probability_score': 0.069, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'LAGOS.', 'section_title': '', 'content': 'This place has made great progress since it was annexed to Great Britain; and we may reasonably expect that the number of civilised people will continually increase. Mechanical ingenuity will be soon heavily tasked in the United States for machines to perform much of the cotton, sugar, and corn plantation labour that formerly fell to the lot of the now emancipated slaves. The agricultural labour necessities of the North consequent on the withdrawal of so many of the male population from the farms for the army during the late war, have already given a greatly-increased stimulus to the production of labour-saving machines there; and the slavery abolition journals of the North are calling attention to the fact. Thus, an instance is cited where a corn-field of 160 acres was ploughed, planted, and cultivated, no man walking a step to achieve all this. "A rotary spader, drawn by four horses, and driven by a man upon the box, ploughed the field to a uniform depth of eight inches, and gave such thorough tilth, that it was not necessary to use a harrow at all. A corn-planter, drawn by two horses, and driven by a man upon the box, next planted the seed. A cultivator drawn by two mules, one walking on each side of the knee-high corn, and driven by a man upon the box, completed the culture of a row at a single operation; and in the tool-house lay another machine, also to be drawn by horses, which will cut down the corn when it is ripe and lay it in regular rows, to be finally gathered by hand. But it is expected that by next year this machine will be so improved as to gather up the corn also."', 'last_edit_date': '1865-07-22', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/22_07_1865#article-23', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.497, 'probability_score': 0.065, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'One of the Results of Railways', 'section_title': '', 'content': 'Mr. Ghose, the Indian Barrister, in a lecture on the present condition of the East Indies, said: "The most striking effect of British rule has been to break down the national and ethnological barriers between the natives of various districts, and to mould them into one people; with a growing sense that they are a nation. The development of a railway system has of course had much to do with this change. The spread of our language and literature, which give a common interest in our administration, all exert the same uniting influence. The change is therefore likely to go on at an accelerating rate. A public opinion has been formed...

and as it is useless to act directly on the rulers at Calcutta, it seeks to get behind the sources of their authority by a direct appeal to England."', 'last_edit_date': '1879-09-01', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/01_09_1879#article-19', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.494, 'probability_score': 0.065, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'Notice to Mariners', 'section_title': '', 'content': '(From the London Gazette.)*

(No. 187.)—**Africa—West Coast.**

**Cape Sierra Leone—Intended Alterations in Light.**

Information has been received from the Colonial Government of Sierra Leone, that on or about October 1, 1886, the following alterations will be made in the light exhibited from the lighthouse on Cape Sierra Leone:—

The existing fixed red light will be discontinued, and will be replaced by two vertical lights.

The upper light will be a fixed white light, varied by a flash every thirty seconds, elevated 75 feet above the sea, and should be visible, in clear weather, from a distance of 14 miles.

The illuminating apparatus will be dioptric, or by lenses of the fourth order.

The lower light will be a fixed red light, elevated 52 feet above the sea, and visible from seaward through an arc of 121° on either side of an imaginary line joining the Carpenter Rock and the light, or between the bearings of N. 84½° E. and S. 70½° E.

The illuminating apparatus of this light will be catoptric, or by reflectors.

The lighthouse, 69 feet high, is white with red lantern.

[The bearings are magnetic, and are given from seaward. Variation 20° Westerly in 1886.]

By command of their Lordships,

W. J. L. Wharton, Hydrographer.

Hydrographic Office, Admiralty, London,

August 5, 1886.

This Notice affects the following Admiralty Charts:—North Atlantic Ocean, eastern part, No. 2060a; Gambia River to Cape Lopez, No. 594; Isles de Los to Sherbro Island, No. 601; Sierra Leone River, No. 616. It is, in my opinion, a matter of the utmost importance that there should not be any further delay on the part of the Government in taking steps to construct some of the lines surveyed. This absence contrasts with the substantial evidence provided by The African Times articles, which support the claim that the publication played a crucial role in colonial Africa. The articles frequently expose abuses and mismanagement in colonial prisons, such as those in Cape Coast and Bathurst, and criticize the arbitrary actions of colonial officials, thereby challenging prevailing colonial narratives. The cargo, free on board, cost 74,500f., and was insured to 85,000f. Is that too much? We should suppose not, and had we entertained the remotest doubt as to the ability of either Captain Schuurman or Hoffman, we should certainly have covered the interest of both vessel and cargo to a larger amount.

Fourth.—Lloyd's agent has, in this case, nothing to do with either vessel or cargo. Not a single Englishman has any interest whatever in our affairs. But it appears, in this matter, that there are even British public officers who seem incapable of apprehending that other nations besides their own navigate the ocean, for the commandant of British Accra, who had undertaken to realise such goods as were saved, assured Captain Hoffman that he was accountable to no one but Lloyd and Co. (sic), and he refused officially to deliver up the books and papers that were saved, and the nett proceeds of the goods. Do you not consider such conduct to be very strange and arbitrary, or rather, injudicious, Mr. Editor? We, at least, think so; and we have consequently entered a legal protest against this manner of proceeding, and lodged a formal complaint against Mr. Edmunds' conduct with our Minister for Foreign Affairs.

We are not in the habit of compiling for the press, Mr. Editor, but in the present instance found ourselves compelled publicly to contradict the foolish and slanderous report of "A. Z."—whose real name we can easily conjecture—by a statement of facts; and we expect, from your well-known impartiality, that you will insert this refutation in the first-coming number of the *African Times*.

In anticipation thereof, we have the honour to be, with the highest respect, Sir, your obedient servants,'}, {'id': 1587, 'article_title': 'CAPE COAST PRISON', 'full_section_title': 'CAPE COAST PRISON', 'last_edit_date': None, 'num_tokens': 0, 'language': 'en', 'block_type': 'text', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/23_06_1869#article-17', 'issue_date': '23_06_1869', 'content': 'Four or five years ago it was our painful duty to expose, on evidence furnished to us by Mr. W. C. Finlason and others, the disgraceful condition of the places in which prisoners were confined at Cape Coast. The statements were of course denied, though every word of them was true; but as a speedy reform followed the exposure, and our bringing the matter, which we did, under the immediate attention of the Government, we were satisfied to allow the official abuse heaped upon us to remain unanswered, treating it with the contempt which alone it deserved. A subsequent exposure by us of malpractices in Bathurst Gaol led also to improvements there, amid showers of abuse on the offending Editor of the African Times. But now we feel as if we had been guilty of a dereliction of duty, although, of course, we can only expose those evils and abuses which are communicated to us, so in spite of all that rebuked officials say of us, we never invent grievances and abuses. Our invaluable co-operator, Mr. Rainy, has lately enabled us, by a letter of his, to bring the state of the Sierra Leone prisons under public notice. The fault there is the absence of classification, and the herding together of prisoners in a manner that can only lead to an increase of crime and a most vicious demoralisation. The evidence in the case of Joseph Gordon, which occupies so much space in our (this month enlarged) paper, shows that the reformed Bathurst Gaol is in need of many further reforms, among which must be placed the medical examination of every prisoner before he is set to work, the prohibition of punishments by mere verbal order of authorities, however exalted, and the making the visiting justices responsible for a due demand on the Executive for such clothing and bedding, &c., as are absolutely essential to the health of the prisoners. Last year we had to denounce the cells of Accra prisons, in which the life of poor Thomas Williams was so cruelly sacrificed—and the improvised powder-magazine dungeon in which it pleased Mr. Ussher, Mr. Parker, and Dr. Skues that poor Mr. Finlason should be tortured. And now again Cape Coast, that hotbed of all official abuses and mismanagement, iniquity, and oppression, crops up in a most offensive way. We had hoped that our former exposure of Cape Coast prisons, and it being known that we are never without correspondents in Cape Coast, would have insured the permanency of those sanitary reforms that ensued on our such former exposure; but we can only suppose that the virtual approval by the Colonial-office of all the official atrocities of Ussher, Parker, Skues and others by the promotion of Parker,—the whitewashing of Skues, whom, contrary to all reliable evidence, the Duke of Buckingham did not consider at all responsible for the death of poor Williams,—and the non-dismissal of Ussher and others from the service, has had the intelligible effect of inducing the present authorities there to believe that they may do whatever seemeth good in their own eyes, without fear of censure; and that to this is owing the state of the Cape Coast prison described in our last number. It is our duty to repeat it. Such a state of a Government prison is too shameful to allow of our passing it by with a mere condemnation of the atrocity of sending such a man as Mr. Lovell into it. Here is the description, reprinted from our last:—'}, {'id': 2784, 'article_title': 'FORGERIES ON THE WEST COAST.', 'full_section_title': 'FORGERIES ON THE WEST COAST.', 'last_edit_date': None, 'num_tokens': 0, 'language': 'en', 'block_type': 'text', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/30_09_1874#article-17', 'issue_date': '30_09_1874', 'content': 'The forger has, we regret to say, been again busy on the West Coast. Some years ago, while steam communication between the West Coast and England was in its infancy, and consequently slow and infrequent, forged bills of lading, and other forged documents, from the West Coast were far from being unknown in England—so far, indeed, from being unknown that, except in the hands of merchants of position and character, it was not considered at all safe to make advances on them. With more rapid communication between Great Britain and the West Coast, the forger, having no longer time in his favour, seemed to have disappeared altogether, and we hoped and believed that he had done so; but a recent fact proves that he had not; and that, although his difficulties had been greatly increased, he might still practise his nefarious trade with temporary success. On the arrival of the steamer Africa from the West Coast ports, early in September, we received a document brought by her, purporting to be a bill of lading of eight puncheons of palm oil, shipped by the Elmina at Bonny, and consigned to us; as also another document, purporting to be a cash order for 62l., signed by the purser of the Elmina. It soon appeared that no such oil had ever been shipped on the Elmina; that the initials appended, purporting to be those of Capt. Rattray, were forged; and that the signature of the draft, purporting to be that of Mr. F. Purser, the purser of the Elmina, was also a forgery. The bill of lading stated that the oil was shipped at Bonny by W. W. Johnson. On consultation with Mr. F. Purser—being anxious, of course, to trace out the forger—we found that he had no difficulty in identifying the writing as that of a West African who embarked on board the Elmina at Fernando Po, with expressed destination to Sierra Leone; but whom Mr. F. Purser recognized as being one Shepherd, who had been convicted of forgery some time ago at Lagos. Shepherd, alias Johnson, left the steamer at Jellah Coffee, instead of going up to Sierra Leone; and Mr. Purser very thoughtfully sent some intimation on shore as to the character and identity of this new addition to the Jellah Coffee community; but the villain was rapid in his movements. He appears to have gone on at once to Quitta, and there succeeded in obtaining advances on the forged documents above mentioned. They were then sent on to us from Quitta as valuable ones, which they purported to be, and were believed to be. We entertain no doubt whatever that, having succeeded in robbing our correspondent, he found some excuse for leaving Quitta without delay—possibly, and indeed probably, by the very steamer, the Africa, which was bringing the forgeries to us. The forged bill of lading we returned by the next steamer from England to our correspondent, who had sent it to us. The forged draft we placed in the hands of Mr. F. Purser, purser of the Elmina, which left Liverpool on the 19th inst., who, by permission of the Board of Directors of the African Steamship Company, kindly promised to use every effort for stopping the criminal career of this Shepherd or Johnson, or whatever he may be now calling himself, on the West Coast. We should not have given this publicity to the deeds of the forger if our journal had been going out also by the Elmina; but as that steamer will be a fortnight in advance of the September number of the African Times, we record the facts, with the hope of preventing other innocent and unsuspecting people being imposed upon by him; and also that some of our readers may recognize him, and be instrumental in putting a stop, for a time at least, to his career of crime. The wide publicity given to matters reported by our journal, may not unreasonably be expected to produce this result, as it will be the duty of any and every one of our readers who may identify this Shepherd or Johnson in their community, to give information to all around them of the criminal course which he has hitherto pursued; so that every possible obstacle may be placed in the way of his making further victims.'}]
